After a few weeks of less pressure I find only an occasional bristle coming loose. Overall I find the brush to hold a good amount of water, lather well, have a comfortable feel. I would recommend to anyone looking for a good badger brush.

I received the replacement, and it addressed both of the issues that I had below. Bristles are more sturdy and the wooden handle is unblemished. Customer service was AMAZING. Thanks Escali. The customer service experience definitely made up for whatever defects existed on the original product. Original: I bought the brush for two reasons. Asthetically, it looked very well designed. The piece I received however has a chalky, carbon tinge to one side of the wooden handle that is very ugly. It won't wash off. The second reason is that the badger hair is supposedly superior to boar hair brushes. This brush has VERY soft hairs. They pretty much fail to lather up shaving cream I use.

  66. I bought this item because I had a shaving brush that lost all of its hair like a maple tree loses its leaves in Autumn. It was part of a starter kit that I bought three years ago when I made the awesome switch to shaving with a straight edge instead of the $25 modern razors. I had some extra Amazon points so I picked this brush up because the picture looked fancy. Now, when it said it was 100% pure badger hair, call me naive, but I thought that was some gimmick name for new brush hair technology. I was not expecting it to smell like my dog. This hair is fresh off the badger. The smell eventually goes away and you'll be thankful you went with animal hair instead of plastic. It produces a better lather, and it's more gentle on the skin. Now that I had made the accidental upgrade I don't think I am going back to the cheaper plastic models.

Don't let the fact that it's badger sway you. If you're starting wet shaving I'd just go with a cheap synthetic omega brush and then upgrade to a nice badger brush if you feel the need.

I've already purchased a second Escali badger shaving brush for travel and may buy one or two more as replacements for when I wear these out. But it lifts the beard and produces a lather that is just unreal! Perfect and creamy! Dense and lush. If you are wet shaving on a budget like I am, DO IT! I hope they stay in business for many, many years to come!!!<br /><br />I am a super happy customer!!

  150. Excellent, and just what I expected from a Badger Brush
  151. We should start off with a little terminology. When you see terms like &#34;100% badger hair&#34; or &#34;Pure badger hair&#34; in shaving brushes, that isn't saying that it's the only type of hair in the brush, but rather those terms refer to the grade of badger hair being used. In this case, the lowest grade. The misconception is that with an Escali you're getting a quality badger brush at a fraction of the price, but you're really not.<br /><br />What's wrong with low-grade badger hair? It's prickly, and can irritate your skin. If you already have sensitive skin and struggle with ingrown hairs, this brush will not help you.<br /><br />Can you shave with this brush? Absolutely, and I did for months before I learned of much better options in a comparable price range. You will get by, until you learn of what can be had, and then you won't go back.<br /><br />What should you look for instead? Boar hair. While boar hair isn't quite the quality of a good silvertip badger brush, it blows the Escali out of the water in performance and is surprisingly cheap. There is a break in period, and once you're through that, you will have a fine brush that will be much softer and will build a much better lather than the Escali ever will. There are two main brands that make very good boar hair brushes that can be purchased in the $10-25 range, and those are Omega and Semogue.<br /><br />Where do I find a boar hair brush? I don't recommend buying a boar hair brush off of Amazon, as there are other vendors that sell them at better prices. A quick google search of &#34;Omega boar brush&#34; will bring you many options. I won't name any specific vendors in order to remain free from accusation of marketing.<br /><br />Where can I learn more? One of the best sources for learning about wet shaving is the &#34;wicked_edge&#34; sub on Reddit. Many people share their own experiences with different products, and I myself have learned a great deal there.<br /><br />Feel free to comment with anyquestions.<br /><br />P.S. Even after shaving with this brush for 3-4 months, it was still shedding plenty of hair which is annoying.
  152. I bought this since I wanted to start shaving again without using the stuff in the aerosol cans. This brush has been good to lather up with. It's a great beginner's brush. It arrived ahead of schedule & the price a good deal as well for a brush made with badger hair. I would highly recommend buying this brush if you want to start shaving the old fashion way again.

  159. I decided to try out wet shaving with a safety razor. I did a research on brushed boar vs badger vs synthetic. I opted out for the badger since it holds and retains water better. Which it does. The brush did not smell until you first dip into water. Which is a common thing from what I read. Due to the chemicals to treat the hair bristles. I just dunked the brush with water and a bit of vinegar and stopped that smell. Once I used it with the Proraso Shaving Cream I did not notice a smell. The brush was excellent for lathering the soap and felt smooth on my face.

  171. This was my first shaving brush and as an intro into wet shaving, it leaves much to be desired. Now that I've purchased a boar's hair (Semogue 620) I realize what a waste of money it was to be cheap and buy this brush. As a disclaimer, I've used this brush almost every day for a full month.<br /><br />Pros:<br />1) Cheap<br />2) Creates good lather (badger brushes are generally easier at creating lather than boar. But an average boar brush will scrub better unless you go with high end badger brushes)<br /><br />Cons:<br />1) Sheds constantly! I've used this brush for about a month now and it constantly sheds a couple of hairs with every single use. It sheds in my soap dish when I gather soap and sheds on my face when I apply the lather. A month later and it's still shedding.<br />2) No backbone. I hadn't realized until I got my boar brush recently, but this cheap badger brush has no backbone. It doesn't provide any scrubbing action to lift your whiskers because the hairs part too easily once it touches your face. I even tried holding the base of the brush and not the handle and it didn't make much difference.<br />3) Uncomfortable. The handle was uncomfortable for me to hold. That may differ for other people. YMMV<br /><br />My overall recommendation:<br />The only people that would consider purchasing this brush would be someone new to wet shaving. So to these people, I say to stay away! Spend an extra $5-8 and get a good boar brush, that will last you a long time (my Escali is on permanent display).<br /><br />Why cheap boar is better than cheap badger:<br />1) I believe almost all boar brushes have good scrubbing action to lift your whiskers and exfoliate your skin<br />2) Improves with each use, the ends naturally split over time. This makes the boar start to feel softer at the ends like the high end badger brushes, but maintains the stiff spine for good scrubbing.<br />3) My Semogue brush hasn't shed any hair since the first day I used it. There was maybe 2-3hairs lost in the first day when I was washing it, but haven't shed since.<br />4) Low cost. It only costs an extra $5-8. Some of the best boar brushes cost $40-50 (vs $100-200 for silvertip badger brushes).<br /><br />I wish I read the B&B forums earlier to learn that a cheap boar is substantially better than a cheap badger. Would have saved me $15...

One thing I have learned about shaving brushes is you must dry them upside down on a stand or at the very least on it's side. Otherwise the brush well prematurely fall apart. I am pleased with this purchase. The bang for your buck is amazing.

However it has many of the same ingredients as expensive shaving soaps. I get a good lather from the brush. I made a stand from some heavy #10 wire and hang it to dry with the bristles down.
  208. I didn't expect much for such a low price but was surprised by how quickly this brush fell apart.<br /><br />After about 1 month of use the bristles broke apart from the wood base. I superglued the tuft back in but it only lasted another week or so.<br /><br />I use Col Conk's which requires a bit more vigorous whipping but I also use Proraso tube soap as well which doesn't.<br /><br />I will definitely be looking for a better product and different brand!

As a first brush it is a great starter. I have used it about a dozen times and with time it has been getting softer. Which is what you will read on any review about a badger hair brush.<br /><br />I have had no warping. Honestly l think who that happenhappens to are the people that don't store it properly. When buying something that could be of less quality, not saying this is, extra care needs to taking. I try to dry it out as good as possible and hang it bristles down. It is wood and if wood soaks it will warp. I guess common sense.and can leat to most of the issues I read on here.<br /><br />So for the money, care and common sense I would recommend this brush as a beginner. Which is what I am.

  262. New to the DE shaving scene - I have used my brush for about 2 weeks now and a couple hairs have fallen out. No biggie. No hairs would have been a 5 star blessing. It is like a paint brush for me and with the shave cream, i paint it on the spots ready for the razor. I really like setting it down on the flat base, hairs up/still with later, in case i need to touch up a spot i missed. Never scrape a spot with no shaving cream, that is bad form. One thing i do like about the brush, is doing a circular scrubbing motion that ensures i have worked the shaving cream into my whiskers - in doing that, there is a slight prickly feeling i really like. No pain of course, it is just that signal you are doing things right. Plus, let's face it, it looks kinda cool as opposed to slapping that stuff from a can on your mug. I wash mine out, dab it on the towel to take out the excess water, smooth the hairs out to keep the original shape and hang it back in the rack, not rack - that was unjust, the 'double edged razor and brush cradle' (it is shiny and chrome and i am a guy, so i dig it) to let it dry naturally. It is very well built and with care, yes, it is a tool gentleman and they should never be abused, it will last a long time.

The lather was much finer and if you did things right you could get a lather that was closer to those hot shave machines they use at barber shops. Shaving has been better since I used this brush, It's unexpectedly tingly/prickly when lathering your face but this is more an observation than an annoyance and for the price this is a must have for anyone looking to try out using a shaving brush with either a soap puck or the old fashion tubes of shaving lather.<br /><br />Retains water well be sure to drain some before starting a lather

  304. This brush is a good value, but there are better quality knots out there for slightly more cash. &#34;Pure&#34; is the lowest grade of badger hair, &#34;best&#34; is higher, and &#34;silver-tip&#34; is higher still. A decent &#34;best&#34; brush feels soooo much better on the face.   330. Like double-edge razors, badger brushes have a finite life. Still, you expect the finer - and more expensive - brushes to last longer. The higher the quality, the longer you should expect them to last, in addition to being made of generally finer stuff. Still, over thirty bucks is a lot to pay for something you put soap on and expect to wear out eventually. But do you want to risk spending less than half that and wonder whether it will only last half as long and be of inferior quality? In this case, I would recommend that you do.<br /><br />Enter the Escali badger shaving brush. First of all, I can attest that this brush shows quality where it counts, eliminating the question of whether a less expensive brush would fall apart at the first sight of water. This brush has held up well after many months of use, refusing to lose bristles, lose shape, or otherwise fail. The quality of bristles appears to be the same as brushes that go for more than twice the price. (Are there different grades of badger fur, I wonder?) This brush has held its shape and firmness, stimulating to the skin without being harsh or prickly.<br /><br />The handle is made of wood and, while finished with lacquer (or varnish), care must be taken to properly dry the brush so the handle does not get soaked, dried out, and cracked; stone or plastic handles are generally preferable in this regard, but the Escali brush has held up well. Indeed, by the time this one wears out, I would feel that the full value of the product - and beyond - had been realized. I'm not sure if I could say the same for a brush I paid over twice as much more for.<br /><br />But how does it work? It works great. The bristles are stiff enough to create a luxurious lather on your face (Proraso and Taylor of Old Bond Street in this case) while being soft enough to stimulate your skin and raise your beard without being harsh. In a word, every bit as good as the more expensive brushes that I've bought and tried.<br /><br />I mentioned that this brush has quality where it counts, and which speaks to value. While this is true, the finish of the brush - namely in the imprinted name, the wood handle, and the lacquer finish - expose the budget side of this brush. If appearance is what matters here, then this one gets lower marks. Close inspection of the handle and its finish reveal that this is not where the attention was paid.<br /><br />So, is this brush for you? If you care that your brush looks as good as it acts and have the dough to pay for it, then you may want to go with a higher end brush. If you are like me and appreciate a great value for a badger bristle shaving brush that feels as good, works as well, and lasts as long as its more expensive cousins, then this may be the brush for you. I can afford the pricier models, but I get this one and bank the savings in my little girl's college fund and feel good about the fact that I've gotten a much bigger bang for my buck. Recommended!rush has quality where it counts, and which speaks to value. While this is true, the finish of the brush - namely in the imprinted name, the wood handle, and the lacquer finish - expose the budget side of this brush. If appearance is what matters here, then this one gets lower marks. Close inspection of the handle and its finish reveal that this is not where the attention was paid. So, is this brush for you? If you care that your brush looks as good as it acts and have the dough to pay for it, then you may want to go with a higher end brush. If you are like me and appreciate a great value for a badger bristle shaving brush that feels as good, works as well, and lasts as long as its more expensive cousins, then this may be the brush for you. I can afford the pricier models, but I get this one and bank the savings in my little girl's college fund and feel good about the fact that I've gotten a much bigger bang for my buck. Recommended!
  331. Great Brush, just a few bristles falling of from time to time during lather process. All in all great performer.

  350. I have been using this Escali brush for about a month now. It has taken shaving from a mindless, daily to-do item and turned it into something I really look forward to!<br />I use a large coffee cup and fill it with hot water and soak the brush while I'm in the shower. It absorbs a ton of water. When I'm done in the shower I work up a lather with the brush. It only takes a very short time to create enough to do a three-pass shave with a DE razor. The lather is great! This brush really aerates the cream and makes a full and rich lather that lubricates and protects my sensitive face and neck. An added benefit is that the shaving cream has a warmth to it when I apply it.<br />I also love the feeling of brushing the cream on my face with the Escali. It's not just a paintbrush. I love the way it swirls around my whiskers and exfoliates my skin. It sets up the shave really well.<br />I've read online that some brushes have a foul odor due to the badger hair. I didn't experience that. \\"Badgers? We don't need no stinking badgers.\\" It had a slightly musky scent, but after two shaves its gone. I did notice that it lost a couple of hairs in the first week. I'm not sure but assume that's normal for any brush. I haven't lost any in the last few weeks, however. I'm not exactly gentle with this thing, but I know how to take care of tools.<br />There are lots of brushes on the market and I'll probably get more of them. But I'll never regret buying this Escali pure badger shaving brush!

  353. Hi, first time owner of a badger brush here. I was expecting to be able to lather up for a shave as soon as I got it, but as soon as the brush touched hot water an over powering odor was released. I'm not sure how to describe it, it was a little bit like wet dog, but more caustic. To be honest, it smelled a little bit of skunk. I'm giving the manufacturer the benefit of the doubt, this is probably just what dead badger smells like (they are related to skunks after all). Unfortunately, the smell overpowers the sandelwood scent of my shaving cream and was unusable for me (maybe it'd be fine for a man's man like Wolverine or Bear Grylls). I looked online and found that an initial odor was to be expected from new brushes and that with use and washing (w/ borax, vinegar, baking soda, shampoo, etc), the smell would go away. I've washed mine with shampoo and baking soda 3 times now and the smell has not abated. I will update this review in a week or two. If the smell persists then, I will downgrade my rating to 1 star. If the smell goes away, I will upgrade the rating to 4. *EDIT* The smell still persists, but it nolonger carries into the cream or outside the restroom. It's usable, but I bought from Escali expecting a little better from the brand. I suggest buying a cheaper product that is rated decently, because that's what this brush is: decent. I'm sticking to 3 stars.
  354. To be fair, the brush is actually very good. Badger is better than Boar and these bristles don't \\"shed\\" as other brushes I've had. The only cons I had was a odd smell when the brush was wet the first couple weeks. I talked to a friend and he said that all badger brushes have that odor at first but it goes away.   414. Remembering my grandfather's shaving practices, I wanted to abandon modern commercial foaming shaving creams/gels and use a brush like a \\"real man!\\" At first I purchased the local drugstore's only shaving brush. Brush hairs would sometimes come off on my face, and then it started coming apart in chunks after only a few months of use. After looking online and deciding against high-dollar brushes (since I didn't know if I would stick to this method or not), I found this Escali Pure Badger shaving brush at a great price on Amazon.<br /><br />Initially, the brush smelled horribly of what seemed to be formaldehyde (really guys - can you lay off the toxic formaldehyde?!) So I washed it thoroughly and left it to air out for probably two weeks.<br /><br />It was smaller than I expected. I anticipated a big, bushy brush. But as I found out, you don't NEED a big bushy brush! It takes me all of about 45 seconds to lather up using this brush.<br /><br />After nearly a year (11 months) of constant use, I have probably lost 5 hairs (which is nothing). It works consistently and shows no signs of wear at all. You have to care for it, of course, by rinsing it off when you're done and NEVER leave it standing brush-side up to dry (always leave it on its side).<br /><br />For me, this product was a \\"gamble\\" when I purchased it -- I didn't know what to expect or how long it would last. I would purchase another one as a backup, but my first one shows no signs of giving up any time soon. I would definitely buy this product again and I would buy it for friends.

  419. Yes, it's a little prickly when you first start to use it. But like any natural hair brush, it takes a little while to &#34;break in&#34;. The best way to get that process started is to use a little hand soap on the brush before you even use it the first time. Build up a good lather. It will clean off the bristles. This helps minimize any &#34;animal&#34; smell and starts to soften / condition the brush.<br /><br />Once you do that, the brush will become softer fairly quickly. And let's face it stuffing our face into a brush takes some adjusting (if you've never done it before).<br /><br />Remember also that you should dry your brush with the bristles hanging down. If you don't do this, you will have two bad things happen. First the base of the bristles will tend to collect moisture over time. This slowly, but steadily undoes the glue that holds the brush together. Second, it promotes mold and mildew.<br /><br />Take care of a well made brush and it should last a long, long time.<br /><br />And let's face it, at this price it's a very pleasant surprise to find such good quality. I expected that I would have to replace this brush. Having used it a few days, I am pretty certain it will last a long, long time.
  420. Quality brush. Highly recommended!

The reviews are excellent for a reason. I couldn't be happier with this product. The brush has a nice wood finish and feels good in your hand. The bristles are perfect, soft but not too soft, just stiff enough for a good lather and they don't come out. If you're serious about shaving and searching for a shaving brush look no further. P*!#ies use shaving cream and 5 blade razors that are a total garbage pit, give a crap shave and get clogged easily. Don't be a p*!#y and shave like a man. Don't be a p*!#y and buy this brush. :)

  452. This was the first shaving brush that I have used. Previously, I used my fingers to work in a lather from gel onto my face prior to shaving. I've used this for the past 3 months, and I must say -- it works really well! The badger brush massages my face as I apply lather (the hairs are fairly soft), which makes shaving no longer a chore for me. I've noticed that I can apply a much smoother and thicker lather onto my face prior to shaving than before when I was using my hands. I'm also able to be more precise with where I apply lather without making a mess. Here are few things that I've noticed: 1) The first time I used this, there were a few stray hairs from the brush that fell off onto my face. After using it about 3-4 times, no more hairs fell out from the brush. 2) The way I clean it consists of rinsing it with warm water (it holds quite a lot of water and lather!) and squeezing the water out by using my index finger and thumb to form a sphincter around the base of the hairs. I do this a few times, and after squeezing it dry, I hang it by the handle upside down so the hairs are facing down. I haven't had any issue with it getting any funny smells, though I have read that some people have used a mild borax solution to wash it safely. 3) I hang this brush (hair end down) using this: [[ASIN:B001XURHNY Colonel Conk Evernice Model 775 Chrome Safety Razor Stand]]. It's important to note that the wood is not perfectly circular. Rather, the base is like an ellipse. Because it's a tight fit into the razor stand, I find that I have to rotate the brush so the skinnier diameter of the wood handle slides in. My only regret is that I didn't buy this sooner! I love this thing! Hope this helps...
  453. I've recently gotten into shaving with soap, that a friend makes,<br />over shaving with shaving cream, and had a decent brush from a big dept store chain.<br />This brush was my first try at a real badger shaving brush, and well worth the extra pop.<br />I found it lathered well, and a much softer application.

This one started out stiff and has remained stiff.<br /><br />My only beef is that it tends to lose hairs more than most. Maybe this will decrease with age. I tried the boar bristle and it was OK and then I ordered the Escali 100% Pure Badger Shaving Brush and believe me there is no comparison in the softness and shape of this brush.   497. Much like another reviewer, I'm new to DE shaving and using a brush to apply cream/soap. Even after I made the DE switch, I stood by, and do so at least twice/week, my Barbasol (yellow) canned cream. I love that stuff, but I've found that applying soap/cream with a brush makes a world of difference. I have nothing to compare this brush to, but it works exactly as advertised. Upon first use, I dipped a dampened brush into my [[ASIN:B0015UWUFM Soap]] (excess water shaken from it, of course), swirled it around a few times and commenced lathering up my face. Within seconds, a nice foamy lather ensued and I was able to shave more comfortably, and closely than I have ever shaved... and there was still enough lather/foam on the brush to shave 2 more passes. It creates a full lather and sheds minimally (I think I've only seen 3 bristles fall off so far). The handle has a decent heft to it and holds nicely in my hand, but again, I have nothing to compare it to. I'm sure there are other brushes on the market with better handling, better bristles, better lathering, etc, but for $14, I'm not sure you can find such a quality, real-hair, wood-handle brush to break in to DE shaving. Of course, very fast shipping as fulfillment is by Amazon. If you're looking for an inexpensive, good quality badger-hair brush, this is an excellent pick, especially if this is your first trek into brush application.

This Escali brush gets bonus points for having an Italian name and a classic wooden handle! This was top-notch quality for a bargain price. For 15 dollars this is honestly a great buy if you want to get an idea of what a badger brush feels/lathers like, but if you are buying this solely because you want a cheap brush, then just go get a cheap boar/synthetic brush in one of those drug store shave kits. It will perform about as well at the end of the day. If you just want to know if this is worth the 15 bucks you are going to pay for it: Yes. Absolutely.<br /><br />This is a good brush for beginners, but will leave you wanting more if you're hoping for actual quality. Beyond that, your best bet will be to look around for a low end Simpson brush. It will set you back about 60-70 dollars, but you will be paying 5 times the price for 20 times the quality.

  555. Just like many who purchased this one, I was just getting into the Wet-shave thing. I wanted a badger-hair brush that would last, but I didn't want to spend a lot on one right out the shoot. This one seemed to fit the bill. I've been using it for a few months now, it holds water very well and works great to build up a rich, luxurious lather (I use Geo. F. Trumper's soap). The bristles aren't as soft as some of the more expensive brushes, but not such that it's uncomfortable. If you're just starting and don't want to drop 50 bucks on a brush, try this one. It's a perfect entry-level brush, or just to have a back-up/travel brush that's good quality but you'd be OK with losing. ADDED: 6 months of use, I have to take a star away from this. The brush part fell apart from the handle. I was able to glue it back together, but even considering that the brush doesn't have the same quality it did after first purchasing it. I would still absolutely recommend this brush as an entry-level brush to those who are getting into DE shaving and just want to get their feet wet. This brush served those needs well, it wasn't so expensive that I would have been mad at myself for buying it if I decided DE shaving wasn't for me. Just know that if you buy this, and you really fall in love with DE shaving, you will almost certainly be purchasing a brush of higher quality construction and material within a year.
  556. As a shaving newbie, I honestly can't say how this brush matches up to others in the same price range. But I've used it now for about a month, and it picks up lather well, hasn't started to completely fall apart, and seems to have fairly good fit and finish.<br /><br />However, there are some issues. 1) It still hasn't stopped shedding hairs. I suppose this is a minor nuisance, but every time I lather, I get at least 3-4 hairs in the soap, and at least one of those picks up and gets on my face. This hasn't really caused major issues, but I really hope it stops shedding soon.<br />2) The other issue is that the brush is still quite coarse. I wasn't expecting super soft bristles, but I was thinking the hairs would soften after use and conditioning. It has yet to happen. But who knows, this may come about with further use.<br /><br />As a side note, there is a subtle animal scent to the brush. It's musky, about what you'd expect a badger to smell like. It's not terribly unpleasant, but for those sensitive to scent it may be bothersome. As far as I can tell the smell doesn't transfer onto anything, it's locked into the bristles themselves, but it is something to note. But for this matter, someone that sensitive to scents may be better off finding a synthetic brush.<br /><br />Overall, I think this brush has done a fairly good job and for the price it seems like it will last for quite a while. If it catastrophically fails, I'll update the review, but I don't foresee that happening.

  572. Finally fed up with the mounting expense of buying the latest and not-necessarily “greatest” innovations in the disposable razor market, I discovered there are a few essential items I needed to buy before I could completely transform to using a safety razor. A decent quality shaving brush was one such item. The ESCALI 100% PURE BADGER SHAVING BRUSH proved to be the answer.<br /><br />WHAT IT IS:<br /><br />- Affordably priced, badger-hair shaving brush with a wood handle.<br /><br />WHY PURCHASE A SHAVING BRUSH?<br /><br />- After decades of spraying gel into my hand to apply shaving cream, I never really gave shaving brushes a thought. Using a shaving brush always seemed as nothing more than adding an expensive degree of sophistication to a rather mundane task (like using silk instead of toilet paper). Once I started using a shaving brush, I immediately saw the benefits.<br /><br />- First of all, applying shaving cream with a brush simply feels better than using your hand as it messages the cream into your skin and helps generate a decent lather with little effort. Brushing a warm layer of shaving soap on your skin adds a level of enjoyment to the shaving ritual.<br /><br />- A decent shaving brush can retain enough soap and liquid to allow several applications without having to “reload”. Using a brush, you can get more use from a smaller amount of soap/cream.<br /><br />WHY BADGER AND WHY ESCALI?<br /><br />- I’ve read several articles and reviews regarding the positives/negatives of badger hair/boar hair and synthetic haired brushes. The consensus indicates badger hair is best mainly because of its absorption quality, it retains water which is essential to the lubrication process. While boar hair is a worthy substitute, it doesn’t retain water as well and has a reputation of retaining a noticeable odor. Synthetic hair brushes don’t retain moisture as well.<br /><br />- I’ve been using the ESCALI BADGER BRUSH for over 5 months and I am quite pleased with its performance. It is has a soft texture and retains enough moisture to generate a decent lather. Yes, the brush does shed (all animal hair brushes will), but we’re talking a hair here-and-there, not in clumps. Badger hair brushes are not cheap, but the price of the ESCALI takes the financial pain out of owning a good quality shaving brush.ite pleased with its performance. It is has a soft texture and retains enough moisture to generate a decent lather. Yes, the brush does shed (all animal hair brushes will), but we’re talking a hair here-and-there, not in clumps. Badger hair brushes are not cheap, but the price of the ESCALI takes the financial pain out of owning a good quality shaving brush.
  573. It does what it's supposed to do, but it sheds between 5-10 hairs every time I use it. This leaves hairs from the brush in my shaving soap container, and when I try to wash it out, it also washes away some of the soap. Meaning the soap doesn't last as long either. If I had to buy again, I wouldn't. I bought a synthetic shaving brush after this one, and that fared much better. It only shed 1 hair but that's a much better count than this one has going for it.
  574. I've used it now for nearly a year and only a few bristles have come off. Still in the original shape.
  575. Great brush for the price. I've been using this brush for quite a few months now, about two times a week and it has held up very well.<br /><br />After each shave I am sure to shake as much water out as possible, reshape the bristles then set out on counter to dry.<br /><br />The bristles are very soft and very few if any ever fall out.
  576. When I use this, I feel like what I would imagine Gaston from Beauty and The Beast feels like when he shaves.<br /><br />This is a quality shaving brush at a great price, buy it and start feeling like a man today.
  577. Cant be beat for the money. Soft on my face and really lathers the shave cream up.
  578. Nice inexpensive Badger hair shaving brush!
  579. This brush has a nice wooden handle and fairly stiff hair. It comes in a plastic hanging display box keeping the brush safe during shipping. Like all brushes, it sheds a little. Having only read reviews and not tried other brushes from Amazon, I would say that this brush sheds less then others. My only real complaint with this brush is that it smells horrible coming out of the plastic packaging. The smell is like that of cleaning solution for the hair mixed with glue (knot) and lacquer (handle). I have given it two good washings and used with shaving soap and the smell is still there. I think after another couple washings and continued use, the smell will be gone. Otherwise, this brush does what it's supposed to.
  580. This is very good value. I have a best badger brush that is more than twice the price, and this one is softer.

  582. Bristles keep falling out. Very annoying. I'm hoping it'll stop.
  583. I am just starting out in double edge razor shaving and was looking for a well rated and inexpensive Badger brush. I chose the Escali because it had good reviews, was well priced,and I liked the wooden handle. Admittedly, the first time that I used it, about a dozen or so loose bristles came off - no big deal. There are probably some softer Badger bristle brushes out there, but the idea of spending $60 for a shaving brush seems a bit much to me. This one works well and is well made. Give it a try!

According to Shave Busta and The Traditional Shaving Evangelist that is a $200 calibre brush. I love it myself the feeling of luxury is amazing on it.   604. This brush is absolutely fantastic. I was looking for an inexpensive but high quality badger brush to start getting into wetshaving, and this does the job.<br />A couple of tips for new guys to wetshaving:<br />-Make sure to hang it bristles down or lay it on its side, not handle down with bristles up.<br />-You will lose hairs the first couple days/weeks from the brush, that's ok. Don't freak out, just keep using it.<br />-When cleaning the brush after shaving (taking the cream out of the brush) be careful when squeezing, because you can lose some hairs from the brush that way if you're not careful.<br /><br />When starting out, I recommend getting a cream, not a soap and here's why. Creams are easier to lather, they moisturize better, and just overall create a better shaving experience. After wetshaving for a while, i've moved onto Colonel Conk's shave soaps and they are excellent products that I love, but the creams of Taylor of Old Bond Street, Proraso, and Cella are 5x better than Col Conk. I recommend starting out with a Taylor of Old Bond Street (I have Lavender which i really like, but i'd say go for Avocado or another scent that you find pleasurable) because it really just is a piece of cake to lather up and make an amazing shave. The con is that one jar of TOBS is around 15 bucks and I got my Col Conk variety pack (4 different soaps) for 18 bucks.
  605. A good solid shaving brush. Hairs occasionally fall out, but that's usually my fault. It does a good job building lather and is smooth to the touch.
  606. Excellent lathering, with a comfortable shave. A great combination of performance and price. Good enough for everyday shaving, and priced so that you can toss it into your shave bag for travel. A great value that compares well against the premium badger brushes. I'm quite pleased with mine.

  620. This is my first experience with shaving with a brush and I absolutely love it. Although I've only been using this brush for a week, it has made my shaving experience a pleasure, so much so that I can't help but lather and shave at least 3 times in one sitting. Gone are the days of using the local department store shaving creams, using my hand to apply it.. This brush does a great job of creating lather, exfoliating the skin, and eliminating those pesky razor rash cuts.<br /><br />The only negative I can see, and it's a minor thing, is that after a week's use, it still sheds a few bristles in my cream, which I was hoping would have gone away by now ... maybe after some more use, it will.<br /><br />Tip: this is not my original idea, I give credit to someone else on here for this, but it works amazingly well. Drill a small flat head screw into the center of the end of the brush and use a small magnet to hang it upside down to dry under your medicine cabinet door. Like I said, it works amazingly well allowing your brush to dry, is cost effective, and saves on counter space.

  627. I started wet shaving about six months ago. I began with one of the shaving soap kits that came with the soap bowl and boar hair brush. The brush fell apart after several months. I had decided to stick with wet shaving, so I began looking on Amazon for a better replacement brush. The Escali brush was by far the least expensive badger hair brush I found. I ordered it figuring if I didn't like it, I'd toss it and just upgrade. Well, I love it. It holds water much better than the boar hair brush did. It is very soft and comfortable. It whips up a mean lather and I've had almost no hair loss from the brush. I'm very satisfied and would recommend this brush to anyone looking for a good shaving brush and not trying to spend money just to spend it.<br /><br />Update: 09/28/2013<br />Three years later, and I'm still using it. Minimal bristle loss. Make sure you get a brush holder so that it hang drys with the bristles facing downward. Highly recommended.

There is an old saying that goes &#34;You get what you pay for&#34;, well I purchased this product because I wasn't sure if wet shaving would be for me. While I love wet shaving I have met cats with medical problems that don't lose their hair like this brush. It reached the point that I would pull twenty or more bristles off this brush before each shave and I still had so many come out in the lather on my face that is clogging up my razor. I have since switched to a higher end brush from Slate and I love it. Do yourself a favor and spend the extra money to get a high quality brush. Your face is worth it.

I like the fact that it's a wooden handle instead of the usual resin one that you'd get at this price, and the loft is at a nice height.

  692. I purchased an older shaving brush at an estate sale, which got me started using a shaving brush. It always had bristles coming out and the plastic handle began to disintegrate. I started researching for a new, inexpensive brush and selected The Escali 100% Pure Badger Shaving Brush. I have been very pleased. Amazingly, I have had only one bristle come out. The brush holds its shape, has a crisp feel on the face, and rinses clean while maintaining its shape. I cannot imagine this brush ever wearing out. It is an excellent value and I highly recommend it to anyone interested in using a shaving brush. Everyday I smile because I am not throwing another empty shaving cream can in the dump.
  693. I personally have never liked shaving. I find it a pain in the backside and I often have shaving rash. After trying many different products I have settled on the Escali badger hair shave brush and Colonel Conks Bay rum soap. What a revelation both these products are superb and I am getting the closest shave I have ever had in 20 years.I even look forward to shaving as it is know more of a ritual indulgence than a chore.Would absolutely reccomend to everyone.
  694. You wake up in the morning, still in your suit from the night before and a cocktail in your hand. You take your other hand across your chiseled face to be met with a rough 5 o'clock shadow. You look over at the beautiful woman in your bed and decide you must remove it before she wakes up. You head to your pearl bathroom, open the mirror and grab your Escali Pure Badger Shaving Brush. You gulp down the drink still in your hand and begin to lather a thick foam with your brush. The soothing warm water and soft brush makes you completely forget you're getting to old to party like that. After a relaxing shave you return to the beautiful woman in your bed. She can't resist you. She caresses your face like it's her first time all over again. You Sir, now have lady hands all over your face. And that my friend, is something you want.<br /><br />I have to say that this has completely changed the way I shave. No longer are the days of razor burn. For a budget brush, this product performs very well. Nice and soft with no smell that you sometimes read about with cheap brushes. I will be upgrading to a silver tip brush soon as I bought this one to test shaving in this manner.
  695. I'm normally a boar brush man because I prefer hard soaps, but I thought I'd give this little pure badger a try since the price was so low. What a pleasant surprise. It has none of the floppiness of the higher grade badger brushes (best, super, and silver tip), but it is still soft and thick enough to hold water better than the average boar. Being clipped to shape there is a slight prickly character to the brush at first, but it fades quickly with use. Likewise the shedding hairs and badger butt aroma go away after a few shaves. So, if you want a brush that will have a softer overall character than a boar but still has enough backbone for hard soaps, you really can't go wrong paying $15 or so for one of these little Escalis. Try one and you'll be lathered like a rabid dog in no time.
  696. Inexpensive, shipped quickly. Quite happy with it.
  697. Great brush. I would recommend to others
  698. A little sandpaper to remove the varnish eliminates the slipperiness in soapy water – making it a much better product.
  699. I know there are lots of wonderful reviews of this brush, but I guess I got a lemon. Unfortunately it has been a while since I bought this brush, and finally when I opened it to use it since my previous one had started to shed, I notice a big clump almost in the middle of the brush - it almost seems like there was a big ole' wart on the badger's back and it got transferred to the brush past a lax quality control person (see picture). Not sure that I can do anything about it other than throw it away and go for a different brand. Edited 8/16/2015 to reflect changed opinion: After I wrote the above review, folks from Epica products reached out to me. This in itself was nice, knowing that there is a manufacturer/distributor that cares enough. I was immediately sent a replacement brush, even though my review was for a purchase from several months ago. I have since started using the new brush. It took a couple of weeks of &#34;breaking in&#34; it seems. There was a smell to it initially, and the brush would not generate or hold enough lather. However, that all seems to have gone away now - the brush has started to work well and holds a good bit of lather. In fact, it is now upon me to educate myself further now that I have a functioning brush. I feel that I am washing away a lot of the lather that is still in the brush that would have worked better on my face. In any case, that does not seem to be the fault of the brush itself, and it is working as I expect it to. I am changing my review to 5 stars from 4 (if there was an option for a 4.5, I would have said 4.5 to account for the initial 'breaking in&#34; period).

  781. My husband took a step back a few years ago by switching to safety razors and shave soap - cheaper, less waste, all the good reasons.   782. I started with a boars head brush from the [[ASIN:B001A3HPT0 Van Der Hagen Premium Shave Set (Soap, Bowl, Brush)]]. I highly recommend the kit for starters into the realm, but I'll leave it at that, it's for starters.<br /><br />I was unhappy with the lather my boar hair brush created, and I didn't want to drop 60 bucks on the silvertip badger hair brushes. When I found this I decided to give it a try.<br /><br />The hair is much finer than the boar brush, and does a much better job holding water. It also creates and amazing lather. The end is a little prickely compared to the boar brush, but if you apply with a brushing stroke instead of a dab -which you should do anyway- it works out great.<br /><br />Now for the cons. As other reviewers have said, you should expect some hair to fall out, especially during the first few uses. But if you accept that and keep using it eventually the hair will stop falling out, think of it as a break in period. After that expect one or 2 to fall out every once and a while.<br /><br />And yes you need to store it handle up, so I recommend some sort of stand.<br /><br />Overall I give it 4 stars because off all the hair that came out at first, and because it is a little prickely. Is it better than a $60 Parker? Definitely not, but it is worlds better than a boar hair brush.
  783. I am loving my new method of shaving I \\"discovered\\" recently. I am not sure why it ever fell out of fashion in the first place. If I had one very minor thing I didn't like, it would be the smell of the brush. I realize it is Badger hair, but the first time I used it, WOW! lol The smell has since gone away. I actually used some dog shampoo to wash it out. On my next Badger hair brush, I'll do that first!
  784. This is my first badger brush and I'd definately say it is softer right out of the box than ANY boar hair bursh i've used. I was a little suprised though at how prickly the tips were when I first used it despite its overall softness but it is getting sofer each time i use it and breaking it in helps alot! As soon as you get it wash it in soap and hot water then let it soak for an hour or so in sudsy water then shake it out, lather it up and leave it like that overnight - in the moning wash it out, lather up and WOW Softer by at least 50%! As to hair loss I think its lost like 5 hairs and Im not gentle in the lather process (I don't use gels or creams - just soap cakes like my grandpap used). Hang the brush upside down to dry - it cuts down shedding and extends the life of the brush. This brush holds at least an ounce of water but a hard shake will remove that and a good squeeze will remoe even more. Unless the tips of more expensive brushes are WAY softer and last for years and years then I see no reason to spend $30 - $100 (or more) unless this brush falls apart in a short period of time. Other posters have mentioned an odd smell with this brush when new but I didnt notice anything too offensive when its wet - boar brushes on the other hand - oh yeah!
  785. First time using a shaving brush was this Escali. Does the trick but it does leave a couple bristles stuck to my face every shave and stings a bit when you have to dab with it. It's not a particularly good looking brush but I suspect it is adequate for what you pay for. Good for a first time shave kit. 2015 Update: After about 8 months of use the coating/veneer on the wood began to delaminate which leave a flakey/sort of sharp material on the bottom of the brush. Also, since first use the brush was releasing hairs as a spread the shaving cream on my face. I thought that would stop but even a couple years later it still does it occasionally. I will admit this could be user error because I do not have a brush stand which may help moisture dissipate. I just run the bristles against a dry cloth and leave in on it side on the counter.
  786. The Escali Pure Badger Shaving Brush is the real deal. Nice and soft while holding lather for a real close shave. Was shipped as expected and on time.
  787. Great brush, I am new to safety razor shaving, I got fed up with paying the high cost of the Gillette blades, so I got a razor and this brush and some shaving soap, first couple of shaves were a bit of a learning curve, but after three or so I am now proficient, I should have switched years ago I would have saved so much money.<br /><br />This brush is a quality product, a pleasure to use, and very reasonably priced. I would highly recommend it.
  788. I bought this a month or two ago and use it 1 to 2 times a week. Had some shedding at the beginning (expected) and smelled a bit when wet (also expected). The smell has mostly dissipated, I haven't noticed it shedding lately, and the bristles are nice and fluffed out so I guess it is in good condition. It lathers my shave soap and applies it as well as I had hoped.<br /><br />I maintain it by rinsing thoroughly after use, holding the bristles right below the wood when I shake it out, and storing it bristle-side down from a hanger that I bent for the purpose. I liked my shave soap before, but this little brush is helping me to love my soap.
  789. This brush works. I've been using it for several weeks and it does the job. It lathers up nice and works the facial hair into place. The first couple of uses caused some of the bristles to come out but this stopped after about five uses. This would be more of a problem except that this brush was significantly less expensive that others that I found. For that reason I give it 3 stars, its good but not perfect.

  801. I bought this for my husband and he LOVES it! This is a great quality brush!
  802. This brush almost deserves a solid 5 stars; I'd give it 4.5 if I could. It works VERY well at lathering up shaving cream (my choice is [[ASIN:B000RI8BZQ Proraso Shaving Cream 5.2 oz (147 g)]]), holds a good amount of water, and is easy to rinse. The only reason I'd deduct a half a star is that it was a little prickly against my skin during the first few uses. This has gotten better with use; now I only notice this once in a while. I don't know if I'm getting used to it or if the bristles are softening up, but either way, it's no longer a complaint. Just wanted to let you know it's not whispery-soft right out of the box. A few things in response to previous reviews: Some other reviews say it smells bad - mine isn't bad at all. If I shove my nose right against it immediately after wetting it, I can smell a hint of animal scent, but I've never smelled anything unusual during normal use. My brush lost a total of about 3 bristles over the first few weeks of use. And finally, a hint if you don't want to take up counterspace with a special brush drying rack. There's hardly any space around my sink, so I didn't want a dedicated brush rack, but I also wanted to prolong this brush's life by drying it properly (bristles-down). To solve these problems, I sunk a small screw into the handle of the brush (opposite the bristles), and stuck a small rare-earth magnet onto the bottom of my mirror/med cabinet. Now my brush \\"floats\\" just under the cabinet - easy access, proper drying, and no lost counterspace. :)
  803. Ordered this as a gift for my husband. He used it a half-dozen times and it completely fell apart. The entire brush portion fell out, and hairs were everywhere. I had also bought a stand for him to hang it on, so that the wood and bristles wouldn't rot. So much for that.

Not sure how long these brushes are supposed to last, but it is meeting my expectations. Not sure how much of the shaving soap experience is affected by a decent brush, but so far I really like it with the soap. Spreads over the face quicker (and head, I shave my head) than squirting gels/foams into hands and spreading. Just paint on with the brush, then good to go. Have seen some bristles come out into the soap, but this was really just when I started using the brush. After breaking it in, it seems to not shed bristles anymore.

  808. This is a good value for the money. Have used it for a few weeks now with minimal loss of hair. I can get my shaving cream to lather quite nicely. One tip - soak the brush in warm water for a minute to get it nicely soft and ready for the shave cream. Then when done, wash it by running under hot water and gently squeezing the later out. Repeat a few times. Dry on its side or upside-down. Your brush will last longer.
  809. Honestly have no other brush to compare this to. However I've been using this for a few months and I'm happy.   810. The Escali 100% Badger Brush: you get what you pay for. This brush runs for about $12.95 and is a horrible choice for a starter brush. It works ok for bowl lathering but not for face lathering. It continues to lose hair, it will probably return it. Also, I find this brush to be scratchy, that is for a badger brush. Now, I understand that for a Badger Brush you would need to spend around $35 and above to get a decent one (everything I have found below that price point is just \\"entry level\\") If you really want an excellent Badger Brush, then, get ready to spend way more . For the same amount of money ($12.95) you can get a great boar brush (like the Omega Professional made in Italy or the Semogue Boar Bristle Shaving Brush made in Portugal. The Semogue is a better brush than the Omega) Either one of these brushes is superior than the Escali. I just purchased the Semogue Owners Club- Boar shaving brush for $37 and it is better than most $70 dollar Badger brush on the market.
  811. I bought this along with a container of sandalwood shaving cream, a silver shaving bowl, an Edwin Jagger safety razor, and a stand to hold the razor and brush (just to give you an idea of how I'm using this item).<br /><br />First off, the brush was delivered on time, looks as pictured, and is perfectly capable of doing its job. It also fits in the stand I ordered, so that's a plus. The bristles are very soft and apply the shaving cream in a smooth, delicate manner, while also raising the facial hair slightly to make for a closer shave. I don't know if it's as soft as those $60 silver-tipped brushes, but I can't imagine the difference in quality is worth the price. For 13 bucks plus free two-day shipping (with Amazon Prime), this was a great deal. At first I was concerned that the bristles would not return to their original quality after getting wet and left to dry, but this fear was undue. Granted, I've only used it two times, but the brush is still as soft as the day I got it. Just make sure to rinse it thoroughly after every shave and give it some air to breathe when it's not in use.<br /><br />The only negative I can think of is that the bristles have a slight tendency to come out of the brush and stick to the sides of the shaving bowl if I mix the cream too vigorously. However, this may have just been a matter of breaking in the item, as this was only particularly noticeable the first time I used the brush. While I've only shaved with this setup twice, the number of loose badger hairs I noticed on the second time was significantly fewer. So it could have just been that I was getting rid of the loose hairs, and that now I will no longer experience that issue. And even then, it's hardly a problem, and the brush still applies the lather very smoothly.<br /><br />All in all, this is a good item at a reasonable price. Would buy again.

It was super soft and much fuller but also $180, so I will keep this brush. Their was some shedding, two maybe three bristles, but I assume that's normal.   871. I confess that this was a late-night impulse purchase, added because Amazon suggested it would be a good companion to some double-edged blades I purchased (100 box of Blue Personnas -- love them, too!). When the badger brush arrived I wondered how often I would really use it, and the answer is: every day. The first two or three uses it had a bit of an odor, and shed a few hairs, but now it keeps all its hairs and smells great. Foaming up the Escali with some good-smelling shaving soap or shaving cream is one of those small luxuries that make time stand still in a busy day. Technique: I fill a coffee cup with hot water and place the badger hair brush in it while I shower. After, I shake out some, but not all, of the water and put a dab of cream in the bottom of another cup. It takes 30 seconds to foam up enough for a two-pass shave. It took a little bit of practice to learn exactly how much water to leave in the brush, and it turns out I like a little more water than most men. If you have read this far you deserve a small award.
  872. Being new to the safety razor, and first time using shaving cream, it should be noted that I'm still learning the art of application. So the shaving brush works as promised and by most accounts, reviews do say that the brush will shed initially. So, with that in consideration, I have been using this brush for only a short time and it does most certainly shed, to the extent that I had to fish out the hairs out of the shaving cream bowl as it was looking rather uncouth.<br /><br />As I refine my shaving technique, along with the breaking in period of the brush will result in less hair loss from the brush. I may be inclined to score this brush higher once I know it will maintain the remainder of its hair.

  979. This is a great affordable brush. It hold lots of water as it should. I was wary about buying this brush because of some of the bad reviews I read about its quality. I read that the bristles fall out or the handle cracks etc. I think these things happen because the brush isn't properly stored. The brush, like all shaving brushes, must be hung bristle side down so it can dry properly. If left on its side or stood up on its handle, the water just sits on the knot inside the handle and causes the brush to fall apart slowly fall apart. My brush has performed wonderfully with no problems. Im glad I ignored the negative reviews and made the purchase.
  980. flimsy product- better off spending more money on higher quality- the brush completely fell off within a week of using it

  984. I am one of those who discovered late in life that a glycerin-based shave cream in a jar is infinitely better than anything found in an aerosol can. What a shame it took me even longer to discover that shaving brush is the key to getting the most out of the expensive shaving creams, like those from The Art of Shaving. A brush is essential because it allows you to build up a better lather with less product resulting in a closer shave and more efficient use of expensive shaving cream. I used to go through a 5oz tub in a month and a half using just my fingers to apply the cream to my face. Now, the same tub last two and a half to three months using a brush and an empty tub to whisk up the lather.<br /><br />Well, let me tell you, the Escali badger brush brush does the trick and then some! The bristles are pliable and smell-free right from the start and I'm now several months into the use of the brush and it looks like it will last for years. Sure, you can pay five or ten times more for a fancy handle, but in the end, this brush does the job and makes me smile knowing how much money I'm saving!

  997. A nice brush, holds soap well, and doesn't shed.
  998. This brush may be the number one rated brush on Amazon, not sure how that happened, however it is an extremely poor performer. I bought this brush when I was first getting into double edge razors and wet shaving, and did not know any better, and hope this review saves someone else money wasted.<br />This brush is clipped, meaning instead of selecting badger hairs of various lengths, and forming the brush, they are randomly placed and then cut, what this means for the end user experience is a prickly and harsh &#34;badger&#34; brush. The entire purpose of badger brushes is to have a softer brush, with a little bit of backbone to make lather well.<br /> The glue or epoxy used to hold the knot into the handle is also sub par, and the brush sheds hairs continuously, and in copious amounts. After reading other reviews, it looks like my experience was not an outlier.<br /> Save your money, and if you are looking to buy a brush that is on Amazon, get a similarly priced Omega, Semogue, or Vie Long. It won't matter if its badger, boar, horse, synthetic, anything you buy at this price point, from those manufacturers, will be leaps and bounds better than this Escali shaving brush.
  999. I'm a novice at lathering up this way, so I wasn't going to spend too much on a shaving brush. Luckily the #1 Bestselling brush in the store is inexpensive. I have yet to find anything I don't like about this brush
  1000. Yeah this works relatively well if you need something simple. Mine has a slight issue where the there's a hole in the topmost layer right down into the knot, but honestly this doesn't really affect anything and I've gotten many a good lather out of it.
  1001. While this is Badger, it is very rough. I found a lot of whiskers (from the actual animal) that were very rough and coarse. This thing also looses a LOT of hairs, typically 5 or more every shave. I went back to my first Burma Shave brush, I like that much more. Also it has a tendency to knot up in the middle which then you have to pull out the knot and lose more hairs! Gave 2 stars because it is technically badger and advertised as such. Honestly I don't like it and should have given it one star.

  1014. Purchased this for our grandson to use to clean and lubricate his small game rifle. A good friend who served in the U.S. Army during the Vietnam War told me he used such a brush to care for his M16, and I've used these brushes ever since. They do a great job spreading lube oil on firearms.
  1015. This brush met my expectations. It was a bit stiff at the beginning, but as i continue to use it it is becoming softer. The best thing is the great lather that it works up and then works into my beard.
  1016. I have been using the Escali pure badger brush for about a month now and it has been working great. I'll probably end up repurchasing the brush after I use up my current one.
  1017. This is a wonderful shaving brush. I bought one for my husband and it's been great. Then I bought one for my dad, with the stand. The stand means the bathroom gets less dust and the brush dries properly.
  1018. This was only the second shaving brush that I have ever owned. I purchased the first one at a neighborhood drug store. It had a cheap plastic handle/base, and the bristles were too long, too soft, too uneven, and fell out with every use.<br /><br />I purchased the Escali brush based on the reviews that I read, and I am exceedingly happy with the product. The bristles are the perfect length and stiffness. The wood handle gives it a look of simple elegance. It holds the shaving soap better and creates a better lather. A few bristles fell out over the first couple of shaves, but none after that.<br /><br />I didn't need an expensive brush, just something that worked well. This brush is exactly what I wanted.

  1021. I tried camel hair. The bristles began falling out after a few months. So far, the badger produces a better lather than camel without the bristles adding new hair to my beard. It was a bit pokey until I realized that I should spread the lather by using a side-stroke with the brush instead of coming straight on. Once I figure this out, it has been smooth sailing.<br /><br />Don't forget that you should hang the brush upside down from a stand (not included) or lay it on its side to prolong the life of your new furry friend.
  1022. This is my first pure badger hair shaving brush. So far it has performed like expected. It retains enough hot water that I can get a nice warm lather at least two times and a decent lather the third time (in case I missed any spots). I've been soaking this brush in steaming hot water (a few seconds after boiling) and it sits for about 5-10 minutes as I shower, and it has held up so far. I'll update my review if anything changes, but so far this product has been as advertised and pleasant to use.
  1023. A few of the bristles have come off, but that is to be expected; similar to paint brushes. Other than that, a great product that feels great on the skin.

  1031. same exact one that we bought before but the hairs are not as soft and effective at whipping the shaving soap.
  1032. Easily the worst brush I own. The reason I got this brush was because I didn't know any better when I first started. There are a ton of other better brushes out there at the same price and you shouldn't waste your time with this one. Issues with this brush: The knot (amount of hair) is very small The hairs are very floppy and can't stand up well to soaps or face lathering The hairs seemed clipped and thus are very scratchy at the ends Constantly loses hairs I would recommend getting something else like: Omega Shaving Brush #10048 (chrome) or #10049 (black) This is a very large boar brush with a huge knot, 28mm knot. Unclipped and will get softer with time. Omega Shaving Brush #10065 (many colors to choose from) or #10066(faux ivory) Medium size boar brush, 24mm knot. Unclipped hairs that get softer with time. Omega S-Brush S10065 (many colors to choose from) Medium size synthetic brush, 24mm knot. Not made from animal hair and thus very low maintenance. No break in required. Good firm feel but still very soft tips. Vie-Long 12705 Medium size horse hair brush, 23mm knot. Horse hair is fairly soft. No break in required. Semogue 1470 (wood handle) or 1460 (painted wood handle) Small size boar brush, 21mm knot. Nice feel of the wood handle. The hairs are also unclipped and will get softer with time. Notice I didn't recommend any badger brushes? This is because there are virtually no good badger brushes in the $10-$20 price range. Good badger brushes start at around $30. Most good cheap brushes will be bore hair, horse hair, or synthetic.

  1057. I have used a synthetic brush for at least two years and I recently switched over to using this guy. First thing is it is actually animal hair, so it smells like a wet animal when it gets wet. The brush will tangle like a knot if you press the brush against your face like the how to videos on Youtube. I find I have to use a comb on the brush after use to make sure it does not get too tangled. With a light touch, just pressing slightly and loading the brush with foam from the soap dish often you get a decent lather that is not as valuminous as a synthetic brush but has a much denser foam so you do not nicked quite so much with the straight razor.
  1058. New to this type of shaving gear so I don't have a lot to compare it to but this brush seems to be a good value. Yes it sheds a hair every now and then but that not really a big deal. I just pull it out of the bowl. Its plenty soft after a few uses and I enjoy using it. I can't see spending 20-100 for a shave brush that basically does the same thing. I mean it spreads shaving cream. How luxurious does it need to be? I'd rather put the money towards a better quality razor. I've been using it about 6 weeks and I lose a hair every other shave maybe. The finish on the handle is holding up fine with no peeling or anything. All in all I'm very happy with it.

  1084. The bristles on this brush are pretty soft, but I have an older brush from Tweezerman that is, I think, a little bit softer and holds it shape just as well as this one. I found the varnish on this brush to be way too slick, and had trouble hanging onto it with soapy hands, and so I went through all the trouble to remove the finish right down to the wood, and then, while I was at it, I used a high-speed rotary tool and appropriate burrs to create a random pattern of shallow holes with sharp edges at the surface of the wood (so as to provide a good gripping surface when the handle was slippery with soap). This worked out well, and now there's no problem at all with grip. Also, I installed a powerful disc magnet in the bottom of the handle and now hang it tip-down from a little cubby that's set into the wall beside my bathroom sink. The's no problem after a month or so of use with loss of hairs from the brush––a few came out over the days, but that has ceased. All-in-all, it's a good brush, IMO, but not really as good as the Tweezerman brush. After all the work I've put into making be &#34;just right&#34; I'm definitely going to keep using it.

Stray hairs all over the soap and my face, and the bristles irritated my skin more than a blade ever has. Easy to whip in a cup, but difficult to get a good lather on my face because of how uncomfortable the bristles were. Its been 13 hours since I shaved, and the thought of putting this against my face right now is making me cringe. I give this 2 stars simply because of its low price, and with genuine hope that it softens up and stops shedding after further use/cleaning. If not, I would safely say one star.

But I wanted to complete the whole traditional shaving experience so I ordered this Escali brush based on the feedback I saw.<br /><br />This brush is no gimmick. It is an essential shaving tool if you are using a more traditional cream like the Proraso since the brush is much more effective at lathering up the cream, and preparing your beard than using your hands alone. I've been able to substantially reduce the amount of cream that I use per shave - maybe a third or quarter of what I used to apply by hand. Also, if you are using a double-edged razor (and I don't used it exclusively) you must make two, sometimes three &#34;shaves&#34; in one session to get a completely smooth shave. By using the brush, it always seems to have enough left on it after my first shave for a second.<br /><br />Obviously our grandfathers knew a thing or two about shaving...

  1212. My experience after using this brush for two months:<br /><br />- Yes it does lose bristles, especially on the first use. My soap bar looked like it grew hair. easily 20 hairs of various thickness shed from the brush. However, once the initial batch were lost, I only get the occasional single hair.<br />- Scent: Yup it smells, it's hair. it does not smell great on first use if you don't do something to somewhat condition it. There are various methods out there like hot water soaks in soapy water over night, then lathering some shave soap, and leaving that sit, etc. I did not do that, but I have noticed that after the first few uses the scent has faded considerably, and doesn't overpower some of my subtle soaps. Initially, I'd recommend using a strong scented soap as the natural smell of wet hair isn't great, and easily overpowers light scented soaps.<br />-Softness: It isn't the softest brush, but I don't find it harsh and I have fairly sensitive skin. It's also capable of whipping up a nice lather with hard soaps.<br /><br />Overall - it's a good price for a decent brush, especially for a beginner. No point in shelling out huge money on something you may or may not enjoy. If you do enjoy wet shaving, then you'll have a nice first brush to continue.

  1260. Great item. Fast shipping.
  1261. It is a decent beginner brush and will do. But be prepared that you know the grades of badger hair used in making brushes. This is the lowest of the grade and on a dry face if you put the plume directly to your face you will feel prickly sticks. This is indicative of low grade badger. If you do a paint brush stroke like you do when painting a wall then the low grade hair is not as evident to your face until you increase the angle of the brush upon lifting off your face. You know that old addage.....&#34;You get what you pay for!&#34; Well in the world of shaving brushes this is no different. That said if you have done research you know &#34;silvertip badger&#34; is the softest of the badger from under it's neck. There is even in some circles I have researched a special designation beyond that to a incredible special badger or something. Well, I am not sure about that one but universally the silvertip is regarded as the best and usually what you desire for most faces unless you have just such a tough face that a plain badger will do. You ask the cost difference between a brush like this to a silvertip.............well that varies of course by the manufacturer. I have seen some decent ones around $50 to as high as $300 + for a single silvertip badger brush!!! Here is a tip though...........if you dislike the badger on this brush you can replace the knot with a silvertip for most times cheaper than buying the entire brush with handle. You just have to get the same size knot of silvertip which usually from what I have seen varies from as low as 19mm to as much as 26mm from my experience. I think this Escali is around a 21mm but could be wrong on that. So the reason for 3 stars...........easy, &#34;It's okay&#34; but not great. You must decide what you may need. I have found everyone usually trys to find the cheapest they can live with while the select few will drop a butt load on the best without experimenting. I like to experiment to see what is best for me and how cheap I can get out for. Good luck and the worse your out of is $13 here and you can even replace the knot with a comparable sized knot silvertip!for me and how cheap I can get out for. Good luck and the worse your out of is $13 here and you can even replace the knot with a comparable sized knot silvertip!
  1262. Most brushes tend to lose their game after a few months, but this Escali brings the quality to the fore, and imagine this is the same brush that my father has been using for years.   1279. The first thing I noticed about this brush the first time I used it was the smell. It smells like it has been soaked in raw petroleum for a while, and it hasn't improved over the few times I've used it. I'm actually a little concerned what chemicals I'm smearing on my face when I use it.<br /><br />The next thing I noticed was how many hairs were falling out as I tried to whip up a lather with my proraso soap. A good 10-20 hairs fell out the first use and each subsequent use. I have to pick the hairs out of the soap with a tweezer every time I use it.<br /><br />Finally, it just doesn't have enough bristles, and the bristles it does have are far too soft to get a decent lather going. The bristles should be stiff even when wet, but these hang like a horsetail once wet, and I can't build a lather with it that will cover my face. Also, since the bristles are so soft, it doesn't do a good job of getting the soap under my beard hairs, which results in far more nicking when I shave.<br /><br />Overall a very poor shaving brush...
  1280. I bought this for my husband because I remember my dad using a badger brush for shaving. My husband loves it, using a badger brush and a good razor has allowed my husband to shave more frequently and not break out.
  1281. I can testify that this is a great brush. Although it was bought for someone else it gets stolen on a regular basis and due to that I can say it holds up very well. Exfoliates, doesn't lose a ton of bristles, makes it really easy to lather up and distribute shaving soap and rinses clean very easily.<br /><br />There was no really distinctive animal odor from this brush. I suppose if I really crammed my nose into it I could detect something, but that would assume I know what I should be smelling in the first place. Nothing offensive that I can detect, so that's another good thing. It is easy to keep in shape and clean - just run water through it, take the bristles from right under the handle in the web between index finger and thumb, and squeeze downward once or twice, and the brush is in shape and free of all water and soap. Hang on a holder, and it's ready to go again.<br /><br />So nice when something I buy is exactly as advertised!
  1282. This is a great brush for the price and rivals the more expensive brushes. Once this little jewel is broken you will begin to see why this brush is so popular. Join the club and buy this brush and use the savings to get some more shaving cream.

I was worried I would need a more expensive brush, but I feel confident now that this will last me at least a year. I'm sure it may even beat that.

I rarely see a bristle come out on a daily basis now. I see no issue on shedding. I do dry the brush thoroughly and leave it on its side between use. This brush does the job it was design to do and I see no negative attributes. Great value for the price. I would not buy a more expensive brush.

  1292. My last brush which finally fell apart after 30 years, so I bought this as a replacement. It is a little smaller than I like and I would prefer the bristles to be slightly stiffer.
