Seems they could have done this before shipping the product. If you get one, wash it a few times before using. Unless, of course, you like brown lather.<br /><br />Otherwise it functions OK.
  1293. I have several brushes ranging from inexpensive boar hair to pricey and fancy silvertip badger. They all do what is necessary: create lather from soaps and creams, either directly on the face, in a bowl, or in your hand. The boar hair brushes need a little time to break in (literally, as the hair tips split and become finer, and therefore begin to cut through the soap bubbles) and could get a bit floppy (think brushing-like). The higher end badger brushes are very expensive and too wispy soft so they don’t pick up enough hard soap, for example. But, they all work and do what is expected.<br /><br />This Escali brush (and its identical cousin, the Tweezerman) is the brush I use most often sometimes every day. I’ve tried other “pure badger” grade knots and they are exactly the same in performance... just cost more! This brush whips up lather without effort, straight out of the box (please see below to prepare your brush for first use, however). It needs very little care/maintenance. And, it costs very little in the event you must replace.<br /><br />I’ve been using the same Escali brush for over 2 years. For a period of about 4 months, I used this same brush every day. It’s a pleasure to use, and I actually like the small amount of prickly hairs as they exfoliate during a face lather.<br /><br />Before you begin using:<br />1. Soak in hot tap water for 5-10 minutes.<br />2. Prepare a hot water soap with a few drops of dish soap. Soak in the soapy water for 5-10 minutes.<br />3. Rinse under warm running tap water for 2-3 minutes, taking care to remove all soapy residue.<br />4. Gently squeeze excess water and give a few good shakes.<br />5. Rub tip against a dry clean towel. Shave a bit more and repeat to rub against a dry clean towel. Do this for 30 seconds.<br />6. Place in a well ventilated area and allow to dry. Brush hanger is not necessary, but if you must, place in a dry shallow bowl on its side.<br /><br />After each use, follow steps #4-6 above.<br /><br />After 3-4 months of use, or as soon as too much soap buildup is visible, follow above steps #1-6, but between #2-3 add this step:<br />2a. With a toothbrush, gently brush with the grain of the bristles to help remove soap build up.<br /><br />Some hairs will fall out during the first 1 month of use, then one hair will fall out every 3-4 uses. This is OK. With this type of bristle loss, you will enjoy the brush for a minimum of 5 years, if not more.
  1294. I love this Shaving Brush. It keeps its shape. It's soft. The handle is perfect. When I first received the brush it smelled like a badger! After just a few days, the smell totally disappeared. But the brush remains my favorite of three brands that I own.

  1348. I am new to wet shaving and wanted a cheap brush to learn how to maintain and use them. This exceeded my expectations. I have barely lost any hairs in it, and it keeps the shape well. Do NOT put this on the base or sideways. You either need to jury-rig a string or cord to hang it from or drop 20 dollars on something to hold it properly.   1349. I'm new to wet shaving and this is my very first shaving brush. I didn't want to spend a lot of money on it only to find out that I didn't like wet shaving. The bristles are soft and feel great on my skin. Then, the first time I swirled it around the tub of shaving cream, there were a few bristles left behind.   1363. I'm new to wet shaving.   1366. Shows considerable wear after sitting in my shower for a couple months. Still works great though, and feels fantastic with a good lather.
  1367. This was the first brush I purchased when I started wetshaving. As such, I had no intention of buying one of the expensive brushes on here, or elsewhere, and so chose between the Escali, and the Tweezerman. Both are in the same price range, and both are highly reviewed here on amazon, but I ended up choosing this one by pure chance. The good things about this brush are its price, it feels comfortable in the hand, and it holds and whips up lather really well.<br /><br />However, the negatives far outweight those. Starting with the first time I used the brush, and continuing up to the present, stray hairs began coming out. Some days it would be just a couple, others easily a half dozen or more. This didn't produce any noticeable impact on the brush or its ability to produce lather, but it is very annoying to have a soap covered in badger bristles, and eventually this would have undoubtedly become a problem. But I was saved from having to deal with that potential issue by another one. The handle fell off the brush. I had only been using it for a month, and had been careful not to use it roughly, but it still happened. I uploaded two photos, and of them is a closeup of the glue used to hold the bristles and handle together. Instead of filling the entire area between the two, which would have produced a strong bond, the glue had a large hole in it. This allowed water to seep in and erode it away until the brush fell apart. Considering how these are mass produced somewhere, I highly doubt this is an isolated incident. Perhaps others are more fortunate and it takes them longer than a month for the brush to fall apart, but I have no doubt that eventually it will happen. So do yourself a favor, and buy something else.<br /><br />The [[ASIN:B000G647Y8 Tweezerman Men's Shaving Brush]] is actually cheaper than the Escali, and I've heard very good things about it both on amazon and sites devoted to wetshaving, so that is a very good alternative. Or splurge a little extra money and buy a best badger quality brush. Which brings me to my final point, badger brushes are divided into 3 grades. The lowest is this one, the \\"pure badger\\" one. Next comes \\"best badger,\\" and the most expensive one is \\"silvertip badger.\\" The difference is in what parts of the badger the hairs come from, with pure badger brushes considered the roughest, and silvertip ones the softest. Best badger brushes are considered a good medium for those that like the luxurious softness of the silvertip, but still want the bristles to have enough strength to build a good lather or exfoliate the face.and buy a best badger quality brush. Which brings me to my final point, badger brushes are divided into 3 grades. The lowest is this one, the \\"pure badger\\" one. Next comes \\"best badger,\\" and the most expensive one is \\"silvertip badger.\\" The difference is in what parts of the badger the hairs come from, with pure badger brushes considered the roughest, and silvertip ones the softest. Best badger brushes are considered a good medium for those that like the luxurious softness of the silvertip, but still want the bristles to have enough strength to build a good lather or exfoliate the face.
  1368. This shaving brush was a gift for my husband and he loves it! It lathers up nicely, doesn't shed, and feels nice. Plus, the price is extremely reasonable. A perfect addition to any double edged shaving system.<br /><br />As far as the seller goes, they shipped a terrific product, shipped quickly, and the item was exactly as described. HIghly recommended!
  1369. the Escali shaving brush is perfect! it's thick, natural, pure Badger bristles whip up a lather quickly and apply it thickly. great product.

  1429. I have read a lot of other reviews on here about how many hairs they where finding while using this brush, so I was nervous about buying this, but I'm cheap first and foremost!<br /><br />Personally I had some hairs come out in the first use, but as to be expected. I was in too much of a hurry and didn't do the proper break in technique I read online, so had some issues, but once I used it and broke it in, I may find a hair every once in a great while. For anyone interested in breaking in a brush, you first clean the brush with dish soap thoroughly, trying to get as many of the hairs out as possible, then rinse, then put into a solution of dish soap for about 4 hours, then rinse again trying to get out many of the hairs. Finally whip up a good lather and stand the brush on end to let the lather dry on the bristles. This really helps get rid of the smell, and the lose bristles out.<br /><br />My only issue is that it's not overly soft, but not bad. That's why it gets 4 and not 5 starts; however, for its cost range it should be a 5.<br /><br />It's a good little brush. Buy with confidence.
  1430. This brush is holding up well for me after a year of shaving. No major shedding, the hair is good quality, and the price was the best I found.

He says that it lathers well and feels soft and smooth against his skin. So far, after a week's worth of shaves it has held up nicely and no bristles have fallen out. It sits perfectly in the mission style wood shave stand that I got him as well. This seems to be a great brush for those just starting in safety razor shaving. Of course you can get a better quality brush by spending more money. In my opinion though, when you are on a budget and aren't certain if you will want to stick with this style of shaving, this brush is a great value. No need to spend a crazy amount of money if you are new to this method. Save your money on a fancy brush and instead get a quality razor and blades. I feel like those are more important. No complaints.

  1529. Very nice.This is my second brush. I must admit that I did not know how to care for these brushes when I bought my first brush. That truly is not an issue. If you treat this brush, as i now do, with the mininmum of care for a brush, it will last. Ahh, the minimun of care, don't squeeze it dry. Don't use the brush like a paint brush. Swirl it. Rinse it if you like but not with the handle down (meaning the water rinsing over the brush with the handle with the handle facing the sink) . Any soap, cream (I use cream) that is left on the brush will not be detriment when used for the next shave. I am not a 'life long' straight razor user, but will be considered one as of last year.
  1530. It gets the job done, but the cheapness shows.<br /><br />I used this brush for 6 months -- I shaved once every two to three days. This brush shed every time I used it. The brush also didn't lather well, but it worked just enough for me to continue using it.<br /><br />I upgraded to a $30 Beauty Strokes H.I.S. synthetic brush and now I am much happier. The synthetic brush does not shed, is softer, and builds lather much better.<br /><br />Again, this $10 brush works, but you definitely get what you pay for at this low price point.

  1553. Great brush for the money. Wanna prevent shedding? Do normal soap wash and rinse prior to using the first time. You do that with any new brush to &#34;clean it up&#34;
  1554. I got this brush after reading a piece on shaving using a badger brush. The brush was packed in a simple packaging and was easy to get out. At first, it smells strongly of badger hair and the smell decreases after repeated use. Its only after shaving with it for a few times, I realized the correct way to use it. What I do is use a small disposable plastic cup to form my lather. If you have a shaving bowl, that's better. Get a small amount of shaving cream in the cup and use the badger brush to lather it. Before that make sure that the badger brush is soaked in warm water for a minute or two to moisten its bristles. The trick is to use a little more water than you would do with a normal nylon brush. The badger hair are good at retaining water and you can get a real good lather. So, start whipping the shaving cream in the cup with circular hand motions and add some water if you feel there is not enough lather. The brush is real smooth on the face and covers your face with thick foam in no time.<br />The 4 star rating is due to the initial loss of few hair bristles from the brush during lathering which I had to remove from my face in order to shave properly.
  1555. As a newbie to wet shaving I was looking for an affordable brush that would give me a good lather and hold up well. This brush has not disappointed and I would definitely recommend for the beginner or experienced wet shaver!!
  1556. Great brush, very easy on te face. The size is just right. Also purchased the chrome stand for both brush & razor Escali makes, All good!
  1557. sheds every time I use it. every time. would not buy this brush again.
  1558. This brush has performed well. The bristles absorb water quickly making for a soft application of shaving cream.You can't beat this brush for the price.
  1559. This brush is great for wet shaving. It has plenty of badger hair, the wood handle is comfortable, and it will allow you to lather like pro. At first, the brush will smell like a wet dog, but if you soak it in dish washing detergent (look online to find out how to break in a new brush and remove the smell) and use it often the smell will disappear. Be sure to soak the brush in warm water to soften the bristles because it can feel a bit hard and prickly to sensitive skin. The badger hair retains water well, and with adequate water+soap, a great foamy lather can be achieved. Be sure to clean the brush thoroughly and hang it with the bristles down to dry. I have had several knots form in this brush and I still have yet to take them out. This brush is priced very well, and will do everything a shaving brush is supposed to do. Take good care of it and it will go a long way.
  1560. It's fine, but it sheds every time I use it. Maybe this is common, but otherwise it does the job like one would expect.

  1603. This is my first shaving brush and it works wonderfully. I've been shaving for 25 years and can't believe I didn't go to the better safety razor, Geo F. Trumper shaving cream and this Escali shaving brush sooner. A pea size amount of the shaivng cream in the palm of my hand, a quick run of the Escali brush through the faucet water and then working the brush into the palm of my hand to pick up the cream provides a great coat of shaving cream on my face. So much better than some cream out of a can and lathered on top of the whiskers. The brush really picks the whiskers off my face and makes the shave so much smoother. I used the safety razor with canned shaving cream for about 2 months, and the difference between that and using the Escali brush is like the difference between day and night, shaving burn and smoothe skin, bloody chin and baby bottom smoothness.
  1604. This brush is very, very good for the price. I've owned cheapie boar-hair brushes before and this is the first badger-hair brush I've tried. I'll just say that this brush is far superior.<br /><br />There are a few faults, but all are forgivable at this price.<br /><br />Firstly... yes, the bristles do have an animal odor about them at first. It's not terrible, but noticeable. The smell goes away the more you use the brush. To reduce the smell almost immediately, follow the instructions at this link: [...]<br /><br />Next up, I did notice that the bristles were a bit prickly during the first few uses. Again, this abates with time and use... use the break-in procedure linked above to reduce the prickly feeling right out of the box.<br /><br />Lastly, there is some shedding. I've used the brush for about 15 shaves now and I seem to lose an average of 3 bristles each use. I gently squeeze out excess water before storing the brush hanging handle-up for a drip dry. I don't think I'm abusing the brush in any way and hopefully it will stop losing bristles once all the loose ones have fallen out.<br /><br />Those three faults are (in my opinion) very minor when you consider the price and how well this brush makes a lather. Whether on my face or in my mug, this brush does a fantastic job of building a lather with either soap or cream (or in my case, a dab of Taylor's cream with soap).<br /><br />Despite the early bristle loss, I think this brush is wonderful for the price. I will most likely give it 5 stars in the future if it stops losing a couple bristles with every shave. For the wet-shave beginner, this brush is quite good.
  1605. My first brush in 40 years glad I am shaving with a blade again
  1606. Have had it for a while and it is still going strong. I don't have anything to compare it to.
  1607. I am thoroughly pleased with this brush. The quality of the product seems to be exceptional. The bristles are soft, yet firm enough to work lather into my beard after a couple days of growth. I dry the brush hanging from the handle, keeping the bristles always expanded and ready. Update: After having used this brush for a couple months, the bristle adhesive let go while I was rinsing it.
  1608. It sheds some hair but gives a smooth shave.
  1609. This is the first brush I've ever owned. Not an expert on these things, but I'd say it's a good buy. After a few shaves, the bristles soften and the brush stops shedding. All in all I'm happy with this experience.
  1610. Over all, I like this product.<br />I haven't had a chance to use it all that much, but the times that I have it's worked pretty well. A few bristles have fallen off in the brushing process, but it doesn't seem to happen every time.<br />It's a pretty good price for a pretty good product.
  1611. Excellent product!! 100% pure badger shaving brush at less than half the cost of competitors. Not only was the price right but I own expensive brushes & inexpensive brushes and this one is the best.
  1612. As many before me have said, is is a smelly, stiff brush right out of the package. Take the time to condition it and you'll have it in your brush rotation in no time.<br /><br />1. Add a bit of water and dish soap and lather a bit, and let the brush soak for a few hours<br /><br />2. Rinse it off, and lather up one of your soaps or creams. Then let it sit in your mug or bowl overnight, with the lather.<br /><br />3. Clean it off, and give it the smell test. If it's still \\"badgery,\\" repeat step 2<br /><br />Mine is now nice and soft, and smells like shave soap. It's not a great brush, but for $12... It's a great brush.
  1613. Brush is extremely soft, durable, looks great. Fortunately I already had a brush holder, but would be nice if one was included!
  1614. When I started shaving with a DE razor a couple months back I was using what remained of my canned shaving gels (Aveeno, Edge) that I used with my cartridge razors. I decided to go for the full wet-shave experience and purchased this Escali Badger Brush and some TOBS shaving cream. I read a lot of the reviews of the Escali brush here on Amazon and decided it was worth the small investment to try it out. I have been using the brush for about two weeks now, and here's what I think:<br /><br />First off, this is a nice badger brush for very cheap money. It's not a large brush but certainly more than adequate for my shaving needs, I actually like the size. It holds water well, and works up a great lather with my TOBS cream. The bristles were a little stiff on my face for the first few days, but they have softened nicely and no longer feel like they are pricking my skin. The brush did shed about 12-15 bristles over the course of the first three shaves, but none since. Not sure if this is normal or not, but shedding has not a problem with the brush at all, after those initial uses.<br /><br />Some users commented that there was a strong animal smell to the brush, but aside from a very mild, musky smell during the first couple of uses I have noticed no odor problem at all. That faint smell faded to nothing after the first few days and all I can smell on the brush now is the residual fragrance of my shaving cream.<br /><br />Guys, it's pure badger, it works well, and it's twelve bucks. You just can't go wrong on this one.
  1615. I would have liked it, as the bristles are nice and soft, but the handle came off after 1 use. There appears to be a crack (or piece missing) where brush connects to wood.
  1616. I love the feel of the brush on my skin. The smell was annoying but it is going away. The brush holds water well enough for me and shedding is minimal.
  1617. I'm sorry folks, you get what you pay for and this just isn't it. Yes you'll save some money, and yes it's supposed to be real badger, but I'm not convinced. Do yourself a favor and order the Parker brush - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002RJC1HC/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1 - Somehow I lost my Parker brush of multiple years, and had to order a replacement. I ordered the Escali, but it couldn't even touch the Parker. The Escali wasn't stiff, however the bristles weren't remotely soft compared to Parker's. The lather was lacking. Furthermore, there was a brownish residue in the water when rinsing out the brush (which in Escali's defense I'm sure goes away after multiple uses.) For me it just wasn't worth it. I sent this one back and ordered a replacement parker. Save yourself the time and use a brush that's worthy of your face.
  1618. The brush arrived on time with zero defects and works just like I thought it would. I have never tried a boar hair brush or other badger hair so I don't know how the stiffness of this brush compares, but it feels just fine to me.
  1619. This is the first shave brush that I have bought. I previously used the spray foam stuff that came from the can and now that I have this brush and some real shave soap I am experiencing a much closer shave. This brush makes a rich and frothy lather and really gets under my stubble in order to bring the hairs out. The only reason I give this a 4 instead of a 5 star review is because it sheds a bit. The first few times I used it, 4-5 badger hairs would dislodge every time I tried to make a nice lather. Now, after a month or so of shaving every 2-3 days, a hair or two will dislodge. It's nothing to be concerned about but I thought it should be mentioned.
  1620. It's a nice brush I think. I've never owned any other brush and I've had this for about a month. Shipping took the average amount of time. Packaging was nice. When you start using, you'll notice that many hairs will come out, but will this will stop after you break it in.
  1621. New DE Shaver is loving the experience. This brush works just great. You might think it is cheap but does the job. I make very easy lather with PRORASO sensitive skin soap (also a great product).<br /><br />Enjoy!

  1638. This brush has lasted one year and is still going strong with regular use!<br /><br />It will lose quite a few hairs initially, and a couple every time you use it. However, it still creates a good lather one year later!<br /><br />Remember to let this dry upside down, so either buy a fancy stand or make one out of a wire hanger (they both work).<br /><br />One piece of advice, lather up your cream in the palm of your non dominant hand instead of a glass or mug. When you lather up your non dominant hand you can easily apply the cream to your face without wasting any cream in the mug/glass. Also, the brush is bristly and they do not feel too good on your face.<br /><br />You will enjoy this product for the price!
  1639. Sheds a lot for the first few uses but then settles down. Dries quickly, but the main problem with this brush is it's too floppy to be of much good. You actually end up applying lather with the side of the brush more than the actual tip. I've gone back to my synthetic brush until I find a good badger brush.
  1640. I bought this as my first shaving brush, and it did the job well enough. It makes a nice lather once you get the hang of it. The bristles are somewhat prickly on the ends, and like other reviewers, mine loses bristles. At first it was just now and then, but after a year of shaving every other day, it now loses 2-4 bristles per use. They stick in the soap and to your face. I've been religious about washing it out, shaking it dry, and laying it on its side to dry. (I don't have a stand.) I've now got a synthetic brush for $25 that I really like. I'd recommend the Escali if you want to try out shaving with a brush & soap, but aren't sure you'll like it. Otherwise, spend a little more for a better quality brush.

  1647. I usually get the drug store variety of brushes and they don't hold up. This brush is well made with a metal ferrule at the base of the bristles and a wooden (not plastic) handle. I've been using it for a while now and it looks as though it will hold up under everyday use.
  1648. So this brush has been relegated to my travel shave kit, because I don't travel all that often.<br /><br />The bristles aren't anchored deep enough into the handle, so as soon as the brush meets my face, the bristles flatten out into a squashed mess.<br /><br />I have a less expensive, no-name boar brush I picked up as an add-on from the company that makes my shaving soap, and it keeps it's shape when wet and gives me a much better lather.<br /><br />This likely would be improved, were the bristles anchored deeper into the handle so they keep their shape during use.   1687. I am very impressed with this brush at such a low price. The bristles are very soft, but the form a great lather. This brush performs as well, if not better, than my &#34;Art of Shaving&#34; badger brush, which was more than 2x the price. I want to offer the warning, however, that the brush has an odor, the first few times you get it wet (think wet badger smell). This can be surprising, the first time you encounter it, as it is very strong. But, after a few uses and rinses, the odor fades away. You may want to lather it up and rinse it out a few times, before you plan to start using it. Also, I recommend buying a stand to hold the brush with bristles down, to let it air dry. This will improve the performance and lifetime of the brush.
  1688. This was my first badger brush so I wasn't sure what to expect but I got an unpleasant smell from it for the first couple of weeks. It did lose hairs as well during the first couple of weeks too so maybe these are all things you have to contend with using a new badger brush. After having used it for several months, it no longer has the unpleasant smell, holds what bristles it has pretty well and doesn't give off the strange brown color when rinsing it. I give it 3 stars because I don't know if all these issues are normal. If they are .. then I would probably rate it closer to 5 stars as it holds up and works well now that it's broken in. ** UPDATE after a year use: The brush consistently loses hairs with every use which is quite annoying on the face while shaving and in the mixing bowl. The finish has held up good. I'd rather pay more for a brush that doesn't keep losing hairs.

Some hairs fall out every shave but, after a month so far, the brush is holding up well. It's served well as my learner brush before I upgrade to something a bit nicer, and I am completely satisfied with my purchase. Definitely recommend!

There is a faint odor when the brush is new that goes away after a few uses but not so strong as to be offensive. All in all if you are just getting into the wet shave this is a good brush to start off with letting you experience a badger brush for not a lot of money just in case you decide you don't want to continue with the wet shave.

  1807. As a disclaimer, I'm fairly new to wet shaving, after many, many years of buying cream in a can and shaving with whatever the latest fad multiple blade shaver is out there.<br /><br />However, this is a very good badger brush, at an excellent price. Like many brushes, it does have a strong odor when you first use it (it isn't offensive, but you can notice it). The smell is only on the brush - it doesn't come onto your skin. This smell goes away fairly quickly - you won't notice it by the 5th shave.<br /><br />The brush has a good handle, and the bristles are firm in a good way. When you first use it, you'll find it sheds hairs. Again, it stops to shed once it has been worn in, and after your 5th-10th shave, it will hold true.<br /><br />Those of you who have experience with brushes, you'll find that the wooden handle is very light. Those that like to have a bit of weight in their handle (like ceramic or brass) will find this one very light. However, if you are looking to start using shaving soap or cream - you will be hard pressed to find fault with this little beauty.

  1835. You can spend more or less on a shaving brush; this one is an excellent find. It holds water nicely and quickly works up a rich lather. If you want a close shave and are tired of spending big bucks for 4 - 6 bladed razors, start here with a quality brush. Be sure to order a shaving brush and razor stand. Excellent gift for the man in your life or a treat for yourself.<br /><br />Have read a few negative reviews and it appears some users are disappointed because they do not understand how to take care of a shaving brush. It must be soaked in warm water for a few minutes before lathering soap or cream. It's the stored water in the bristles that creates lather not muscle and grinding bristles into soap or cream. Brush must be dried bristle side down outside a cabinet. Once dried you can store it in a closed cabinet, if you don't allow it to dry it will smell funky. Why not just display the brush and double edged razor in an attractive chrome stand. Looks cool and makes me happy happy happy. Any brush will shed some hairs initially so don't fret. Take time to shape the brush when dry. Try this for a smooth shave: Take a finger print sized dab of Taylor of Old Bond Street Sandalwood Shaving Cream and place on top of Proraso Shaving Soap, Eucalyptus & Menthol. Soak the brush in warm water for a few minutes, shake excess water and lather up cream and soap mix. Out of this world rich lather! Added benefit, it exfoliates your skin as you apply lather. Whether you use up and down stokes, like a painter, or do circles, let the brush do its work without smashing the bristles. Enjoy!
  1836. This is my &#34;go to&#34; brush for every day shaving. Certainly, this would be hard to beat for the price. Since the handle is wood, it is extremely easy to drill a hole and put in an &#34;eye&#34; screw to hang up the brush.<br /><br />I have had very few bristles fall out. But, I take care not to soak the handle in water and I always hang it up to dry.
  1837. This brush meets all my expectations except one: that badger hair brushes are expensive. I am quite satisfied with my purchase and the quality of the product and would recommend it to anyone wanting to experience the comfort of an old-fashioned shave.

  1840. I recently switched to a safety razor to save some money on razor cartridges and had to get a shaving brush. This one has lost a few hairs but overall has been a great experience.   1843. I bought this brush 8 months ago and have yet to have a shave where it didn't loose at least 5 bristles in the process. I recently was given a vastly nicer brush with a much-softer (and non-shedding) \\"best badger\\" knot in it and decided to see just how many more bristles the Escali brush would loose. I spent several minutes rubbing the brush on my palm over the sink and coated the porcelain with more than 50 bristles which promptly jammed up the drain. I then cleared the sink and tried it again with almost as many lost in the next round. I don't know if all the bristles will just fall out, but I got bored before finding an end-point to the shedding. The brush isn't looking \\"thin\\" yet, but the never-ending shedding is annoying as the coarse hairs deposited on your face can jam up your razor.<br /><br />Also, the bristles are pretty sharp (at least compared to my new brush) and I find using it unpleasant aside from the shedding.

Shaving has transformed itself from a chore to something that I look forward to.<br /><br />Would definitely recommend.
  1849. I got this for $9 - be aware Amazon changes prices constantly so you may be able to get it for that much too instead of the regular $13 or so. This makes a great travel brush. It's a little scritchy but that tells me the bristles are getting under my beard & lifting the whiskers to provide for a great shave. I've found it face lathers and bowl lathers very well with Arko, Proraso green (tube), Proraso white (tub), or Proraso red (tub). I can't speak for how long it will last but I expect at least several years if taken care of. This brush is a great product.
  1850. Decent, but not as comfortable to use as the much cheaper boar brush it replaced. After a month of use, still feels very harsh and prickly against the skin.
  1851. The bristles started coming out with the first use. My badger seems to have a receding hairlime. I find more of the badger hair on the floor of my shower than my own!
  1852. Very nice brush compared to a Van Der Hagen boar brush. Makes a very nice, thick lather, quick! I've read in the reviews that this brush would not fit in a Colonel Conk stand. Mine fits perfectly and allows the brush to dry properly with the bristles pointing down. There is a very nice gloss finish on the handle. I've had about 10 shaves with this brush and still experience 1 to 2 hairs falling off the knot each time I lather with it. Price considered, I still think it's a solid 5 star and absolutely worth the price if you're thinking about moving up from a boar brush.
  1853. The brush is very good except for losing bristles frequently. It is a good value which for a reasonable price.
  1854. . . . before it had completely shed the entire finish on the handle. This means the wood of the handle is now completely exposed to the \\"wet\\" part of wet-shaving.<br /><br />Bristles are okay, but the handle is so bad it more than negates any good here.
  1855. My first badger brush so I really didn't know what to expect. After reading some other reviews I purchased Escali since the price wasn't going to burn my wallet. I did notice after the first few weeks, a few strands of the brush was coming off. About a month later, no hairs were falling off. It's been about 3 months since I started using this brush and the hair is still full and helps create a good lather. I strongly believe this brush will last me at least a decade. Make sure you keep it dry and hanging brush facing down on a stand.
  1856. Not only does the brush work well, but I like that the plastic case it comes in works well for protecting it while traveling.   1870. You'll see a lot of badger hair brushes on the market for upwards of $50-100 but there isn't really a need to look further than this brush - it's the best value out there. I haven't had any problems with shedding or smell as some other reviewers have noted here but make sure to sanitize the brush before your first use and then maintain it properly during it's life (rinse, blow dry if possible, hang upside down to continue drying).
  1871. I gave this as a gift. The recipient said it didn't grab on to shaving soap well the first time but after 1 or 2 uses, it's great. Very soft and flexible.
  1872.   1873. Best shaving brush I have ever used. I have had a lot of trouble recently with brushes that would fall apart within a month. This one seems to be holding up very well.<br /><br />It also does a great job providing a nice thick application of lather. Easy to clean up and store.
  1874. I purchased one of these nearly a year ago. My first shaving brush. I splashed some water on my face, got the bristles wet, swirled it around my dish of shaving soap, lathered it up on my chin, cheeks, and neck, aaaaaand suddenly knew what wet badger smelled like. (A lot like wet dog, it turns out.) I also ended up covering my face with badger fur.<br /><br />OK, so it turns out badger fur brushes are supposed to be soaked in soapy water and rinsed out before using. I can't fault the manufacturers for my ignorance. (I just related my experience to serve as a forewarning for others.) But I CAN fault them for the brush continuing to shed hair for weeks to come. I'm not exaggerating. It shed fur. Every. Time. I. Shaved. For weeks.<br /><br />I was hesitant to give up on this brand. It's the most affordable one I've seen, and for all I knew this was just how badger fur brushes were. Most of the reviews on this site were positive. Perhaps the one I bought was a fluke? I ordered another.<br /><br />I soaked the new brush in soapy water for a few hours, then rinsed in thoroughly in running water. The first couple shaves the brush still smelled a little musty, and it shed a little. But since then it's been great. I've been using it for weeks now, with no smell and nary a loose hair to annoy me.<br /><br />Brush #2 has been very good, and I'm going to assume Brush #1 was a fluke. I'd recommend this product, with the caveat being that a little preparation and patience is necessary.
  1875. The Escali brush comes in at a very reasonable price and has performed well for me. Shaving has gone from being an irksome necessity to something I look forward to. Other than some minor early shedding (which has mostly stopped), it has been very solid. The brush is an excellent value and I'm glad to recommend it.
  1876. It's probably one of the most economical brushes out there and it shows why. Being conscious about hygiene i thought i should first give the brush a wash before using it. I was right to do so! Turns out that as I'm soaking the brush in warm water, it starts to change the water's color to a dark brown. I highly doubt the manufacturers sterilized it. Luckily I have some chlorhexidine solution lying around so I was able to clean it properly. I suggest anyone who buys one of these brushes do the same. It builds up a decent lather and isn't harsh on the face. Its loosing some of the hairs but since its a new brush, it is expected to happen. Lets hope the shedding does not continue much further.
  1877. Great Value. Works well

Not really a significant issue, this is to be expected from most brushes.<br /><br />The bristles are great, just about the right 'softness.' It has lasted for a year, and I see no signs of needing a new one anytime soon, so all the better on reliability. The price is right.   1888. I'm really enjoying this brush. It's cheap and I find the quality is solid for its price. I am African American/Italian and I always suffered from ingrown hair and inflammation on my face (when I cut close to my skin). I recently came across a video on youtube and use this person's tips along with exfoliating my skin twice a day with this badger brush, it has done a lot for my skin. The things that cleared up my facial skin (surprisingly): Selsun Blue Medicated, face scrubber, and Escali badger brush. I apply the Selsun Blue Medicated in the shower with the face scrubber and I apply the badger brush to my beard in the morning and at night. I'd say my face is about 90% clear or more, it hasn't been this good since I didn't grow facial hair (more than ten years ago). But the brush even before I was using the other tips was working well for my skin. It really helps to clean up your skin, as well as lift and soften your hair. I feel this is particularly valuable for those with curly hair that will tend to curl back into the skin (but obviously it could work for anyone). This is a solid brush and I recommend it, if it did what it did for me, no telling what it can do for you!
  1889. solid brush. this is the first shaving brush i have used and i am happy with it. smells like the animal hair when you apply it to your face, but that's likely because it's made out of animal hair! all in all i'm happy.

  1903. I started using shaving brushes with this brush, and it was a okay quality and inexpensive way to get into using a shaving brush. The brush started out rather stinky, but I let it soak in some dish soap for a few hours, and then let it soak in regular hair conditioner and at then end of this process the stink was nearly completely gone, and the brush was much softer than it was when I first got it.<br /><br />Please note that you really NEED to clean it before your first use or you will do as I did and smear badger smell all over your face.<br /><br />After having this for about 9 months all of the bristles came out of the wooden part. They are all glued in as a clump, and I was able to super glue them back in and reglued it every month or so for the past few months, but I am finally moving on and getting a newer and higher quality brush.<br /><br />If you are just getting into brush shaving and you don't know if it is right for your, then this is a great brush for you. If you want a quality brush that is going to last a long time, then check out some of the better brushes.

  1918. I am rapidly approaching middle age,&#34;I am 72&#34; I have always since age, about 18 used a garden variety Drug Store, or Grocery Store, shaving brush; well let me tell all who might be interested, this brush is; at least for me, far, far, ahead of those garden variety brushes. It loads and holds lather very well, it feels good on my face. Just for the sake of clarity here, I shave twice almost every morning. I use a variety of straight razors and sometimes a safety razor. The brush holds enough lather that after I have hot ragged my face I can dip the brush in the hot water, shake it out and will still have enough warm lather for my first save, probably for both shaves, good lather, hot water, sharp razors, and a good brush have made shaving a pleasure instead of a chore. This brush is great for me. I especially like the fact that it will load so much lather. First time I used it I saw that it was going to lose some hair, so, for the first two times that I used it I combed it out with the coarse end of my comb, it rarely loses a hair now. I cant tell from it's performance that it's ever lost any.<br /> Sign Me, Happy and Satisfied.<br /> Allen G.
  1919. It holds water and lather for the 15 monutes it takes me to shave and it's become softer and easier to use over the few weeks I've been using it. the only gripe I have at all is the wood is kind of cheap and it doesn't have the premium feel to match the razor (I paired it with a Edwin Jagger DE89) but what can you expect for such an affordable price? if this isn't your first brush, I would look elsewhere as this is probably not going to be an upgrade for you, but if you want to test the safety shaving waters, this is a quailty product with a very low entry fee.

It shed probably less than a total of six hairs during the first and second shaves, but after that, no more dropped hairs. I hang it to dry on the rack, and it dries perfectly, ready for the next shave. I believe it when the experts say that badger hair brushes are the best, because this brush does what it is supposed to, and does it well. I am totally happy with this brush, and I consider the price point an outstanding value. I would buy it again. I have nothing negative to say about this shaving brush. I hope this helps in your decision making.
  1965. An excellent brush that lifts up your wiskers before shaving.My only regret is that I did not order the stand.
  1966. Lovely brush for shaving. High quality. Will purchase item again when needed. Had one already and this if for a son who will be traveling and living abroad.
  1967. Great brush for the price. Purchased as a Xmas gift for my brother. He loves it and I will most likely purchase one in the future.
  1968. This is a very nice product; none of the badger hair comes out of the brush. Make sure to dry it completely before putting it away.
  1969. Finally decided to give old time shaving a go and this is the brush I went with.<br />I went with relatively inexpensive items across the board since I was just getting started.<br />This brush seems to hold lather well and is very comfortable on the face.<br />I had a few bristles fall out the first couple of uses but since then it seems to have stopped shedding.<br />Overall I'm very satisfied with this brush and consider it a great value.
  1970. Bristles fall out every time.
  1971. so far so good. i have only lost one hair strand out of it. It does hold more water than the bore bristles. good product.
  1972. Escali 100% Pure Badger Shaving Brush is an incredible value. I recently started shaving with a safety razor, and comparing the price of this brush to the average brush made it a very simple choice. Paired with a quality shaving soap or cream it creates a wonderful lather, however, you can tell the quality is not equal to the 30+ dollar brushes as the bristles are a bit rough. It does the job well, and if you don't see the reason to spend double the price on a brush, this one will do the job quite well.
  1973. Can't beat what I got for what I paid. Some minor shedding at first, but that was to be expected. I'm using less soap than with my old brush and getting a better shaving experience.
  1974. First Badger brush for shaving with a safety razor. It works very well, holds water and makes a great lather. I would definitely recommend this brush.
  1975.   1980. I feel that the Escali 100% Pure badger Shaving Brush is a great bargain and a great product for the price!
  1981. It holds a good among of water to build a good lather in a mug however it did loose about 15 hairs total after three shaves but after that only once in a while does it loose another
  1982. I use to apply the lather and it usually leaves one or two little hairs on my face that I have to pick off and re-apply. It's not the best of brushes, obviously, but for the price it's not bad and it gets the job done.
  1983. Good for the price, but will probably spring for a higher quality brush the next time around. Good for a first brush.
  1984. I've had this brush for a couple of years--and have given them as gifts. I've been pleased with the quality--and it's hard to go wrong with a badger hair brush for under $15. However, in my experience, the bristles on the Escali are much stiffer than the Tweezerman. And in my opinion, they don't become softer. But if you want a brush that exfoliates (or if you like to rotate your brushes), this can be a good thing. If you want softer, I'd go with the Tweezerman. I have both and like them equally.
  1985. Nice wooden handle and natural bristles. Did lose a lot of the bristles at first but seems ok no that I've used it for awhile. Like the finish a lot.
  1986. My first brush so I don't have anything to compare it to. Makes it easy to lather up, soft bristles so you don't feel like you are brushing your face with a wire brush. Noticed a couple of bristles come off, but not a big deal. Fewer than a high dollar paint brush.
  1987. When I first used this product I had an issue with the hairs coming off. Since this is my first shave brush I can't be too hard on it. It does build lather very nicely and is very comfortable. My next brush will probably be a boar's hair brush since I like a more bristly feel. For the price I paid I'd say it was money well spent as my first shave brush.
  1988. This brush looks good and the build quality seems good, but I did have some personal issues with it. For the several first shaves, this brush had an unpleasant smell to it and the water that dripped off it after the first use was sooty. I also found it uncomfortably prickly. I had previously used a brush from a Van Der Hagen set that was softer, did not have a smell and had cleaner (whiter) looking bristles. After using this Escali for several shaves, these problems have mostly gone away (or perhaps I have grown used to them). In short, I do not know if my criticisms reflect the quality of the product or merely something to be expected from an animal product. If you're okay with a breaking in period, this brush might be fine for you.
  1989. Soft, no poor odor, good handle, and it even looks good. It hold water well, and it rinses super easy. I did lose a few bristles on the first use though. Some reviews seem to indicate a LOT of bristle loss, others almost none. I can infer that either A) Some reviewers are being too aggressive with it, or B) This product varies in quality and is not consistent. I'll leave that to the reader to decide which they think it is!<br /><br />All in all, a great brush for the money!
  1990. Works great! Creates a rich lather, cleans up nicely. Makes me look forward to shaving in the morning.

  2003. I read about this in an article published by The Art of Manliness and was sold.
  2004. This brush is not the softest. It lathers ok, but doesn't create enough for two or three passes...... (like it's much more expensive counterparts.) The brush is cheap. It does not shed particularly and is very much worth the price you pay. Let's face it. My Simpson Chubby Best Badger or even the Semogue Boar brush I own would be an unfair comparison to this Escali Badger. If you soak it in a heavy, heavy shampoo bath for a few hours and thoroughly rinse it out when you get it, the fairly pungent badger hair smell disappears and it actually has an attractive bloom as the hairs dry out. The brush is truly a great value, but should not be expected to perform like a Kent. Omega or Vulfix. It gives a decent shaving experience with very little cash outlay.
  2005. Brush is soft, sheds very little initially, but lathers well. Will purchase again for a gift.

  2021. Keep in mind this is my first shaving brush and I had no idea what to expect. Also keep in mind that I have had it only a short time and can not speak to its durability or lack thereof. Now that the caveats are out of the way...<br /><br />I am extremely happy with this purchase. The brush feels great on my face and it lathers well with my shave soap. It's hard to explain but it somehow makes the shaving experience much more pleasurable for me. My shaves seem closer, but I know that the shave is mostly the result of my razor and shave soap. The wood handle is comfortable in my hand and the feel of the badger bristles is soft and pleasant on the skin. After reading several reviews of various brushes I was under the impression that cleaning the brush might be more difficult than it is. Running it under water and squeezing the brush hairs easily clears the remaining soap from the brush. I squeeze the excessive water out and then hang it upside down on a brush stand that I bought separately.<br /><br />Since I haven't tried any other brushes I can't comment on more expensive brushes, but it is hard for me to understand how much better a $50 brush could be than this inexpensive model. Hopefully, I will get that opportunity at some point and if I do I will update this review.<br /><br />If half stars were permitted I would have given this product 4 1/2 stars based on how much I like it and the price point. The one minor negative that cost the half point is the perfectly round handle can roll. I noticed that several other brushes have a flat side to prevent this. I can't imagine the price would have been significantly different if they had shaped it not to roll.
  2022. My dad has had the same shave brush for as long as I can remember..20+ years... When the bristles started to fall off, he was sure he'd never find another just as good...I ordered this brush and he LOVED it even more than his old one!! :)

I use a dry lather method, slowly building up the lather on my palm. This brush is so much better than a synthetic bristle type, and the bristles are soft, while the brush holds a large amount of lather. The resulting lather also feels creamier, maybe due to the fact that it can introduce air and water to the cream more effectively. Great product!

  2048. The shaving brush showed up in a short amount of time and it's been really great. The product is of considerable quality and I've had no issues with it to date.
  2049. I was looking for a brush as part a gift set with a new Double Edge Razor by Merkur. This Brush is a pure Badger Shaving Brush at a great price with excellent quality. I could not have been more pleased!
  2050. I had never really used a shaving brush correctly until I saw a video on how to correctly prepare the brush for shaving. Here's the method I learned: soak the brush in warm (not hot) water for a minute or two, then shake gently to unload some of the water. Try not to scrub the brush in a circular motion to generate lather. Once finished, rinse the brush gently to remove the lather (does not require harsh motion) and shake to get the remaining water out. Gently run the brush over a soft towel OR hang in a stand to air dry.Let the brush bloom to aid in drying (the brush does not require that the hair be compacted or shaped). Shedding will occur at first AND if you don't prepare the brush in water! Else this brush is well made and very effective.
  2051. Honey badgers don't care about your face and if you cut yourself shaving, but this badger brush does, and helps lather up a nice shaving cream for your face, not too prickly and kind of soft.... the only downside is that you have to squeeze some of the water out before you lather up or your shaving cream will be all types of watery
  2052. I bought this brush as my first brush when I started DE shaving. For the value, it is fantastic. Lost a few hairs on the first few uses but now it works great. As with many things, you get what you pay for. However, I would rate this brush as top tier for the price point. It is now my travel brush and I love it.

The other day I took my brush out, she became entranced and walked right up to me, standing on her back legs and placing both paws on the sink (she's a black lab, so it's not like she's tiny). A simple, &#34;Go&#34; command for my wife was all it took to grab the dog and toss her into the bathtub as I quickly placed the brush back and began running the water to clean the pup.<br /><br />Seriously, you think I'm joking, but this brush has all sorts of great applications as now I don't have to carry 60 pounds of trembling weight to the bathroom when it's time to get clean.

  2204. This is my first badger brush, and altogether I'm satisfied with it. No, it's not a pricey silver-tip brush, but it's great for a beginner. As others have noted, it is animal hair, so it will give off a bit of funk the first time it gets wet. It will also shed hairs the first few times you use it.<br /><br />I would recommend soaking it in hot water in a cup, and swirl in some shave soap to cleanse the bristles before you use it the first time. When I did this the water turned brown from the dirt and oil on the badger hair. Repeat 2 - 3 times until the water is clear and there's no more smell. Also, massage in some shave soap and comb out any loose bristles. Just takes 10 minutes then you're ready to shave!<br /><br />(I purchased mine from Amazon seller, Perella's, and received it in good condition)

  2234. I'm a first-time user of shaving brushes, so I'm certainly no expert. I've read about odors with Badger brushes & hairs coming out. After only seven uses, I can't rate its long-term durability, but I only found two hairs on the shaving soap after the second use and three more after the seventh use. I also made sure to order the stand for the brush & razor after learning how important it is to let the brush dry with the bristles down. I can say that after rinsing the brush, I couldn't detect any unpleasant odors & after the first use, no detectable odor at all. After the brush was completely dry, I noticed it was softer than when it was new. The brush did feel \\"strange\\" on my face but that's likely because I've never used a shaving brush.
  2235. very disappointing the brush spreads outward making it very messy in applying soap- good news is that at least the bristles don't come off the brush but I think they were put in backwards or something == it is not the way other brushes have been for me in the past
  2236. This is a simple but well-executed product. The bristles are thick, soft, and installed into the wooden handle very securely. The instructions are concise but very useful, mainly where maintenance of the brush is concerned.<br /><br />[NOTE TO INTERESTED PARTIES: this brush MUST be stored hanging upside-down or on its side; the flat part of the handle easily supports the brush in an upright position, but if you store it that way after using it, the brush will not only start to get a funky smell but it will fall apart after a short time. This is because the moisture in the brush will pool inside the handle and get musty and damage the adhesive holding the bristles in place.]<br /><br />My only complaint regarding this product is that they don't offer a stand from which to hang the brush upside-down; if they do, I didn't see the option anywhere here on Amazon.<br /><br />All in all, this is a great buy for the price. Most real boar bristle shaving brushes typically cost $30-$50. This is well worth the $13.
  2237. I was disappointed with this brush. I've been using brushes to shave for 40 years and this one doesn't cut it. The bristles have no body to them so by the time I'm done lathering up, all of the bristles are pointed 90 degrees from the handle. I carefully straighten them back up to let them dry, but the next time it is the same thing. My old brush which I'm ready to replace does a much nicer job than this one. I'm returning it and will look for a more substantial brush.

The brush is good quality, it does a good job working up the lather, and softening up the beard. My one disappointment is that the brush is about 25% smaller than what I would have liked- it feels a bit small in the hand and the brush size is equally a bit undersized. Thinking about it- this may result in being able to use less shaving cream to produce a good amount of lather on your face- a bigger brush will retain a lot more of the lather. However, I still would have preferred it a bit bigger.

  2258. I bought this brush as my first, having recently discovered the joys of shaving with a safety razor and brush on shave creams. Took about a week to \\"break in,\\" meaning for the first few days it shed routinely and smelled a bit like a small animal (not a bad smell, but it did smell). After the first week, the brush was extremely comfortable to use, sheds very little, and smells like whatever shave cream I most recently used with it. It's held up very well for several months of daily, rough use, and I even bought my wife one just like it so she could use it with her favorite brush-on shave creams. Rave reviews from both of us. I'll probably spring for a higher end brush at some point, but for now this one is working very well for me.<br /><br />Update: I just dropped my rating for this brush from 4 to 3...bought a new one for the wife, who came out of the bathroom sad a few days ago because the knot had detached from the handle after only 3 uses. Super glue and patience got it working again, but there's no doubt quality is an issue here. Mine is still going strong after 4 months or so, but is losing hairs at an increasing rate per day. My wife's came apart after 3 uses. Kind of a crap shoot. Still a good entry brush, but you get what you pay for.
  2259. I was very happy with this brush. So happy, in fact, I bought two more - one for my son and one for my nephew.
  2260. Many people these days expect the best possible product on the market for a minimum amount of money. This leads to many things, and one is the loss of value. If you're looking for the best possible brush, you're realistically looking at a couple hundred dollars. Here's a nice analogy that describes this brush:<br /><br />You don't walk into a department store and buy a $200 suit and expect the construction and quality of a bespoke suit from Saville Row. You can buy the $200 suit and get a shotty quality fused suit and save a boat-load of money. Or you could shell out well over $2000 for a full bespoke suit that has superb quality and be broke. Every now and again you come across a nice half-canvassed suit with decent quality for around $600. It doesn't break the bank and you get a decent quality suit; the best of both worlds.<br /><br />The half-canvassed suit referenced above is this brush. It's not the best brush on the market, but it is an excellent value for the money you pay. I've been wet-shaving for a while and enjoy luxury shaving items, but the reality is they are very costly. This brush provides me with an excellent wet shave and I didn't break the bank on it. If you're willing to spend more money, spend more money. There's no doubt you'll get a higher quality brush. But if you aren't a shaving enthusiast, you can't go wrong with this brush.

I have three main points as to why I deducted stars.<br /><br />1. The brush is prickly. To be honest it isn't that bad but I am guessing other brushes would be softer.<br />2. Sheds. This brush sheds and continues to do so. I think I typically lose a hair from the brush every use or every other use. It has not affected its performance yet but I am sure at some point it will.<br />3. Does not work as well with actual soaps. The brush worked well with the first two creams I purchased but I just purchased an actual soap so loading the brush is harder. The first time I tried the hairs flattened out and couldn't get any soap on the brush. I then discovered if I support the hairs by grabbing the hairs at the knot then I am able to load the brush with plenty of soap.<br /><br />Not sure if this should be an entire point or not but it feels like the hairs are starting to get weaker. I am not sure if this is a perception issue or if it simply is getting softer(to soft) over time.<br /><br />Final thoughts: If you are on a tight budge, this little guy will get you by until such time you can afford a better brush since this one will not be the last brush you ever buy.

One note: if this is your first time using a brush for shaving, expect your skin to sting a little afterwards (at least compared to using a cream).

  2337. Excellent product and service<br /><br />This shaving brush came extra fast, and has proven to be more than worth what I paid for it.
  2338. Does the job, people complain about the smell of wet badger hair but I actually enjoy it. Maybe I'm just weird.

  2341. At first I really liked the brush. For the price it did a great job and seemed solid. After a month or two I've started to notice bristles in the sink or soap. I'm hoping that this might just be an initial bristle loss, but I'll keep an eye on that and post an update. [Update] After 10 months I need to replace this brush. I lose bristles every time I use it. I take proper care of the brush rinsing it and gently squeezing it (not wringing it) and then hanging it in a stand. The past several shaves the bristle loss has increased and the brush is noticeably less full than when I started using it. Along with the loss of bristles it seems that they have softened too. Honestly for the price you could just plan on replacing it every 6 months, but for now I'll upgrade to a higher quality brush.
  2342. First one so don't know what to compare it to but it works and feels great. I would recommend it.

  2344. Did not know what to expect, but it really works well!!! I would recommend this brush to anyone using a straight razor to shave.

The brush works well, is easy to handle, and feels great on my face. I did notice that there was a slight &#34;wet animal&#34; smell for the first week or so of use -- but honestly, isn't that to be expected in a brush with real natural fibers? I think I'd be more concerned if it DIDN'T have a bit of an odor. Nevertheless, the smell went away after just a few uses. I've had it for about a month now and it seems to be holding up well. I think I've only noticed one or two fibers falling out. I'd recommend anyone give this a try as an &#34;entry level&#34; quality shaving brush.

The smell fades quickly though, and ends up smelling more like the shave soap you use. The only reason this brush doesn't get five stars is because in the first few uses some of the bristles came out, but this is the only brush I've owned so this could just be a normal thing that I am unaware of.

  2402. I purchased this brush after reading all the positive reviews. I've been using a boar hair brush for years and liked it just fine, but since I was getting a new double edge razor I figured I'd go for a new brush too.<br /><br />After using this one a few times I am back to my old boar hair brush. I'm not really sure what all the fuss is about when it comes to badger hair brushes. The bristles flatten out way too easily when your applying cream using very little pressure. So you end up with a pancaked shaped brush with a handle. My old boar hair brush is much stiffer and does not flatten out like this one. I guess if you used real light pressure and babied it the brush would stand up fine, but that is not my style.<br /><br />So this might work fine for you if you use a brush that way, but if you like to be more aggressive when applying your shaving cream this might not be the brush for you. Oh and the bristles were falling out a lot too. I suspect they might stop after more uses, but it was annoying having to shave with bristles stuck to my head.<br /><br />I can't recommend this brush even at the low price point.
  2403. Love it soft and smooth!
  2404. You really can't beat this product for the price. The only improvement I think could be made is weight.   2405. Essentially became only 50% useful after two to three weeks of use, at around 3 days between shaves. First lather on shave soap showed some brown oily residue, I figured since the brush was brand new I would have to break it in, but yet here I am months later and still brown residue coming off bristles. The bristles themselves are very coarse to the skin, especially for those who have sensitive skin and are likely to bleed during a shave. What did it in for me was that after about 6 uses, with typical lather technique, the middle part of the brush (essentially the core of the brush where most lather should be) became depressed into the brush, the bristles became tangled down there and that results in a garbage lather. Lastly, I feel the handle is too small as most of the lather created always drips down. Still using, but only until my Edwin Jagger Best badger brush arrives. You get what you pay for. Since badger brushes are graded by hair, it's like the three little pigs story. Don't start with the hay house (this brush) spend your 16$ and go to the next level.

  2433. I love the brush but it took some getting used to. The handle is very soft and comfortable but could be more rigid. The part that goes against your face is wood, which is unusual.   2434. The brush tips are &#34;scritchy&#34;. They are trimmed and supposedly that means the tips will never soften as they are the thickest part of the hair. I use Proraso green so I don't feel the irritation. I also cannot use it in the swirling motion (which exfoliates better) on my face because of said irritation. So I can only paint the lather on my face for application. Further more I'm still losing one or two hairs every time I make a lather (it's been used for about 40+ shaves), which causes me to not want to use tubs/soaps and instead use creams, so I don't have to fish lost hairs out of my tubs. As I understand a pure badger is usually lower quality than boar. I would recommend a boar or even horse hair brush instead of this (or any pure badger) brush. Hopefully mine stops losing hair or I'll just break down and get a whipped dog silvertip, which can be had for the cost of 3 of these things.
  2435. This brush is great as an entry level shaving brush. Honestly, this should be used only if you're trying to decide whether to switch from a foam (e.g. Gilette) to a brush, as I was. The first shave, I found the bristles very stiff and &#34;poky.&#34; I thought I may be doing it wrong. After some research, I learned that there are three grades to badger brush hair: Pure, Best, Silvertip.<br /><br />Thing is, Pure is meant to be &#34;poky.&#34; It is the stiffest of the grades. That said, after a few more shaves, I actually started to appreciate the feel on my face. It occurred to me that shaving brushes were Man's original exfoliant. Women have creams. Men have brushes. Even so, I still thought it was a tad bit sharp for my test, so eventually I will be opting for a good Best Badger Hair Shaving Brush.<br /><br />In the mean time, for the price and the use I have gotten out of it so far (~3 months) this brush was well worth the price for an introduction into brush lathering.

I expected a bit of shedding at the beginning and I was right, as it did happen. However, eventually the shedding slowed down to no more than about 1 hair every other day, sometimes 1 hair every day. I don't know a lot of about shaving brushes, so take this information with a grain of salt as it's possible that this is normal for them or that it's not going to cause any problems for a long time.
  2455. The brush is inexpensive, decent looking, and works nicely. Some people mention an odor, mine had a slight &#34;badgery&#34; smell the first couple of uses, but this has all but disappeared. It's a good brush. As long as it lasts, I see no need to pay any more than this.

They are just all around better in every way, softer, quicker lather, feels better on the face. Don't waste your money.

The Walgreen's brush has lasted for years. And I don't remember when the last time was I saw a loose bristle. With the Escali brush, on average I lose 30 to 40 bristles during each daily shave. They stick all over the razor, on my face, in the lather, and all over the sink bowl. It's disgusting. The loose bristles interfere with the shaving process and are difficult to remove from the razor. Doesn't matter if you use hot or cold water. Same thing happens. A month later still dropping bristles like crazy. Do not buy this brush, you will be sorry if you do. Will write the seller and request a refund or credit, not sure how that's going to work out.

  2468. Great shaving brush! I find it holds a lot of moisture and is perfect for lathering my face. The badger hair definitely makes a difference. In the past I have bought my husband other shaving brushes made from different material and they did not work as well. I like that you know exactly what the material is because your face is a sensitive area of your body. I also like how they also give you directions on how to maintain its shape. Escali recommends that after using your rinse the brush with water, making sure to remove all of the shaving cream. They also recommend hanging the brush upside down to dry. I saw someone commented that they added a screw in their brush to hook it to hang. This is a great idea. I received this brush at a discounted rate for my honest, unbiased opinion.

  2495. Being new to wet shaving, I had done enough research to determine that I wanted to go with a Badger brush compared to either Boar or Horse hair brushes. It's nearly impossible to find quality shaving products in the retail marketplace. With the amount excellent reviews, and the shear number of reviews, I figured I can't go wrong with this brush. I found the brush to be adequate for the price. There is a slight scent to it, and the bristles are somewhat scratchy - which was expected. What wasn't expected, even for what I assume is a machine made brush, was the amount of hairs that this brush has lost. I soaked it, shampooed it, and brushed the hairs as you are supposed to prior to using it, but i continually get about 10-12 loose hairs during each use. The hairs get in the shave cream and on the face, and presents an (albeit small) obstacle when shaving. You can get a highly regarded quality Boars hair brush like the Semogue 1305 for just a few dollars more, but if you are committed to wet shaving, you might want to go a little bit further and get the Edwin Jagger Best Badger brush. Either of those brushes I feel would be a step up from this one, for not that much more money.

  2521. I would recommend this brush.<br />Here's why:<br /><br />I have three brushes, a very high end Badger brush, a not so expensive badger and this rather inexpensive brush. The second brush is a backup to my best.<br /><br />I purchased this brush for travel knowing that I will eventually leave it somewhere. So I purchased this to lose it. I was very pleasantly surprised that for 12 bucks I could get an very acceptable brush. In fact, the Badger hair is a bit firmer than my more expensive one and so this one provides a more vigorous application of shaving soap. It also helps whip up the lather better. The firmness feels quite nice on my face where others have said it \\"scratches\\". I disagree, but understand why they may think that.<br /><br />The brush holds water nicely, drys nicely, and holds soap perfect.<br /><br />Why not 4 stars? Two reasons. First, the weight is very light, ideal for travel but I like a heavier brush. So it's a personal preference. The second reason is that it loses hairs pretty easily. I know this will end after more use, but a brush should not lose more than a few a shave. In the early going, of this brush produced way too many in the sink. It seems to continuing losing them as I continue using it. So I might lose the brush, the badger may escape on it's own.<br /><br />Would these two detract from me recommending this? No way. In my humble opinion, this brush is exactly what I need for travel. It also is perfectly priced for my absentmindedness. It will be lost, and I won't care. Unlike my primary, and very expensive brush, this one is cheap and priced nearly as if it was disposable.<br /><br />My main point is that the brush works and is inexpensive. If it were my main brush, I'd would not enjoy shaving as much, but on the road it is perfectly acceptable, temporary solution.<br /><br />Enjoy

Yet review after review stated that the VHD soap was indeed fine. Far from the best, but not bad for the price. I finally decided to try a budget badger brush which brought me to the Escali shaving brush. It is like night and day compared to my previous VHD boar bristle shaving brush. I have no problems getting a thick lather using the VHD soap. I highly recommend this brush for anyone getting started with the classic shave or for an extra travel brush. Badger brushes like this are known to create the lather quicker than other types of brushes, which is a plus when you're using it regularly and can't spend a long time making lather (such as when you have to get to work). I typically do 20 circle swipes to get the soap on the brush, then it takes another minute of applying the brush to the beard to get an adequate lather. There is usually enough for two passes when used this way.

Therefore I invested in a German razor, the Escali shaving brush, and a jar of sensitive shaving cream that lasts quite a bit longer than the canned foam. I gave the brush five stars because it's soft and spreads the shaving cream well. The Escali shaving brush also keeps it's shape, and of course it's recommended to rinse it out and hang it up each shave so it drys thoroughly for the next shave. I bought a stand to hold the razor and brush. The brush then hangs upside down for maximum drying time. I believe this product will last for years. I also purchased a traveling case for the brush and razor. I am very satisfied with each shave. This is a 5 star product.

I use it primarily with Taylor of Old<br />Bond Street shaving cream. Expect it to be a bit stiff at first, at least for the beginning 5 or 6 shaves.<br />After that the badger hair softens a bit and you can feel the difference.<br /><br />Expect some shedding at first, it's normal. I have not as of yet purchased a stand in which to let it dry.<br />i just get the excess water out and lay it on it's side,no problems with that so far. Be sure to grab the base<br />of the hair and not the handle of the brush as you flick it. I've notice the brush has achieved a nice thick blossom<br />I enjoy shaving quite a bit now. Sure, it's not as expensive as other brushes but i have no doubt it can hold it's<br />own with any other brushes with their fancy bells and whistles. A great buy for beginners. Highly recommend.<br />I intend to buy another one for my traveling kit.
  2727. Bought this brush as a gift for my boyfriend and he loves it. It arrived quickly too, which I appreciated :)
  2728. Purchased as a gift. Dad said he likes it.

  2730. First noticed it has a funky smell when applying C.O. Bigelow shave cream. It isn't the cream, I've applied it by hand and it smells great.<br />It does do a great job lathering the cream on my face.<br />But and this it the reason for the low rating, it sheds tons on of bristles on the cream on my face, I had to go pick them off. It sheds even more when you rinse it and give it a light shake to get the water out. There were 40+ bristles in the sink and just as many hanging out of the brush. I am not sure if this is a one time thing, but it must be 10% of the hairs out of the brush after just one use. Might be a defective brush or just a really crappy product. But not worth driving to the shipping store to return it.<br /><br />Buyer beware! Do not by this brush!!!
  2731. I got this brush because I wanted to try out wet shaving, but didn't want to spend a ton of money to see if it was something I wanted to do long term or not. I used it for every shave for about a 8 month period, and it served me well. After 8 months or so, it started to shed bristles pretty regularly, and I just decided to upgrade to a nicer brush.<br /><br />If you are looking to try out using a bush and wet shaving, but don't want to drop a few hundred bucks on all of the nicest gear, this is a great brush for you to get stated with.<br /><br />If you are looking for a fine brush to pass down to your kids...and you think you can get it at this price point... you probably shouldn't be having kids. ;)<br /><br />It did just what I needed it to do, and I feel like I got my $'s worth out of it.
  2732. Great little brush they got here. I have had it for 3 months now, using it every day and from the getgo i haven't seen many bristles falling out at all. One word of caution though, the entire brush head did fall off though. It was still all glued together, but it popped out of the body. I did a quick fix by throwing some epoxy on it and sticking it back it so it didnt bother me at all. Still working great. For the price I would absolutely recommend it. Gets a great lather going for me.

  2757. I would bet dollars to donuts that the people giving this brush good reviews simply have not experienced better brushes. This brush is just awful. It's not soft, it's actually quite prickly and does not soften after being broken in. A good badger hair brush (even pure badger which is the lowest grade badger hair brush) should soften significantly after 10-20 shaves. This brush is just as prickly after 50 shaves as it was on day one. It sheds an unacceptable amount. A good badger hair brush should lose approximately 5-10 hairs in the first 5 shaves and then only the occasional errant hair every once in a while. This brush sheds 5-10 hairs per shave. Do not trust reviews from people who don't know better. For the same price, get a boar hair brush from Omega or Semogue. If you're dead set on a badger hair brush you'll need to spend more money to get a quality product.
  2758. The brush came on time and it works well. It's my first time shaving with a brush, so I'm still getting the hang of it. But this seems like a good product.
  2759.
