Since then, none have come out, and I have used the brush several more times. It works well for anyone how wet shaves, and wants to decrease razor burn by preparing your skin for a blade to slide on it.<br /><br />This is really more of a $25-30 brush at less than half the price...and the reason I shop on Amazon. At first I thought that only the loose hairs were falling out and that after a while It would stop, but no, I have had it for months and every morning more hairs fall out. This complet ruins the brush for me, and I am buying another, more expensive one.
  2851. Got this as a beginner shaving brush. The bristles comes off every time i shave. But I guess I will invest more in a shaving brush next time. For now this is a good brush for beginners.

  2867. I was convinced to purchase this brush by the &#34;outstanding&#34; reviews and of course the price. I must have got the only defective one ever produced. I have been shaving with a brush for over 55 years and I wound up so disgusted after 4 weeks of use, I threw it in the garbage. First, it started to shed the hairs and continued to do so for 4 weeks. The biggest problem was there were not enough hairs left and they were too soft. The brush was not stiff enough. When lathering your face, you were rubbing the wooden handle against your skin because the too few hairs were splayed sideways against your face. Consequently not much shaving cream was being left on the skin. A very frustrating experience and my first disappointment from Amazon.

  2881. Recently a friend of mine bought two-bladed disposable razors at the store. \\"Two bladed?\\" I thought, \\"Ouch!\\" When I asked why, he mentioned that he was transitioning to an old school non-disposable razor because that's what his father used to use. He was working up to using a straight razor like his granddaddy had used.<br /><br />Right now there's a fever for manliness*. Whether it's in the form of Ron Swanson, Mr. Rogers, Ronald Reagan, or Teddy Roosevelt, people want to feel self-reliant and they want to smell like the good old days when you had to walk to school uphill both ways. Nowhere is this more apparent than in the growing popularity of the barbershop cult.<br /><br />My two-bladed friend and I were perusing Amazon, looking for the shaving products he wanted, and he showed me a soap he particularly liked. As soon as he was gone I bought the soap. I knew he had his father's razor but did not have a suitable brush. Part of the self-reliance mindset is buying items of quality while taking your budget into consideration; given these parameters I found a few brushes made of quality materials within my price range, but the Escali 100% Pure Badger Shaving Brush had the best reviews. Not only was it made of durable, natural materials, but also the bristles were 100% pure badger hair-- the most frequently recommended bristle material for an old-timey shave. Even better, they do not shed as they would in cheaply constructed brushes. This is the kind of brush will last. The quality is outstanding.<br /><br />When the Amazon box arrived, I gave it to my friend. He opened it, found the soap he'd been wanting, and thanked me. \\"Keep going,\\" I said. \\"There's something else inside.\\" When he pulled out the brush his eyes widened. He turned the box to view it from every angle. \\"Badger hair,\\" he breathed reverently. \\"Do you know how long this will last? I can't believe you spent that much on me.\\" Thanks to this shop, I didn't spend that much money at all,and every penny was worth it for the tears in my friend's eyes (he probably just had something in his eyes, of course, like TEARS) and the satisfaction of knowing that he has a quality brush that will serve him for many, many years.<br /><br />I'd like to mention the politeness and punctuality of the shop vendors. As someone who has experienced unannounced months-long back orders and excuses from some shops, I appreciate being left alone but for polite updates letting me know that my item is in the mail, and quickly, too. These vendors are personable and although I'm being sent a form letter update, they manage to make it seem personal and respectful.<br /><br />Fans of The Art of Manliness will probably like this brush. Gents, or hey-- ladies-- who want to return to wet shaving, the double-edge safety razor and shaving brush: This is the real deal. Badger hair. Affordable. Perfect size. Does not shed. Want to get back to basics? Want that rugged, clean WWI balanced budget feeling? Go for the combination of quality and economy in this brush. Make every morning shave feel like something Indiana Jones would do.<br /><br />*Nota bene: I'd like to point out that the fever for \\"manliness\\" should more properly be thought of as a fever for self-reliance, integrity, and discipline, but \\"The Art of Self-Reliance, Integrity, and Discipline\\" sounds a bit punitive for a light-hearted popular website, I suppose. All the same, you can't argue with the cool factor of anyone that shaves with a brush and straight razor.

  2905. After having shaved with only an electric razor for over 30 years, a few years ago I decided to try blade shaving again, using the wet shaving method. I've been slowly moving towards &#34;upping my game&#34; by using better shaving products as I find them. Upon hearing about and ordering an awesome shaving cream (Duke Cannon Superior Grade Shaving Cream), I figured the next step would be a shaving brush. Doing some research led me to bristle brushes.<br /><br />Enter Escali. I found brushes ranging from $20-$250 and everywhere in between. I wanted an introductory brush at a reasonable price and Escali seemed to fit the bill. I read all the reviews, both good and bad, then ordered. I'm no expert at using a bristle brush, this being my first foray, but the Escali Badger Brush works perfectly well. It does exactly as it says, builds up a nice foam/lather, covers well/evenly, feels good, etc.<br /><br />** UPDATE ** - I'm leaving this original review info in place for full disclosure/historical purposes, but *please* read my update at the bottom, about the scent being gone.<br /><br />The one biggest criticism I read here is about the scent of the brush when it's wet. OK, so yes it does have a mild scent. BUT, I have found the following to be true:<br /><br />- The scent is strongest when the brush is used for the first time<br />- It only lasts while you're shaving and does not &#34;stick&#34; to you<br />- You can use hair shampoo on the brush to help eliminate the residual scent<br />- The scent *does* decrease over time - and I've only used it a few times. If I really wanted to make a concerted effort, I could shampoo/rinse it a bunch of times in a row, but it just doesn't bother me enough to do so.<br /><br />Keep in mind, folks, that MAYBE if they doubled the cost of the brush, they could deliver one with ZERO scent; maybe.<br /><br />Let me close by saying that the scent thing is really No Big Deal; I merely included the info above to give a full & complete review, not glossing over anything. But at the end of the day (and the review), let me leave you with these final Q&A points:<br /><br />Q: Do I like the brush?<br />A: Yes<br /><br />Q: Do I enjoy using it?<br />A: Definitely - it does exactly what I need, and quite well<br /><br />Q: Would I buy it again?<br />A: YES!<br /><br />** Update ** 03/05/2016: TWO Major Points:<br /><br />1. The scent is essentially GONE from their new brushes. Whatever Escali has done, they practically eliminated that &#34;scent&#34; which people talked about a few years ago. There's nothing noticeable when it's wet, unless you stick your nose INSIDE of the brush and inhale deeply, and even then, it's barely there. Plus, **NOTHING** comes off on your skin. Nice job, Escali! You got rid of the one major complaint.<br /><br />2. I liked this brush so much, that after we bought some special Basin shaving cream for our 17-year-old son, I bought him his first Escali Badger Shaving Brush, and HE loves it, too. Says that it makes shaving more pleasant and even a little fun, which is saying a lot, coming from a teen. Now, you have two different generations who both enjoy Escali's product.

  2913. I have been using this brush for about three weeks. It works quite well in stimulating my beard to 'stand up' for shaving. Some have said they like to let it soak with in the soap mug with hot water for a bit before using in order to soften the bristles. I actually prefer the bristles to be firm and stiff allowing them to get in and prop those beard hairs up a bit. Now, when this brush first arrived, it did have the smell of badger hair. It was pretty strong, but not overly offensive. After three weeks of usage, the smell has dissipated and I mostly smell the scent of the shaving soap I use. On the matter of bristle leakage, yes, every other shaving session, a bristle may fall out. That is to be expected. But, by properly rinsing, squeegeeing, and hanging the brush handle-up via stand, this brush should last for a long time.

  2952. Does the job but hairs keep coming out. Worth the price. :: 08/26/2015, I have to update this review and change it to 5 stars. Even the best paint brush ($30 to 50.00) will loose a bristle now and then. Way to go Naomi. ~Rick
  2953. This is my first brush, having received it in February, when I first started DE shaving. Having nothing to compare it to, I will give my general opinions. It whips up a real nice lather, which can be controlled easily by adding water or cream to make a perfect ratio if at first you don't succeed. That being said, I am still getting stray hairs which come out in every shave. It doesn't bother me, but it's a little discouraging, having owned this brush for seven months, to continue to get the stray hairs. Other than that I love this brush.
  2954. Essential tool for a great traditional wet shave.
  2955. This is a quality shaving brush with a light weight feel and great bristle strength which leads to an excellent shaving experience. I love this brush and glad I made the investment!
  2956. Good quality, good pricing. I decided on the Escali because of the many reviews. You can't beat the price and the product, that while simplistic in nature, it does it's work. I use the Proraso shave soap, and this brush creates a good deal of lather/foam. You must remember to clean lightly, don't be rough when cleaning it. And let it dry on it's side or get a brush stand. Never leave facing up to dry.<br /><br />The brush may shed a couple of bristles once in a while. And it may have a &#34;funny&#34; smell... it's from a real animal. The smell goes away considerably with use. The saving soap, whichever you use, will mask any brush smell. By the way, the brush smell will not stick with you or your face.<br /><br />Great product, recommended.

  2966. Is this the best shaving brush I've ever seen? No - and it's not trying to be at this price. The brush is not nearly as scratchy as hog bristle, nor did the smell of badger linger on the brush after is was washed. It has shed a few individual hairs, but nothing that I wouldn't expect from all but the most expensive brushes. I've shaved with it for about a week, and i have no complaints. When I opened the package and first soaked it in hot water, it smelled like hot badger booty, but after a little soap and a rinse, the smell is all but gone. Mostly I just smell shaving soap. Overall I feel I got more than I paid for.

  2968. I recently left my Art of Shaving (lower end) brush in a hotel room and needed one quick. If you want a proper wet shave, start with a brush that costs around $60. They do get much more expensive, but that is the necessary starting point. I assure you it is a world of difference.

  3061. In the interest of full disclosure, I think it's important for me to admit that my original review of this brush was only three stars. The brush I received had several coarse hairs noticeable on first inspection. The brush had a fairly strong odor to it, and the first several rinses resulted in a filthy brackish water pouring from it. After a thorough cleaning, the brush functioned fine, and I reported as much. My review was not overly harsh, but it was honest. A day later, I was contacted by a representative of the supplier, Perella's. The CSR expressed regret that I had been unhappy with their product and offered to send me a replacement for free. My replacement brush has since arrived and proved to be much cleaner and had fewer coarse hairs apparent. The new brush returns reliably to original shape and builds excellent lather. It has a slight odor to it, but this is the case for several other natural badger hair brushes that I have tried as well. Altogether I think this is an excellent value for the price, you could easily spend three times as much or more for a shaving brush from some other companies that would not be significantly better than the Escali. I think it's fair to say that Perella's went above and beyond in this instance; I did not submit any complaint to them directly, nor did I offer a terrible review, but they still reached out to me in an effort to make me happy. So this review is half for the actual brush, and half for the seller. I am impressed by a small company willing to go out of their way to provide excellent customer service and a quality product at an affordable price.
  3062. After about 6 months of daily use, I've only lost a few bristles. Soft feel, easy to clean and dry.
  3063. Excellent low cost yet high quality badger hair shaving brush. The softness of the badger hair allows for an almost relaxing shaving (are there people who actually like to shave every other day?!) experience.
  3064. The Escali Badger Bristle shaving brush is a welcome tool to my grooming arsenal as I need all the help I can get. When armed with some warm water, a decent hunk of shaving soap in my surplus mug, and a proper blade, I have no doubt that the goal of a clean, close and comfortable shave will be met. It's a bit of a comfort knowing that in addition to the sheer enjoyment of using the brush with its good robust bristles in play after tuning up with the aforementioned warm water enervated lather, at the end of the day I also will find this an economical way to stay in the game. Only the best.
  3065. I have this product for just a short time but I am very impressed. When used in conjunction with a nice safety razor; I purchased a Merkur &#34;1904&#34; 42C, nice blades; I purchased Astra Super Premium Platinum Double and a nice shaving cream, you will get the best shave of your life. As a reference point when I say that, I started shaving in the 1960s and experienced the horrors of the old Gillette Blue Blades. This product is very high quality and has a nice price point. You can always pay more, but if you're just putting your toe in the water for this type of a shave, no need to drop a king's ransom. For those who are considering moving over to a wet shaving system here is a nice tutorial link: http://www.gentlemansgazette.com/double-edge-razor-guide-de/.

  3082. Badger brushes... why on earth would I ever need that? That's what I always thought as a boy of 23 years old. Then, on my 24th birthday, my Opa buys me a badger brush.<br /><br />Why? I asked my Opa (yes we're german).<br />He says to me, BOY! BECOME A MAN! SHAVE LIKE A MAN!<br /><br />So, as a crying child of 24, I went upstairs to the washroom and proceeded to shave my face using the badger brush. The way it felt in my had felt oddly right, like it was ment to be there. The warm water rushed across the brush as it dampened. The way it magically turned the shaving soap into a nice thick lather. The prickly, smooth feel against my skin and I slid it across my face.<br /><br />I knew then as I know now, I had taken a huge step to becoming a real man. Sadly it was not until I purchased my safety razor that I had truly become a man. But atleast on my birthday I felt like I almost was. There might have even been a slight twinkle in my Opa's eyes when I came downstairs with a shockingly smooth face.

  3114. This is BY FAR the cheapest 100% badger brush of high quality available on Amazon. I'm sure there's a slightly higher quality brush out there selling for 50 or 60 dollars - but at $13.00, this brush is really excellent.<br /><br />Be forewarned: You WILL, consistently, get stray badger hairs on your face and hands the first 5 or 10 times you shave with this brush. However, a month later using this brush and I consistently get perfectly whipped lather and only very occasionally do I get a stray badger hair on my face.<br /><br />TAKE CARE OF THIS BRUSH: get a cheapy plastic brush stand (4.25 plus shipping on ebay), and keep your brush on it whenever its not in your hand. Thoroughly rinse out your brush and squeeze out the soap, then shake it out til it's good and bushy, then hang it up and you're good.

  3141. This is a great Badger hair brush that is great for anyone trying to upgrade their shaving experience. I bought this with the Marvy Shaving Mug and Proraso shaving cream. There are a few things you should know about this brush:<br />1) This is real badger hair and will smell when you first get it wet! To get around this I washed it with Johnson's baby shampoo a few times until it was tolerable to use, and the smell went away after a few uses. I found this also helped get rid of some of the loose hairs.<br />2) You want to get a bowl that is wide enough for your fingers and deep enough that the lather won't splash around.<br />I found that this brush was compatible with the Escali Deluxe Chrome Razor and Brush Stand. It takes a minute or two to work up a nice lather, and feels great on your face while you shave. For the first two uses there was a slight &#34;prickle&#34;, but it didn't bother me and completely went away after 3 days.<br /><br />Overall, this is a very inexpensive brush that is great to use or give as a gift. It will tremendously improve your shaving experience and greatly facilitated my transition into wet shaving.

  3161. This is my first shaving brush, so I don't have anything to compare it to. A few things that I noticed:<br /><br />It's smaller than I expected, but gets the job done well (I like the size).<br />The bristles feel good, and are soft<br />Shedding - this did shed a decent amount over the first few uses, but now it's just the occasional hair here or there.<br /><br />Make sure that you store it vertically, with the bristles hanging down. You want to thoroughly rinse it after every use, then put it in a stand to dry. This will extend the useful life of the brush, and help prevent premature shedding/rotting.<br /><br />When mine wears out, I will most likely buy another one of these.
  3162. This brush is definitely an upgrade over the cheap low-quality drugstore brush I had been using. I can get a nice thick lather with this brush, and it feels good to use.   3166. I bought this to replace a synthetic I had. The price was tempting so I opted to start with this instead of the $30 brushes (or more). It feels much softer than synthetic and and lathers nicely, one difference I notice with the badger hair than the synthetic is it absorbs water MUCH more, so you really gotta soak it to get the soap wet. This allows the soap to fill up the brush more as well so you can really lather up your face.<br /><br />The brush does have an odd smell, not sure if it's normal badger smell or just exclusive to this brush as I've never had another badger hair brush before (or smelt a badger!). But it's nothing bad or potent, just noticeable compared to no smell, also you won't smell anything once it's covered in soap.<br /><br />The bristles started falling immediately, stuck in the soap dish and fell into the sink during rinsing. I think this is normal first-use wear out of a badger brush as I only lightly whipped up the soap (I'm sure pricier brushes lose less though). No significant amount of hairs have been lossed, and very few if any fall out now that it's broken in.<br /><br />Overall for the price, it's nice, especially if it's your first brush or need a spare travel to not worry to much about if you lose it. I'll probably upgrade eventually, but this should last me a while with proper care.
  3167. Brush feels great, is affordable and actually looks more pleasant than other brushes in the same price range! Will definitely be buying a couple of these as gifts for my fellow wet-shaving buddies
  3168. This is a very nice brush while it lasted. I bought the shaving brush on November 30, 2014 and on March 9, 2015 the bristles separated from the handle. I was surprised to see that the bristles didn't extend that far into the handle; they're just seated in glue. Apparently the glue gave way and now the bristles have separated, en masse, from the handle. I was careful with this brush and always hung it upside down when wet. Very disappointed. UPDATE: A little glue from the hot glue gun and I'm back in business. I get a great lather with this brush with Proraso from the tube.
  3169. Decent shave brush but is still losing bristles after 6 months of use,
  3170. Works well to create a rich lather.
  3171. So far I'm enjoying my escali brush. I owned a cheaper quality brush before this one and I'm very glad I switched. I've lost a few hairs the first time I shaved but haven't since. Which is to be expected. It holds water very well and lathers quite a bit even without tons a shaving soap. I did notice the water turned a little brown when I rinse bur I'm sure that will stop after a few more shaves. I haven't noticed any smell from it like some of the of the other reviews. Honestly I'm extremely pleased with this brush. I'll update this review if anything changes.
  3172. It smells like a wild animal. I thought the smell would go away but it hasn't. I will be buying a new brush.
  3173. Bought a Parker silver tip and I like this escali better. Not too &#34;fluffy&#34; and bushy. Good buy.
  3174. I wasn't sure what to expect upon ordering this brush. I had ordered it without even looking at the reviews, because at the time I was inexperienced with Amazon and didn't think to look.<br />Now, however, I must agree with most of the reviews in saying that this brush works wonders for its price. It smells like wet badger when it's wet (the scent fades a bit after use), but what else is to be expected? The bristles are of medium stiffness, so it still forces soap into your whiskers, but doesn't irritate your skin.<br />As with most of the other users, I have lost my fair share of bristles; more during the first few uses than after. I usually lose about 1 per shave currently, although I'm sure that will become less as time goes by. As with any tool, take care of it and it will take care of you. I dry mine upside down on the counter, wedged between a wall and the case it comes in (for about 1 day).<br />Good product. If you need a brush and are on a budget, get this. You won't be sorry.
  3175. Hands down best brush I have ever owned, it is very soft on the skin, but strong enough to create thick foam.
  3176. I have only used the brush once but thought I would go ahead and write a review. This is my first shaving brush and everything that I read made it clear a badger hair brush is the way to go. I've seen a lot of other brushes made of a lot of other material but I've passed them by regardless of price because I wanted to get one brush and love it. I found one badger hair brush that was about half the size of this brush which, by the way, is probably a standard size brush which is a good size to me. so don't assume all brushes are the same size. The badger hair bristles did feel good on my face. I think I'm not using very good soap so although I can't blame the brush for the amount of lather I got. It was enough to shave comfortably, but my face did not look like it was covered in Cool Whip. After rincing the soap out of the brush, I noticed that the water was cloudy, almost brown. I don't think the brush was dirty or there was badger poop in the water, but I'm guessing there is a breaking in period for the brush. After shaving a couple strokes I rinsed my razor out and noticed that I had apparently grown badger hair because that's partly what rinsed out of my razor. Again, I'm sure there's a breaking in period and those loose hairs will get worked out. I'm sure I'll be happy with this brush for a long time and after looking at all the brushes and brush sets I think I chose the best one for the price. Rather than purchase a shaving brush stand I nailed a little picture frame holder to the side of my medicine cabinet and put a screw eye into the handle of the brush so I can hang the brush from the side of the medicine cabinet. It would have been nice if the packaging was a little more interesting or even included tip sheet on shaving.
  3177. Following a few simple care suggestions and it seems to do OK. Loses a hair once in a while but it isn't falling apart by any sense. Rinse, hold brush bristles together and give it a shake, hang in stand. Easy.

Not really but it's just as good as some of the $20.00-$30.00 brushes sold out there. For those complaining about losing hairs, all brushes lose hair upon first use, my Kent BK8 which many would consider a top of the line brush shed hair the first few weeks, these brushes have literally thousands of badger hairs of course they will shed in the beginning. It's a beginners shaving brush for under $15.00; it works pretty good and would make a fine travel brush when a more high end brush would replace it at home. For those complaining about quality and smell I would have to ask what exactly do you expect for this kind of money.

  3283. I've gotten 6 months of good service from this brush, and I can't see how much more I could get out of one costing $100 or more. I've read a few complaints about several other less expensive brushes, and I really think the issues users had (bristle loss) are because they're not soaking the brush in water for several minutes before they shave. After 6 months I see a bristle from time to time, but that's all. It lathers the cream, and puts it onto your face before you shave, and it does a decent job of it. Just soak it in hot water to assure it's fully hydrated before using. I think you should also let it dry it hanging upside down.

  3292. Arrived quickly from the seller, just as described. It's a good brush for the price, builds a very good lather with a little work. I have not noticed the musky odor that some others have noted.
  3293. I have used this brush daily for a couple of weeks, and I am very happy. Being new to wet shaving I first made the mistake buying a boar brush at the local drug store. Don't buy boar! Boar belongs in hair brushes, not shaving brushes. The boar was stiff and hard even after soaking in hot water for a few minutes. This brush, costing only 3-4 dollars more, was a spectacular upgrade. Whips up a nice fluffy lather in no time and then applies the lather softly. I first soak the brush for a few minutes in a small ceramic bowl in really hot water (tea pot hot water). Then I pour the water out and shake excess water from the brush, not all. I quirt maybe 3/4 of inch of Proraso cream [...] into the bowl and whip it up. Ready to go. The ceramic bowl retains the heat well so the lather stays nice and hot. After use I rinse out the brush in running hot water and let it dry hanging down (handle up) so the water doesn't pool in the handle. There was some very light shedding, a handful of bristles maybe, the first time I used it, but that was it.
  3294. The brush is full and lightweight without feeling cheap. It is just the right weight for agility and control. I have used it a lot - and in fact, abused it a bit - and the bristles, shape, and finish hold up well.<br /><br />Initially I thought this would be a starter brush for me until I saved up for something more fancy. Having used this brush and travelled with it, I do not plan on trading it in for a different brush. This does everything I need and looks and feels much more expensive than it costs. Not only did it end up being a great brush, it also ended up being a wise investment.
  3295. Ordered two of these and they are nice. You'll loose a few bristles the first couple of times you use them, that's normal. Nice wood handle, nice feel to the bristles
  3296. I carefully checked over this brush comparing it to others. I settled for thi escali badger hair brush ,and I could not be happier.the hair is just the right stiffness, add lathers up very good. I use proroso shave soap , ( the tube type ) thiis is great stuff. after wetting the brush i squeez out approx. 1/2 &#34; to 3/4&#34; proroso onto brush and lather my face. you could repeat this lathering 4 times easy without adding anymore proroso . just keep squeezing the escali brush between your thumb and fore finger. this produces lots of lather. Im very satisfied. thanks amazon.

  3301. This Badger Shaving Brush is replacing a Boar Bristle one and it is much better. I never had a Badger Brush and now I would not go back to any artificial or natural Boar type. The price is great.
  3302. It's stiff but not too scratchy, lifts hairs, and lathers soap well. I would recommend for daily use. Initially lost a few hairs at first use (~50?) but has stopped shedding since then. Used for about a month daily now and no damage to wood handle. Store it bristle down. Don't stand on end.
  3303. There's no substitute for badger bristles, in the soap or on the face. The Escali 100% pure badger bristle shaving brush fulfills it's purpose and at the best price available. A few lost bristles is my only complaint, and only while breaking it in. Step up from synthetic - buy an Escali.
  3304. This brush offers an amazing value. The price is minimal compared to the quality shave this brush helps to provide. A worthwhile investment, and this brush from this seller is the best value out there.
  3305. So first the good: sharp, pointy bristles produce a nice thick lather and the price is right. Now the bad: this thing smells like a wet badger! Seriously, it reeks when it gets wet! If you enjoy smelling like a wet badger, you will LOVE this brush!
  3306. I've had this brush for about six months now. It replaces an Art of Shaving Badger brush that mysteriously disappeared. The Escali is very similar to my old brush; it loses a lot of hairs at first. This lasts a month or so and then you don't lose as many. It also takes a couple weeks a breaking in until it starts producing its best lather.<br /><br />The biggest drawback that I see is the wooden handle. The finish is starting to chip on my brush. Now, keep in mind, I don't hang my brush upside down, like recommend. I dry it as best I can and then lay it on its side. With that being said, I knew what I was getting into when I purchased the brush.<br /><br />Overall, I like it. I've purchased a second one for my brother, if that tells you anything.
  3307. Considering how damn expensive and fancy these brushes get, I want to point out that this brush is an exceptional value. The quality of the bristles are great - it creates a nice rich lather and are just rough enough to exfoliate the skin. If dried properly (hanging freely upside down) the bristles dry perfectly resulting in a nice bloom effect. The wood handle is easy to hold and looks nice. Although it can be a bit on the small end in larger hands, it is good enough for me. The \\"escali\\" name on the front leads one to believe it's an Italian product, however I'm not sure this is in fact true as there is no indication on the product page or on the product itself as to where it's manufactured. So, it may be \\"made in china\\" but whatever - a badger is a badger no matter what the country. Enjoy this brush and be proud of yourself for not wasting upwards of $50 on something else.
  3308. I've used the brush twice, and it is shedding like crazy. It's got a very strong chemical smell which has faded a little after washing it a few times. Otherwise it's soft, and works up a good lather. I wouldn't purchase again. Update: I was contacted by the company after posting my first review. I was sent a replacement free of charge. The replacement is great. The quality is excellent, and it does not shed. There is no chemical smell either. I'm very satisfied with this brush, and much more satisfied with Perella's customer service.

  3365. First of all, the smell. Yes it smells like a wet dog at first, but it goes away quickly and is honestly not that bad. Even a mild shave cream or soap will cover the smell for the first couple of uses till it goes away. At least you know it's real badger hair!!!<br /><br />At first the brush was a little rough on my face and lost a number of bristles for the first week or so and picking them out of the shave soap was very annoying. After the first week however it softened up considerably and I rarely lose any bristles now. Using circular motions creates more of an exfoliating feeling from the brush while up/down or back/forth motions feel really soft and produce a wonderful lather with my Proraso Shave Soap. If you want to break in the brush quickly you can always mix up some lather on the brush and let it sit overnight, rinse well in the morning and it should be much softer.<br /><br />I have noticed some discoloration of the wood around the knot (where the bristles meet the handle), as well wear around the top edge of the handle, as if the finish is wearing off, not sure how the brush will hold up long term but I didn't buy it expecting it to last forever.<br /><br />I would recommend this brush for anyone starting with DE shaving, or just looking for something cheap.

  3399. This is probably a good brush for the price, especially since it's the first one I bought and I wasn't ready to shell out more money for something nicer until I had the hang of things. The smell eventually dissipated. I expected to lose a few hairs on the first few uses but the brush is still shedding hair after a month and a half of daily use. They get all over the sink and stuck to my face. I'm not sure how long the brush will last at this rate. I'm also having a difficult time working a lather up with it, which may be user error but also seems to be a design issue. After lathering the brush in my hand or in a cup, there's shaving cream in it but it doesn't transfer well to my face. All of the shaving cream seems to move to the outside of the brush rather than the tips of the bristles. If I strip the bristles with my fingers there's plenty of shaving cream but if I rub it on my skin the lather doesn't really do much. Maybe denser bristles would help move the soap from the area where the hair meets the handle to the end of the bristles. I guess I'll find out when I buy my second, hopefully better, shaving brush.

  3409. It had been more than 30 years from my last experience with a DE razor, when i decided to give wet shaving a shot again. When i got it I made a couple of batches of lather to see how well the soap foamed. I would recommend the same to anyone who has a new brush. It helps get rid of a lot of the loose hairs. By my third shave, it stopped shedding hair. By the end of the second week of use you could see a nice bloom shape on the dried brush. I have used it to lather my face directly and used a bowl. It worked very well in both instances. While I am curious as to why someone would $50+ for a bush and how it would feel on my face, I would spend the money on something else. I have been using it for 2 months now and am very happy with the value i got with this brush.

  3417. After purchasing the Escali as my daily shaving brush, I pulled it out and noticed that the badger hairs in a few areas had bound together in clumps. I realized that this was glue that had traveled up past the handle into the hairs. I had to use a flathead screw driver to break apart the excess glue among the hairs. The brush barely lathered before that fix. My item may have been a one off quality control problem. After the fix, the brush works fine, other than the glue problem I have no complaints on its performance. The brush has shed a bit of hairs but that is to be expected in this price point. I would recommend it as a starter brush, but there are alot of other options in this range.
  3418. This is my first animal hair brush. I had used a couple of synthetic brushes. not sure if i notice much difference between real and synthetic but this is a good brush for a good price.
  3419. Good product,, Arrived when stated,<br />Quality of brush is good<br />Would have been better if it included a stand, as has to be left upside down to dry

I have heard that storing a brush with the bristles facing up like that can significantly shorten its life, so bare that in mind.<br /><br />Overall this has been an excellent purchase and a good price

I rated this brush with a 5-star rating only because of how well it works.<br />. . . . . . . . . . .<br />However, the bristles still had the dirty wild animal grime in them and I had to use a concoction of boiling water with borax, washing soda, dish soap and 91% rubbing alcohol. When I did this, the watery concoction of cleaner turned a dirty dark brown, like poo-water. The smell was that of a dirty badger. I've skinned them before so I know. I had to change the watery cleaning concoction three times to get the smell out, until the water stayed clear. Then rinsed it well.<br />Now that the brush is actually clean, the smell is completely gone and it works like magic.<br />Imagine what would have happened if I had taken it straight to my face from the package.   3529. This shaving brush is exactly what is described. It is dense enough to do the job, but still a little soft. At first it has a bit of a smell (wet badger?), and also in the beginning it stains the soap a little bit tan/brown. Being a natural product, I was not surprised or taken aback, and now it is odor-free and does not stain.<br /><br />I like the handle, but almost wish it could have been made from something completely impervious to water...plastic, maybe?   3549. I bought this brush as a replacement for my old, boar's hair brush, and I have to say this makes all the difference. It's pretty soft after you use it a few times and the wooden handle seems to not be affected by the water if you let it sit in there for a few minutes while soaking the bristles pre-shave status.<br /><br />So what I did was I bought the Taylor of Old Bond Street Sandalwood shaving cream when I bought this. I soaked these bristles for a few minutes, then I put some of that shaving cream on the end and lathered it up. I added a bit of water to my cup and let the bristles sit in the soapy water for about an hour or so. I don't know if this is how you get that last little bit of animal scent out of your brush, but it worked for me.<br /><br />You might lose a few bristles out of this brush for your first few shaves, but I've used it about seven or eight times in the month that I've had it and mine seemed to stop shedding after like four uses. Cheap and nice, can't ask for more than that.
  3550. I bought this for my fiance for Christmas and he really likes it. Just make sure you wash it with soapy water before you use it.
  3551. This was the first badger shave brush I purchased when I started wet shaving. After using it for several months, I purchased a more expensive best badger brush. The best badger brush is slightly softer and more absorbent, but it was also 4X the price of the Escali Pure Badger. Overall, the Escali Pure Badger is a better value. For the money, the Escali brush is very soft and performs well.<br /><br />My only complaint with the Escali is that it does shed a bit more than desired. Even after a couple of months of use, I still find a few hairs left behind in the soap bowl. It's not enough to consider a significant problem, but it is noticeable.
  3552. hAVE NEVER USED ANY OTHER BADGER BRUSHES BUT IF YOU ARE LOOKING FOR A ENTRY LEVEL BRUSH IT DOES WHAT IT IS SUPPOSED TO DO. PUT LATHER ON YOUR FACE.
  3553. Brush is soft and works well with the cup soap. Feels great on the face. Does not come apart with use.
  3554. If you want a real firm bristle brush, then this isn't it, but for someone like myself who prefers a soft bristle, this one is perfect. The wood is nicely finished and I have had minimal loss of bristles after over a month's worth of use. I dry it (as prior experience taught me) with the bristles hanging down from a holder, and each shave is perfect. I have been using a shaving brush and shaving soap for nearly 40 years and have gone through a number of brushes. This one appears to be a good deal for the price. I don't like the plastic ones, and a cheap wood one cracks and/or loses bristles quickly. So far . . . so good!

  3564. This is my first real badger brush. I like it very much. It is soft and holds a lot of water, which is what you need if you're mixing up lather from a cake of shaving soap in a mug or using a brush-type shaving cream from a tube.<br /><br />(There are brushless shaving creams in tubes as well. They're not meant to use with a brush, but I prefer to use a brush even with these. Generally this lets me work a bit more water into the hairs before shaving, which is usually a good thing.)<br /><br />Others reported the brush smelled.   3570. This isn't really a con, because it's advertised as real badger hair, but just be aware that it's going to have a slight odor to it.<br /><br />Overall:<br /><br />Great brush, especially for the price. I switched to safety razor shaving recently after 10 years of cartridge shaving and it feels SOOO much better. Creating the lather directly on my face feels great, and if you do it correctly you get the shaving cream up UNDER the hairs and on the skin directly, as opposed to smearing it around on top of all the hairs if you are using shaving gel from a can and your hand. This really helps to create a more comfortable AND closer shave.<br /><br />I took 1 star away for the fact that quite a few of the hairs came out of the brush the first few weeks of using, and the slight smell to the brush. But, I'd still probably purchase it again.
  3571. I wondered at first if the price indicated low quality. BOY, WAS I WRONG! Anyone who pays twice, three times, TEN TIMES this much for a shaving brush is making a huge mistake.<br /><br />Break it in: (1) soak it for five minutes in hot water (2) load it with a good shaving soap (3) work up a good, heavy lather (4) let the brush sit overnight in its stand (5) rinse soap out and repeat steps 1-3 at your next shave. Voila! EASY!

  3586. This brush is at a good price point, but my brush continued to have hairs fall out DAILY even after 3 months of use. I just got into wet shaving and did not know much about quality of brushes. I had heard that badger brushes are good and so I was quite intrigued to see such a relatively inexpensive brush that was \\"pure Badger\\" ... which I incorrectly assumed meant that the brush has nothing but Badger hair. Although pure Badger brushes do only have Badger hair, that's not the definition. If you look online, you'll see that there are different badger brush qualities where many consider the order (lowest to highest) being: pure -> best -> super -> silvertip. As such the pricing of these types of brushes also usually goes in that order.<br /><br />The difference lies in what part of the badger body where the hairs come from. You can look online for the detailed explanations of this. But the names of these brushes aren't necessarily all that helpful. For example, \\"best\\" is not necessarily the best!<br /><br />Despite the fact that silvertip tends to be the most expensive, that does not mean it is the best for everyone. It is regarded as the softest but some prefer that their brushes have a bit more \\"backbone\\" so that the brush can get into the beard and help the hairs stand up prior to shaving. Some have stated that pure badger brushes tend to be of poorer quality and are prone to having knots form within. I found this to be the case with my Escali brush.<br /><br />I didn't want something too soft (silvertip) so I instead went with a best badger brush by Edwin Jagger (Model 1ej947sds):<br /><br />[[ASIN:B002QI45Z0 Edwin Jagger Best Badger Shaving Brush With Drip Stand, Imitation Ivory, Medium]]<br /><br />Many reviewers have stated that the Jagger best brush has a great quality and has sufficient backbone. So far I found that this is true and this brush suits my needs better than the Escali. And, even in the first use, I found that NO HAIRS fell out for the Jagger. That was not the case with the Escali.<br /><br />This is not to say that the Escali is a poor choice for everyone. At that price point it could be a very attractive brush, and it's hard to argue with the MANY high product ratings. But I thought it'd alert other new wet shavers who don't know much about badger brushes that there are other types aside from \\"pure\\" and that \\"pure\\" doesn't just mean \\"100%\\" in this case.<br /><br />If you can, try visiting a store that carries various brushes (for example, Art of Shaving but beware that their prices are HIGH). When testing brushes, I wouldn't brush the face directly as you have no idea how much that brush has been handled and what's on it. Instead apply it somewhere like the back of your hand or on your forearm. I found that the sensitivity in the palm of your hand is not very good, but you could feel differences on your forearm. Try out the different brushes and you'll notice a difference between the pure and other brushes. Honestly, I could HARDLY tell the difference between a best and silvertip, but you might appreciate the difference. Good luck!
  3587. I've been using this thing every day for the past year and it's still fantastic even after all that use.<br /><br />Definitely recommend using with Proraso/Bigelow shave cream.

  3632. I expected this shaving brush to have a smell, and I tried several methods to reduce the smell to a comfortable level before returning it.<br /><br />Running the brush through warm soapy water did not help. The smell from this brush once wet with warm water was overpowering and nauseating.<br /><br />I searched for other methods to reduce the smell from a badger hair shaving brush. I began with soaking the brush in a diluted distilled vinegar and warm water solution close to 10% vinegar for 20 minutes. I found this did not improve the smell at all.<br /><br />I next tried soaking the brush in a 50% vinegar and 50% water solution overnight. This marginally improved the smell from the brush, but it was still overpowering.<br /><br />Next, I soaked the brush in water with dissolved baking soda overnight. This slightly improved the smell, but it was still very strong and difficult to even test smell once wet with warm water.<br /><br />Last, I cleaned the brush with shampoo and conditioner and then made a baking soda paste, thoroughly worked this paste into the brush, let it sit overnight, and finally proceeded with several cleaning cycles of warm water and shaving soap and again with warm water and shampoo and conditioner. This did not improve the smell; it seemed no additional cleaning cycles improved it beyond this point.<br /><br />I realize that this much cleaning may have impacted the quality of the brush as well, but I did not care. The smell was so strong that I was more interested in reducing it rather than thinking about its use later. I do expect a brush like this to have a smell, but the smell from this brush was simply too strong. I suspect that there was a defect in how this hair was treated and processed initially before being manufactured as a shaving brush. The \\"pure\\" in the description is an indication of quality for badger shaving brushes. Pure is the lowest quality classification typically used. My next purchase will be a higher quality classification.

  3654. I'm new to shaving with a double edge razors. One of the must have items for safety razor shaving is a shaving brush. Being a novice, I didn't know whether or not I would like it. Aside from the initial investment of the hardware, the blades are cheap and the soaps and creams reasonably priced but the shaving brushes were all over the spectrum. After spending a money on an Edwin Jagger razor, I didn't want to spend too much on a shaving brush in case I decided this type of shaving wasn't for me. At least with the razor itself, I can sell it but the brush I wasn't sure I could due to hygiene.<br /><br />Now for the brush itself, it was priced much less than some I saw. Not having used any other one, my review may be one sided. In any case, I found this brush to be very nice. The hairs themselves are soft and the wooden handle gripped nicely and felt nice on the hand. A few hairs fell off but only because I realized I wasn't wetting the brush enough before lathering up with the soap. Once I got that down, no more hairs fell off.<br /><br />Applying lather to my face felt so soft and gentle that I actually enjoy the whole process. Cleaning is so simple I just run water through it and shake it a bit to get the excess water out, sometimes i just press the hairs with my fingers a few time and before hanging it on my stand to dry off.<br /><br />It feels like a well built quality brush. Not having another brush to compare it to I still give it a five star. There probably are better brushes out there but I found this one to be more than adequate and worth the price.
  3655. I've been using this brush for about 7 months now and while it is great for the price I still have a few badger hairs fall out. No biggie, still works as intended. Make sure to use a stand with this product and don't leave it lying around.

  3677. I have been using this brush for about a month, and it more or less what I expected it to be. I have used this brush exclusively with shaving soap (Queen Charlotte, DR Harris, Edwin Jagger, Tabac).<br /><br />The brush is capable of creating good lather from the soap. However, it has continuously lost 2-5 hair strands every use, but that does seem to finally be slowing down now. I have to make sure that I really load the brush to produce enough lather for 3+ passes. I have had to reload the brush occasionally. There is also a section of hair in the middle, but a little off center, that has more backbone that the surrounding hairs. This took some adjustment, but it is not a problem after a few uses. I have also found that this brush works much better with a shaving mug as opposed to a face lathering. I considered ranking this as three stars due to the issues listed above, but for the price, I think these issues are acceptable.<br /><br />Bottom Line: This brush is perfectly fine for a beginner, but you will probably want to upgrade if you continue wet shaving.

  3724. Around December I decided to switch to wet shaving due to being tired of getting horrible irritation from any other form of shaving. I made the mistake of not doing as much research as I should have and wound up on the page for this brush due to the fact that it had such good reviews. I also got a few other popular products to begin my shave den such as Proraso Green, my Merkur 34C, and a decent brush/razor stand. Those turned out to be fantastic, the brush, however, turned out to be a disaster. Not only did it seem like a disaster, I also felt completely swindled into buying a totally crap product. On my very first shave, I may not have known exactly what to expect, but I knew I had watched enough videos on YouTube about loading a brush and creating a lather to know that the Proraso puck shouldn't have been caked with &#34;badger hair&#34; from the knot. I also use the term badger hair lightly. After using several different brushes at this point and knowing what REAL badger hair looks, feels, and smells (yes this is important) like, I am very hard pressed to believe that this vendor is telling the truth when they say 100% badger hair in the product description. Please, please, please do not waste your money on this product.<br />**New wet shavers and old alike, if you are looking for cheaper options (like me) for brushes, this is not your answer. There are plenty of other cheaper brushes that work wonders and will last you for ages. Some of these options can even be found here on Amazon. Check out Omega boar brushes. I got an Omega 10066 boar hair brush after this piece of crap and I still use it almost every day even though I have several different brushes now. Above all just do a little research about this stuff if you are new to wet shaving of thinking about getting into it. Don't waste your initial investment like I did, and don't let bogus products like this one take away from the enjoyment you can get from a good old school shave!

Williams seems to be the pickiest, did not like at all the VDH brush so I am using this one.

  3747. This Escali 100% Pure Badger Shaving Brush is a great product for a great price. Upon receiving mine and having a first shave with it, I noticed a pungent odor not unlike that of a wet badger. It was bad enough to make me dry-heave when lathering my mustache area beneath my nose. Some quick googling revealed that this is not uncommon. An overnight soak in white vinegar followed by a rinsing in dish soap thoroughly stripped away all the funk. I have used this brush every morning since I bought it and am very pleased. The bristles are soft, yet firm enough to lift the whiskers. The odor is completely eliminated - not a trace. I recommend this product as long as you're willing to soak it overnight in white vinegar before using it.

  3757. As far as shaving goes, using a shaving brush is a huge upgrade from whatever aerosol gel you're using. What I usually do is let it sit in my mug full of water to get those bristles wet. Then I dump out the water and shake off any excess to create my lather. It works wonders, especially once it's broken in. While the bristles were a little stiff for my liking, it's done my face nicely. Sure it sheds a little bit in the beginning, but I find all shaving brushes do that, and they usually stop after a few uses.<br /><br />Bottom line: If you're new to traditional wetshaving, or returning to it, this a great brush for the price.

  3786. I recently started using the &#34;Safety Razor&#34; form of shaving, and didn't want to spend $40-80 on a &#34;nicer&#34; brush until I knew I would like this shaving method. The Escali brush seems to be of very good quality, especially for the price (about $13). It absorbs warm water very well for pre-shave &#34;priming&#34;, lathers well in shave bowl, and does a nice job in exfoliating skin as you spread the later across your face (circular motions). I doubt I will be buying a &#34;nicer&#34; brush any time soon since this brush more than meets my needs and expectations.<br /><br />Please note that this brush will shed a little bit, but nothing major.<br /><br />All in all, this is a terrific brush for the price, a great value. Not sure what the $80 brushes can offer that would make them worth $67 more than this brush. If you are new to this shaving method, this is the brush for you.

I find maybe 3 hairs that fall out each shave, but it isn't really an issue--I think most of these lose a few each shave. I've had it for three months, use it 2-5 times a week, and I don't foresee needing a new one for a while. For the price, I definitely say go for it.

  3815. I've got one of these already for myself, and liked it so much I gave one away as a gift to my brother who is just getting into wet shaving. It gets the job done, holds together (a few hairs came out for the first week or so, but that's fairly normal and it hasn't had a shedding problem since)and doesn't look so bad either. Like most real-badger hair brushes, there's a bit of a funk to it right out of the package; give it a good hot water rinse, soap it up really well with the shave soap of your choice, and let it dry overnight. A gentle rinse-out the next day and it should be good to go, (also helps get rid of loose hairs at this point instead of on your face!) if not then one more soap up should do it. The price is right, I'd recommend it for beginners, although I'm sure you could get some good mileage as your main brush as well.

  3821. I have used a lot of brushes in my day and this is a solid product.<br /><br />I shave straight razor and although you can get away with using a crappy brush a good brush with fine bristles I find<br />helpful in getting lather all around the hair and ensuring a clean cut.<br /><br />The only tip I can give people who use a brush is to get some hair conditioner (any kind will do) and to use this on their brush after they clean off the soap. The reason for this is simple - it ensures that the brushes natural hair bristles don't chip off or split.<br /><br />This is a five star product I would recommend it to anyone.

Also, the copper ring seems like a decorative touch, but it should stop corrosion of the wood and bristles of the base by being a sacrificial element, much like the zinc plates on boats.   3922. I've never used a shave brush before or shaving soap that requires a brush. Anyway, this is the first one I've owned and I bought it based on the reviews and price. I don't have any to compare it to. The reviews and online tutorials all said to get a pure badger hair brush, so I looked for the best most reasonably priced one I could find.<br /><br />It works well, and seems well constructed. I can whip up a good thick creamy foam without too much trial and error. The wood handle is nice and does not seem to be affected by being immersed in water. I soak it in hot water first then whip up the cream and apply it. The bristles are soft but strong and stiff enough to whip up the cream easily and hold more than enough for multiple shaves. The bristles are able to pull up the stubble and help prepare the face for a good shave.<br /><br />My only complaint is it tends to lose more bristles/hairs than I think it should. I know any brush made from hair will lose some but it is a little more than should be acceptable. Thus, one star down.<br /><br />Overall I think it was worth the money and it works well, I am not disapointed!
  3923. I picked up this brush because it had solid reviews and a low price tag. I had a synthetic brush from a big-box retailer and wanted to give real badger hair a try. The price was right and quality seems to be about on par with other entry level brushes. There was a strong animal and chemical smell for a few weeks, but now it just smells like my shave soap. A few bristles have fallen out (several during the first few shaves), but that seems to have stopped now. Make sure you get a stand like the Colonel Conk Evernice Model 775 Chrome Safety Razor Stand. You want to hang dry the brush to prevent early wear. Definitely a solid purchase if you are getting into traditional wet-shaving.

  3934. I had a boar bristle brush before buying this better badger bristle brush (whoa, what a mouthful!) However, there was a noticeable odor for the first week that I used this brush that has since vanished. The smell was only unpleasant while applying the lather, and didn't stick around, and now it's gone completely!   4034. This is the second one of these I have owned. Yes Martha, they do where out. Funny how some can get a new cell phone every year for hundreds but cannot afford $13 to keep a fresh shaving brush. Oh, well, their Bubba beer coolers are full.<br /><br />Those that complain about some of the hair coming out of it need to learn to break it in. Nothing more, nothing less. When you get the brush take it out of the package, put it in your right and, stick you left index finger out, and then slap the brush 10 or 12 times up and down against that finger. Then...look at the brush and you will see some of the hair has raised up. Take you fingers and grab these strand and throw them in the trash. Then.....do it again, and repeat. Usually on the third time you will no longer get any loose strands. I know this is a bit of work....but I know you can do it Bubba....I know you can.<br /><br />Good luck with your shaving.
  4035. Like most things in life you're going to get what you pay for. It's not a terrible brush in terms of softness, but spending the extra $10 makes all the difference in quality. The reason I gave it 3 stars wasn't for the quality though.....it's because the brush smells like a dead badger. I see I'm not alone in noticing the smell....though I don't know how a person couldn't notice it considering the smell of decaying flesh is fairly overwhelming with this brush. Which brings up another point....some folks here are trying to describe the smell. It's the smell of a rotting animal....because it's a rotting animal. There is no other way to &#34;describe&#34; the smell.

  4110. I finally got around to using my brush tonight after my old fairly cheap badger brush broke. I let it soak in hot water before shaving and immediately noticed a strong smell coming from it. These smells are pretty common with real animal hair brushes so I wasn't too surprised, but the smell was definitely stronger than I anticipated, and very 'farmy'.<br /><br />After soaking it I gave it a quick rinse and then began to hand lather with TOBS soap. The brush held water well and helped give a quick lather, but I noticed that the lather started to go from a shiny white to off-white and eventually darker and darker. I wrung the lather out of the brush and saw that parts of it, presumably from the base around the knot, were a dirty brown. The hair must have not been cleaned properly prior to assembly and was leaving mud in my lather. I rinsed that lather down the drain and tried again after cleaning the brush a second time, and the same thing happened. It was also caked into my soap where I had loaded the brush, and left the same 'farmy' smell from before in it.<br /><br />I eventually went ahead and shaved with it anyway, and noticed that the brush wasn't as soft and gentle as it felt when dry. It felt like a few but not all of the hairs were quite sharp and fairly irritative, but I can't complain from a $10 brush. There was also fairly few loose hairs in the first use, certainly fewer than other brushes I have owned.<br /><br />I think after the dirt in the brush is eventually washed away and the bristles soften up, it could be a very good brush for it's price. But just a few extra precautions in the assembly process could have avoided it entirely.

  4123. This brush is excellent for anyone looking to get into wet shaving and not wanting to spend a lot of money in case it's not for them. My original Escali brush has handled everything I have thrown at it from Mitchell's wool fat soap, to Taylor of Old Bond creams., it has performed well in bowl lathers as well as face lathering. However I recently ordered one for a relative of mine and have noticed that this brush is slightly different than my original from about a year ago. This newer one has a different finish on its handle, it is more of a sealant, similar to Semogue wood handles, than a varnish like on the older version. The handle also has a wider profile on its base, but overall the appearance remains about the same. All in all this is a great brush to get started with, and is capable of handling everything that is out there, in terms of shaving creams, soaps, and cream-soaps.

It's soft, but not as soft as other badger hair brushes. I clean the brush after each use by rinsing and letting it sit in warm water. Then I squeeze out the water and place it in the stand for the next days use. The handle is nice and wooden. It's a great shape for the hand. I'd like to see it be a little softer and not lose as many bristles. Overall I'd say it's a good beginners brush.

  4150. I decided to move from a Mach 3 razor that I've used the last 7-8 years over to a safety razor after constantly hearing how great it was. I bought this brush which was &#34;recommended&#34; with the Merkur safety razor along with some proraso soap. It had a lot of reviews so thats why I bought it. I've never used a brush in all my years of shaving or had any other brush so I have nothing to compare it to. The brush seemed to work as it intended. I have no intention of going back to cartridge razors after just 1 shave with my new safety razor but I'm not sure I'll continue making my own shaving lather. I don't have a sensitive face at all and I can just as easily shave with water. Makes no difference to me really and Razor burn is just not something I've ever had an issue with in all my years of shaving so a good shaving lather just really isn't that important to me. I just want a close shave, and need a sharp razor to do it and after just 3 shaves with a Mach 3, it can't do that leading my to buy more which are just too dang expensive. I just used the cheapest shaving creme that I could buy from the dollar store. I used to shave daily when I was in the Military for 4 years, but now I shave 2, maybe 3 times a week.<br /><br />As other users here mentions, this brush seems to lose a lot of hair with each use which is kind of an annoyance and I would use a pair of tweezers to pick the strands out of my soap. I read that some users said it wasn't very soft on their face. Again, maybe it's because I don't have sensitive skin, but I thought it felt great on my face. I certainly couldn't justify spending any more on a brush though and I see there are some really expensive ones out there.. I'll admit, I did enjoy making the lather and have since practiced making a lather on nights when I'm not even shaving just playing with things like thickness, adding more or less water etc.<br /><br />I purchased a small hanger at walmart that holds my new razor and this brushwhich stays on my bathroom counter but for those mornings when I'm in a rush, I'll probably just grab my can of shaving cream as I always have though. I'm knocking 1 star off for it losing the bristles but I liked it other than that. Brushes just aren't something for me.

I would certainly try other products from this company.<br /><br />EDIT: after using this brush maybe twice a week for a few months now I can say I'm a little let down by it's performance and durability. I lather a mixture of hard glycerin based soaps and soft soaps and have lost quite a few hairs. It has only slightly lightened up (become less prickly) but is still too harsh to face lather (especially having now had experience with some Boars hair brushes that had been softer). The other issue with face lathering is that once it's loaded up to a nice lather on the brush, the bristles spread out in all directions when applied to your face, leaving the middle to scrape along your dry face.<br /><br />Overall I'm pretty disappointed with this brush, and after some non-amazon related research, found that it is listed on a \\"bad gear\\" list on Reddit's Wicked_Edge subreddit, and I believe it belongs there. I'd try another Badger brush but not another Escali.

  4198. $13 for a workable, full-size badger hair shaving brush? That's hard to beat. And as long as you're drying it correctly, the bristles stay on just fine.<br /><br />A few things you may want to know:<br />- If you, like thousands of other shoppers on Amazon are considering buying the Colonel Conk Shaving Stand to hold this brush and your razor, you should know that the Escali brush handle is just a shade too thick to slide easily into the prongs. It fits, but you have to hold the stand with one hand and almost lodge the brush handle in between the prongs. On the flip side, it is a really secure hold :)<br />- I agree with some of the other reviewers who recommend not leaving the wet brush sit on the handle. I can see how that would cause issues with the wood/bristles (for any brush really). I hang-dry the brush from the handle each time, and I can't remember a single bristle trying to get away from the brush in the few months I've used it<br /><br />I sometimes wish the bristles were softer, but knowing that I'd have to pay upwards of 2-3X more for that level of cuddly badgery softness, I'm quite happy with the Escali.

  4251. So far, there is nothing I dislike about this product. My only word of warning is that if you are new to using a shaving brush like I was, spend some time on youtube or other websites to learn how to use it and what to look for.<br /><br />Having said that, I have been using this for weeks now and I am very happy with it. It stays nice and stiff when wet and it loads up very easily. I do have some bristles come out every now and then but hopefully that's just the weak ones being lost. The handle is nice and easy to hold and the bristles are very comfortable when in use.

With the help of a YouTube tutorial on shaving with a brush, I am now getting the best shaves of my life.

  4270. Got this at the request of my husband for cleaning his rifles (it's an old Army thing). Works fine for that!
  4271. Not to bring down the sales to the shipper,because the delivery ways quick and customer service oriented. But for people who are looking into buying a shaving brush, this is not the way to go. I say that because I noticed pieces of the brush on my face and in my shaving soap dish almost immediately after using it. A true badger shaving brush is never supposed to leave behind the bursh bristles on your face or soap. I spoke with someone who has been straight razor shaving for 30 years and using a variety brushes,he completely agreed and said it should never fall apart. If you are looking into buying a good brush you are looking into paying a little more money and a price range of 30-70 dollars. Silver Tip badger hair brushes is what you should be looking for, they are the best quality and will not fall apart like this. I hope this helps you in making your choice of choosing badger hair brushes.
  4272. I had bought a starter wet shave kit that came with a standard synthetic shave brush. Now that I've used both, I can honestly say this one not only works up a better lather, it also has softer more flexible bristles. It arrived just when I expected it to and it does everything it says. I do occasionally lose badger bristles in my shave cup, but I guess that's just par for the course.
  4273. Works great, no complaints. I am new to wet shaving and purchased this brush based on all the reviews I saw here. The brush is soft and lathers very well.   4275. I purchased the Escali Badger shaving brush after reading the benefits of this brush indicating that this is a great brush, creating a rich lather, and very confortable. Well, MY experience with this brush is very disappointing. The brush is very prickly against my face even after soaking it in hot water and leather it up with soap. I could feel the hair of the brush as being fine needles against my face. Thinking that it might need \\"breaking in\\" I continued to use it for four days, soaking it for about 2 minutes in hot water and then using it, even thought I could still feel it pricking my face. On the fifth day, that morning, I noticed red spots all over my face where I had used the brush. I discontined to use this brush, went back to my old brush, and my face cleared up after a couple of days, and have had no further problems using my old brush. I did not change soap, shaver, or the temperature of the water. The only thing different was the Escali Badger hair brush. Perhaps I am allergic to this brush, however I have had a badger brush in the past without any problems. It may also be my age..I am 71 and have been shaving with a brush for over 50 years. Maybe it was just this brush or this hair. However I am not using it again and it is sitting in the drawer, in the plastic case that it came in. If Escali makes a brush with a different hair, I would like to try it.

Upon first use just a few brush hairs came out of the brush but after that, none! After use I gently rinse the brush and hang from a stand so that bristles point downwards.   4325. You can't beat this brush for it's price point and quality. Yes, it's badger hair so it may give off a smell initially, but that quickly goes away. Also, a few of the bristles do become loose and fall off during the first couple uses, which wasn't a problem for me, so I ran it under hot water with a bit of shaving cream and used the brush on the palm of my hand before shaving with it to get rid of a majority of the loose bristles. After that initial wash / prep, I only had 2-3 more bristles fall of during my shave. I would highly recommend this product, especially if you're just starting out with wet shaving and don't want to spend a substantial amount on a real badger brush.

I initially dug out my grandfather’s 50 year old spice mug, brush and cheap disposable razors, but when the soap was gone, I knew I liked the ceremony and results of the way of my ancestors. However, with this shaving brush the shedding never did stop. There were bristles on my face and on the shaving soap nearly every time I used it. Once it became clear I was going to stick with wet shaving I bought a mid-level Parker shaving brush. I have never seen a single bristle come out, which is amazing to me. It is now clear that the Escali brush was far from ideal and I used it for way too long. It now sits in my drawer.

  4385. This little brush works wonders creating a nice lather for your face. People have mentioned bristles falling out. That has not happened to me at all and I only recently went back to shaving with a non-electric razor. Some things to note on keeping this product in good condition: 1) Do not let water leak into the handle 2) Do not be overly rough with it 3) Rinse the bristles thoroughly to get all foam out of them (I use a medium-hot water -- aka it doesn't hurt your hand when you touch it) 4) When storing this product, make sure that it is pointing bristles-DOWN so that any remaining water will drip OUT of it Now, #4 may seem like a hard task if you don't have a brush holder. You may not want to even buy one. I know I didn't, but that's where some DIY comes in. Some people use a coat hanger to hang this product from somewhere in their bathroom. That works pretty well. I on the other hand, did not have a coat hanger for some reason to spare. So what I did was -- I used the box it came in (a plastic, see-through container). This small, plastic box has a hole near the top that you often see on products so that they can hang from walls in stores. I attached a paper clip to this part and am now simply letting it hang from a spot in my bathroom. That's even less work than using a coat hanger! If you do it this way, then you may want to poke a small hole or two in the plastic as well so that moisture can escape. Just some FYI for those who want to DIY! (was that as catchy as it sounded in my head? oh boy do I hope so!) EDIT: I have added an image to the gallery that shows my 'DIY'. As you can see, I have something in my bathroom that is perfect for hanging things with a paper clip. You can use other things though, such as string, Rubber Bands, etc. Hope it helps! EDIT (11/21/2014): I bought this ages ago and it still works like a champ! However, the bristles now ARE falling out (every shave). There's so many of them that it just doesn't matter, but they do get in the sink and on your face. Not a big deal really (especially considering the price of this product).
  4386. Nice inexpensive brush. Does shed a little so far, but hoping that will stop with continued use.

So I have upgraded the rating to four stars. For the price, this is an okay brush.<br />The Escali is not my first badger brush. The reviews were so overwhelmingly good, I decided to check this inexpensive brush out. It arrived today. The results of my first shave: the brush is on the small side, but remember the low price. It lathered well and gave me a nice beginning to my shave. It feels a bit coarse. It also lost quite a few bristles. So why did I give it three stars? It provided the foundation for a very good shave but it shed a lot.. As I continue to use this brush, I will update the review. If the shedding stops I will raise my rating to a four. If it continues to shed, I will return it to Amazon and lower my rating to a two. Again, what should one expect for twelve bucks?

  4420. This is my intro into wet shaving and badger hair holds more water and is denser than boar hair - it is just technically better for this purpose at any grade. Supposedly this is the lowest grade of badger hair (pure) given the price point. Appears that the price point is about 30 to 60 before you get anything rated best or silvertip and becomes exponential if name brand is involved. I have never tried shaving with another brush, but I attempted to do some research and went to a store to look and feel what a $120 brush buys you...There's no question that it is a higher grade product, the bristles are softer and more consistent, the handle is made of 'real' material, and there might be more hair inside the handle (the knot) so that is less likely to fall out over time. This brush lathers just fine and probably has a lower overall useful life than a more expensive one. Based on the reviews and pricing, I had almost no expectations. I'm not losing to many hairs after first week of use and it lathers just fine. Getting the smell out was a different story. This thing smells like an animal...not as bad as a boar brush (at least you know it's &#34;real badger&#34;). I tried dish soap, head & shoulders, every shampoo I could find in the bathroom, and hot water. What really got the smell out quick was proraso. I would practice lather making with any strong scent shaving cream or soap a few times to get the smell down to an acceptable level before actual use.

  4442. This is a great brush, just the right size to whip up a decent lather using [[ASIN:B0031OXOBE Taylor of Old Bond Street Almond Shaving Cream]] for a superb shave.<br /><br />I have used this combination daily for over a week now, with a Bic disposable 3-blade razor and I have to say this is giving me the closest shave I have ever had. In fact I am astounded by what a difference this makes compared to my previous use of Barbasol gel in a can with the same razor.<br /><br />It has lost a few bristles on use, but really the loss is quite minimal and I expect this to last if looked after well. I would recommend getting a stand though as badger brushes should be left upside down or on their side to dry out after shaving otherwise the bristles will fall out due to the wooden brush handle drying much more slowly that the bristles.<br /><br />Pros: Amazingly close shave when used with [[ASIN:B0031OXOBE Taylor of Old Bond Street Almond Shaving Cream]], and a regular disposable razor; feels nice to handle and use<br /><br />Cons: some bristle loss; a little bit of a longer shaving routine; brush is a little rough on the face till you get used to it, although perhaps this helps \\"exfoliate\\" (what do I know?)<br /><br />Overall a great product so far.

If you're looking for something ornamental or elegant, this isn't it--as you might have already found out from the picture, it has a plain, undistinguished wooden handle.
