  4503. Item arrived as described and on time. Using the brush about three times a week since purchased. Bristles are still firm and intact.
  4504. Great value. Superior to my old one which was inherited.
  4505. As I read before buying a brush that you want boar or badger and either is pretty much fine especially for a beginner learning what you like. Well I love it, it lathers good with my proraso soap and after the first few shaves no more hairs are coming out. Great product with a great price! I shave with a generic 3 blade safety razor from walgreens with it and it works great. I don't see myself needing another of these for a long time unless something happens to this one. Perfect for intro to wet shaving brush (and maybe more?) but i definitely like wet shaving and this product has been perfect!
  4506. I have been using this brush for several weeks now. It works very well and is a great value for the money. I would highly recommend this brush to anyone interested in wet shaving.
  4507. It's not bad, just a bit smelly at first. I'm guessing that most badger brushes are probably a little &#34;gamey&#34; at first. This is the best way that I have found to use it: Use hot water to make your foam in a cup. If you want the foam to be thick, use a little less water in the brush when working up the lather. Use short quick circular motions to apply the foam to the face. It does a nice job of applying the foam and lifting the whiskers. When you rinse it out, run water through it until it looks clean. Then, load it with water and &#34;sling&#34; the water out in the shower or tub (hold on to the handle and do a short fast throwing motion). If there's any soap left in it it will show. Do it until there's no more soap coming out.Form it with your hands to the right shape and hang it to dry. When it's dry, if there are stray hairs sticking out at right angles to the main knot, just snip them off. Only cut the hairs that won't conform with the others. I've been using this one for a few months and have grown to like it.
  4508. I used it for about 3 weeks and it broke already. The brush came out of the handle.
  4509. I gave it to my son & he was very pleased with the brush. He said it is very soft and is high quality.
  4510. Lathers my skin well. It's my first brush so I'm not sure if this is a normal occurrence, but every time I use it one or two of the bristles fall out.
  4511. I am new to using a shaving brush and with quite a bit to choose from finally decided on this one. Other reviewers have said it is scratching but for me anyway, that is not the case. No bad smell either. I have noticed a very small brownish tint to my soap when I lather up but not enough to bother me.
  4512. Didn't know shaving could be so enjoyable!
  4513. Brush works great. Bought as an upgrade from my brush that I got in a kit from a big box store. This one performs much better.
  4514. Great Brush, lost a few hairs the first couple uses, but definitely a great buy!
  4515. Badger hair began to fall out within a couple days. The entire brush came out of the handle in only 3 months. Clear coat on handle cracked and fell apart within a few weeks.
  4516. I've been using this daily for nearly four months now and it continues to perform well. A stray bristle will occasionally fall out, but I would expect the same of any shaving brush. The brush seems to retain an appropriate amount of moisture while shaving and dries well between uses.

Before this i had a van der haagen brush from a gift set.<br /><br />Ive used this brush a couple times and it stinks very badly. it is almost unbearable for me to shave with it. it smells like a weird thick musky rubbery smell, as if the animal they got the hair off of was hideously unclean and they never bothered to clean it or something.<br /><br />the musky smell of the almond soap certainly doesnt help. I wouldnt be surprised if this was horse hair or something.<br /><br />The brush is extremely small. it is slightly prickly, but thats ok. arguably that is its only redeeming quality. If the brush was bigger and less smelly it would be fine but this thing is tiny and smells awful. perhaps a different soap like proraso or some other menthol/eucalyptus soap would help?<br /><br />I will try washing it with dish soap to see if the smell goes away.

  4531. The overall design of the brush is a bit small, which is great if you like to lather while holding with your finger tips. The bristles are firm but not scratchy. The big loss is that the hairs consistently fall out. I've been VERY gentle with the brush when lathering in the shaving cup; only the tips of the bristles touch. Regardless, be prepared to lose at least 3-5 hairs per shave. I've had this brush for about 2 months and the hairs keep falling out. Still, the price is very affordable and the handle design is solid.

From day one I have dried it out really well and hung it upside down after use, so I know that wasn't the issue. That hasn't affected the ability to create a good lather, so I haven't felt the need to replace it. It still on average loses a hair or two every time I shave (which is 2 or 3 times a week). But again, overall, good brush and certainly good value.

  4578. Gone are the days of the swine! No more shall I bow down to any more boars and their whiskers for my shaving needs! I have now found badger to harass, hunt and steal hairs from... now I shave like a man, utmost grandiosity intact and Samurai honor prevailing!<br /><br />Boar brushes used to kick my arse to hell and back. There was no way to tell why they would do that, but the fault lies with me for not using the better brush. Now don't get me wrong, some people prefer using boar whisker brush - which is absolutely okay, but it is not for me - and definitely not for those who cannot handle the loose hair upon their manly faces. Just imagine, looking at yourself into the mirror, admiring the vessel that contains all that testosterone for hot love making and being the epitome of manhood. Imagine Henry Cavill staring back at you all Man O' Steel like, only to have the image twist unto Davy Jones and those loose boar spikes turning you into a monstrosity you don't deserve to be.<br /><br />Why the three stars? Three reasons;<br /><br />The brush is not the best quality, then again... it's not supposed to be. You get what you pay for. This is for those transitioning from boar to badger. Loose bristles on occasion therefore are an annoyance, but always remember to dry it (or hang it upside down after usage like I do).<br /><br />Rugged face surface hurts the brush. Now on a scale of 1 to 10 with 10 being The Thing and 1 being Kate Beckinsale's lovely parts, I am a good solid 6. But on occasion the brush scrunches against my skin, unwilling the withstand the temerity of gallantry and awesomeness that is me (seriously, if you're Santa and wish to look like Sean Connery, this brush will bend over backwards and go to extreme lengths for you, but there is no guarantee it'll survive after pulling of &#34;Saving Private Ryan' type feats of valor!)<br /><br />Ask not what the bristles do for the brush, but what the brush can do for the bristles. Seriously, mate... take good careof this brush. It will last you a few hundred shaves, enabling you to stand tall with the likes of Allan Quarterman and Captain John Blackthorne (yes, I know they sport beards... but I'm matching sheer awesomeness, not smooth faces). Finally you can upgrade to a better quality badger brush too, I look forward to that day as well.<br /><br />Disclaimer: No boars or badgers were harmed in the writing of this review.

I have less irritation and razor burn, and it really doesn't take me as long as I expected.<br /><br />The only reason I couldn't justify 5 stars is that the brush does lose a bristle or two from time to time, which means picking them off my face after I lather up. For the price, I expected so much, and it really isn't a big enough problem to make me want a different brush any time soon.<br /><br />I'm using the brush with [[ASIN:B0007M4SOA Geo F. Trumper's Coconut Oil Shaving Cream Tube 75g]]. I soak the brush in warm water while I shower, then dump the water and shake the excess from the bristles. With about 1cm of cream from the tube, it makes a great lather. I also picked up a cheap stand ([[ASIN:B001613S8I Kingsley Clear Shave Brush Stand]]) as I understand that drying it with the bristles down is supposed to prevent them from falling out.

  4601. I should start by saying this is the first and only shaving brush I've ever used, so perhaps all shaving brushes are like this: I found that the bristles are too long. When wet and full of shaving cream, the brush works more like a paintbrush - It just smears the shaving cream on my face, which I can do with just my hand. To get the brush to do what I think it's supposed to do - work into my whiskers and exfoliate a little, I have to grab the base of the bristles with my fingers to make them shorter and stiffer. Also, be prepared for a musky smell, especially the first few times, presumably from this being badger hair. When rinsing the brush after shaving, the water would run brown. I guess the bristles aren't washed very well before assembly. The bristles rinse clean now, after a couple of weeks, but there's still a musky smell. Doesn't bother me, but the scent is there.

I told him it had starting to shed hairs. I told him how I used everyday and left it on the counter sitting on it's base (as it is in this picture above.) He gave me a cheap plastic stand to have the fur/hair facing down after a good rinsing and said I should think about buying another brush to rotate if I shave everyday.

  4633. I'm new to \\"old school\\" shaving, and recently decided to dump the Gilette Mach $$$ and switch to a safety razor. Produces a good lather (using Taylor of Old Bond Street Sandalwood Shaving Cream), and while it did lose 7 or 8 bristles upon first use (and a couple during each of the next few shaves), it no longer sheds.   4634. I've been using this brush for 4 years now, and it's still going strong. I originally wanted to purchase an inexpensive brush because I wasn't sure if I was going to stick to using it and I did not want to invest in a &#34;high quality&#34; expensive brush --I figured that if I stick to it, I'll just purchase a better one later on. But let me tell you, I think I'll buy this one again if, and when, my first one needs replacement. I'm a big believer in taking care of things no matter the price you paid, and with that said, if you take care of this &#34;inexpensive&#34; brush, there's no reason it shouldn't last you for years --like I said, it's been 4 years since I've purchased mine, and it still does a great job.
  4635. I think this is a great brush for the money. A few hairs fell out on the first couple uses, but it stopped soon after that. It's soft and works well. Can't beat it for the money!

A couple of pumps from the shave cream and it completely lathers my face. I can run over my face with the electric razor once, and still able to re-apply several times if needed. A simple rinse under the sink and it's clean and ready for the next time.<br />Highly recommend getting a brush stand so it drys upside down to prevent the bristles from losing shape.<br />Get it!!!

Pros - price (mine cost under 10 USD), real badger hair, compact size, dries well in down position. Cons - not as soft as some other badger hair or synthetic brushes, handle is light weight wood (would prefer a bit more heft), packaging is unremarkable for gifting purposes.

Seriously, when you soak the bristles in warm water, it's impossible not to feel that you're brushing your face with a bedraggled forest creature.<br /><br />Combined with the ethical concerns about badger treatment, I have no hesitation saying: Go for synthetic.

  4704. This was my first badger brush and I noticed right away that when rinsing it after shaving, the rinse water was brown colored. Since this was a &#34;natural&#34; badger brush, I was patient and eventually there was no more color loss when rinsing. I then noticed that the brush was losing bristles with each use - on the order of a dozen or more at first, and now - after several months of use - it still drops 6-10 bristles per use. I held the brush up and purposely plucked any bristles that were noticeably longer than the rest; wow, I gently removed over a dozen with very little effort. I hope this is not a typical issue with badger brushes as I do enjoy using it - just don't enjoy dealing with all the loose bristles and wondering what the results from my next shave will be.
  4705. Great brush, great price.<br /><br />There are some comments about how these brushes can smell out of the box, and yes, this one had a mild scent to it out of the packaging, however after the first use it was gone.<br /><br />Pro:<br />Soft bristles, comfortable in the hand, the wood handle is a nice touch, bristles spread evenly, retains water (depending on how you view that, it could be a con) unless you shake / wring it out. It does hold lather very well once you get it built up. Very attractive design in my opinion. The finish on the handle is as shiny as the photo indicates, and the gold ring is a nice touch as well.<br /><br />Con:<br />Some of the hairs came out on the first use (~8-12), more on the second use (~5-8), basically none on the third and consequent uses (maybe one or two). The loss of hairs isn't noticeable and does not impact the use of the brush. Takes a while to build a lather on the soaps I have. Again, this may be a reflection on MY SOAP not the brush.<br /><br />The only reason for 4/5 stars is just due to the fact that on the first use, a bunch of bristles came out which gave me a negative first impression. As stated, however, this stopped and my impression has since reversed.<br /><br />This brush was exactly what I was looking for at a cheaper price than I anticipated. The 'cheaper' price, however does not reflect a cheaper quality. This will get the job done, and well too... just make sure you squeeze out the final rinse water, and try to sore it bristles down hanging from something. It does hold water well, and I've had to fluff the bristles out a bit to ensure it dries properly.
  4706. Hairs fall out constantly on every use, doesn't feel like it creates a good/thick lather. Not that happy with this. I know most are, but maybe it was the way mine was manufactured (I'm not ignorant, I know that can happen).
  4707. It is kind of coarse at first but softens up quickly. great shaving brush.
  4708. Disclaimers: 1. First time buying a shaving brush at all, so I'm not going off previous experience and basically chose this brand/company blindly; and 2. Wasn't used to shave a man's face but woman legs, so I might (somehow) be using it wrong or differently from what you're gonna use it for.<br /><br />Loses a couple hairs each session but specifically a couple; it doesn't appear to be falling apart as others have reported. There's at least one small knot of bristles that may have been from applying it too hard the first couple times, or I just didn't notice when I first opened it.<br /><br />Out of the box, the packaging gives the impression that there's a magical, wonderful City of God that sells high-quality badger brushes on endcaps like they're potato chips.<br /><br />Followed another reviewer's tip and bought some velcro and applied one side to the bottom so it can dry brush-side down; through a couple uses since then and it hasn't failed yet.<br /><br />Overall satisfied with the quality for the price--and definitely after looking at the price of others, will likely buy this kind again.
  4709. Excellent service. I will buy all my shaving supplies from this company. Good brush and good value for the money. Seems like it's gonna last at least a couple of years.
  4710. This is a high quality brush. It is very soft and creates a nice thick lather. A few tips:<br />1. Soak in hot water for a few hours, then lather and leave for a few hours before rinsing and using. This will tame the natural odor and soften before first use.<br />2. I screwed a small eye hook into the butt of the handle and a small hook in the top of my linen closet so that it hangs brush down to dry properly.<br />3. To use, I use a small glass to soak the bristles in hot water while I shower. Shake it once to clear the water, then use one pump of shaving cream into your palm and lather with the brush. Rub over the area to be shaved, alternating circular and downward strokes to coat all sides of the hair.
  4711. Its a great brush if you are just starting into DE shaving. It's value for money. Expect it to last couple of years till you master lathering and shaving technique.

  4755. Let me preface with the fact that most people's complaints can be solved by running shaving soap through the brush 3 or 4 times prior to first use.<br /><br />Hair loss - Lost 4-5 per use initially, but this slowed to a hair or two per use just like my last brush. I expect it will stop completely after a couple weeks of use, also like my last brush. You can easily see loose hairs that are protruding from the brush before you put it on your face - it's nothing truly bothersome. Again, just wash it a few times pror to use.<br /><br />Animal smell - No smell ever ends up on my face... besides, I use an aftershave (as you should). The brush itself had a tiny bit of a smell the first couple uses, but it washes away quickly (and is typical of affordable rushes). More expensive companies wash this smell out first. Personally, I'll save $40 on a brush and just wash it out myself.<br /><br />Size - The same size as every brush I've ever owned and seen. Fits your generic brush holder.<br /><br />Texture - very soft. If you get a coarse one, I recommend you return it for a replacement of the same brand. I did not have any coarseness issues at all.<br /><br />Durability - I'll have to report on this later, but please keep in mind there are a handful of steps to PROPERLY care for a brush. Most people who only get 6 months out of a brush are not properly handling it during use.
  4756. The full badger is a definite step up from the mixed bristle (boar) brushes you typically find around this price point. It is well worth it.
  4758. Recently in New York I had my first straight razor shave. It was amazing. I didn't have to shave for days. I've been using a Braun for years, and never realized that I wasn't really getting a close shave, so I decided to give the safety razor a try. I read that Badger hair was the softest, so I bought this brush. I'm not really in a position to compare brushes, but this seems fine. I like the grip and wooden handle. It's soft, but not as soft as I thought it would be. It makes a good soap lather. I always notice a few badger hairs in the soap or on my face, but I'm assuming that's normal.
  4759. I used this to replace my Art of Shaving badger brush. I was a little worried that the quality would not be the same since the product was relatively inexpensive, but it works great! I would definitely recommend it to anyone.
  4760. Nice brush, good value. Would give 5 stars if I had long term experience with this product. It's lost a few bristles in the 1/2 dozen first uses, but this may just be the initial break-in..
  4761. OK, I've been using a brush and shave soap for at least a decade or so. Once you try it you won't go back to a can and your hand. The brush I use is this cheap thing I bought at a pharmacy somewhere during my travels. Red and white base, light bristles, don't know who made it. Always worked very well. I decided it was getting old so I figured I'd try a new one. Since I paid about 5 bucks for it, I figured I was safe going cheap again. Oops.<br /><br />I'm not at all keen on this Escali brush. It sheds like my old cat and it's bristles are about as soft as her fur. It's workable when using tube soap (like Proraso) even though it gets all spread out on your face if you bear down even a little bit. It's almost useless if you are trying to work up a lather with a soap puck in a cup (Williams Mug, good stuff). Not only that, but even though it's supposed to be pure badger, I swear it's losing color as well as bristles. Maybe it's pure &#34;dyed&#34; badger.<br /><br />I've also got an Art of Shaving travel brush that I paid a few dollars more for. I like that one a lot - properly stiff, no shed and a good feel on the whiskers. Too small for daily use, though.<br /><br />Anyway, I'm going to give it to an artist friend of mine - maybe he can get some interesting textures out of it before it loses the rest of its bristles.
  4762. The Escali brush is great, very reasonably priced, quality Badger hair, which is always stiff before warming up in hot water. This brush loads the shaving soap very easily. In fact I use less soap than before with previous brushes....I have been using Taylor of Old Bond St shaving cream, which is pricey, this brush just needs a little tap and twist into the soap and it loads extremely well. This brush is definitely one of the best brushes I've used since my shaving history since 1972..
  4763. Good not great brush. Hairs are not packed tightly as a higher end brush, but good value.

  4817. So I ordered this brush when I first got into straight-shaving. I didn't want to invest a ton of money on some fancy pants silver tipped badger brush, not knowing if I would continue using a straight razor. Over a year has passed and, while I don't straight shave very often any more, I use this brush ever time I shave. Reading other reviews I expected to see some bristles falling out the first couple times I used it, and I wasn't disappointed. The first maybe 10 times I lathered up, I would lose 2-3 bristles each time. I also noticed the distinct \\"animal\\" smell some other users reported the first couple times I used it. Honestly, this is not a huge deal. I still got a wonderful lather with very little effort and the animal smell is long gone. If the animal smell turns you off, don't buy a product made from the hair of an animal. The important thing to remember is that you have to care for this product correctly. Rinse it out VERY well BEFORE you use it for the first time. Also, if you put it away wet with soap still in it, the brush won't last as long for you. Rinse it out and flick the water out of it when you're done and it will last. I've had mine for over a year of daily use and I don't have any intentions of getting another one because I simply don't need to yet. Although at less than $15, I won't hesitate to buy this same brush again when I have to. Those that complain about this brush and say \\"you get what you pay for\\" must be used to spending (wasting) a ton of money on an expensive, top-of-the-line silver tipped badger brush. I'm not knocking you if you have that kind of cash to throw around on frivolous luxuries, but if you're a working class guy like me, with 3 kids and a mortgage, I promise you won't be disappointed with this brush. You'll get a better, more comfortable shave lathering up with a brush than you do with that canned s*** foam and your hand. This brush is priced similar to boar's hair brushes, which are ALL crap, so don't torture your skin by trying to save a few nickels by buying one of them. To summarize, this brush is WELL worth the small investment. With proper care it will last you quite some time, all while giving you a great shaving experience. I would also recommend that, while you're shopping for shaving gear on Amazon, grab some good quality shaving soap or cream. It makes a big difference.
  4818. This is a great product. I'm glad I bought it.
  4819. I'm 6 months into DE shaving and a VDH boar was my starter brush. The Escali is a huge step up in foam generating speed. I generate lather in a bowl, so bristle softness (or lack thereof) is not relevant for me. With a dab of Proraso cream, I can whip up the most luxurious lather in 20 seconds.<br /><br />The brush is quite well made - I've not lost any fibers bar some initial shedding during the 1st week of use. There was a very strong odor out of the box, but 5 washes with shampoo, conditioner and shaving cream, followed by a thorough drying took care of it. I hang it upside down (under my sink) and it dries out very quickly (much faster than the boar brush used to).<br /><br />The brush runs on the small side, but considering the amount of lather it can generate, I don't see the need of purchasing anything bigger. Highly recommended!
  4820. I started using a DE razon for about a year and had been using the shaving cream in the can. I decided to try the shaving bar soap and bought this Escali. It's cheap and nice to use. The smell has mostly wore off and is a bit more noticable when wet. At first, I thought it would smell like \\"wet dog\\" based on some reviews here. Not really that strong. A few hairs fell of the first time I used it. Now, maybe one hair falls out every 4-5 uses. I let it dry upside down at least 24 hours before each use.<br /><br />Here's a neat space saving tip for drying if you don't want to buy a metal stand for the brush. Go buy a square of sticky velcro like this [[ASIN:B00006IC2K Velcro Sticky Back Pre-Cut Squares, White (90073)]]. Attach the hooks part under the brush and attach the loops (fuzzy side) to the bottom of your medicine cabinet shelf. When done using the brush, you can just hang it, like a bat in a cave.
